The bill is expected to decrease general fund revenues by over $1 million annually. DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and managing the fiscal health of the state's budget.

The bill concerns 'qualified retirement plans' under the Internal Revenue Code. As the manager of 12 distinct retirement plans for the state's public workforce, the agency oversees assets that could be subject to the theft or fraud described in the legislation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Teachers & State Employees Supplemental Retirement Plans
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency manages voluntary savings plans (401k, 403b, and 457b) which are specifically defined as qualified retirement plans under the IRC and would be subject to the tax protections offered by the bill in the event of theft or fraud.

MarylandSaves oversees retirement accounts for private-sector employees. These accounts are qualified retirement vehicles whose participants could potentially be victims of the fraud schemes targeted by this subtraction modification.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency coordinates statewide public safety policy and manages programs for victims of crime. The bill creates a fiscal remedy for victims of criminal theft and fraud schemes.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill modifies the definition of a historic motor vehicle for registration purposes. It changes the eligibility requirement from being a model year of 1999 or earlier to being at least 25 years old. The bill maintains existing usage restrictions, prohibiting the use of these vehicles for general daily transportation or commercial purposes, and preserves existing fee structures and inspection exemptions for certain older vehicles.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners of motor vehicles that are at least 25 years old and the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill establishes registration fees for historic vehicles at $55.50 annually (effective July 2025) and a one-time fee of $50.00 for vehicles at least 60 years old. These fees contribute to the Transportation Trust Fund. The bill's fiscal impact is limited to future registrations, as it applies prospectively and does not affect vehicles registered as historic before July 1, 2026.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the Maryland Governor's Office is the principal executive agency, it is responsible for overseeing the state departments, such as MDOT and MDE, that must implement the changes to historic vehicle registration and environmental exemptions.
The Comptroller serves as the state's fiscal watchdog and revenue collector; changes to the definition of historic vehicles affect the registration fees directed to the Transportation Trust Fund.
The DBM oversees the formulation of the state budget and estimates revenues; changes to vehicle registration eligibility have a fiscal impact on state revenue projections.

The MDE is impacted because historic vehicles are exempt from emissions inspections and controls; expanding or altering the pool of eligible vehicles affects the scope of MDE's air quality regulations.
MDOT is the primary department responsible for the state's transportation network and the management of the Transportation Trust Fund, which will be affected by changes to vehicle registration fees.
The Maryland State Police enforce motor vehicle and highway safety laws; changes to registration criteria and inspection exemptions affect their enforcement protocols on state roadways.
The MVA is the primary agency responsible for managing vehicle registrations, issuing historic plates, and updating the criteria for historic motor vehicle status as defined by this bill.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor to state agencies, including MDOT and the MVA, regarding the interpretation and enforcement of new transportation statutes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill creates exceptions to the mandatory seven-day waiting period for the sale, rental, or transfer of a regulated firearm for specific individuals, including law enforcement officers, retired law enforcement officers in good standing, and individuals who hold a valid permit to wear, carry, or transport a handgun.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Law enforcement officers, retired law enforcement officers, handgun permit holders, and regulated firearms dealers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $100,000 in FY 2027 for one-time programming costs to update the Department of State Police licensing portal so that it can recognize exemptions and automate approval notifications. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Police is the primary agency responsible for regulating firearms and dealer licenses in the state. The bill specifically modifies the waiting period for regulated firearms, and the fiscal note identifies a $100,000 general fund expenditure for the agency to update its licensing portal to accommodate the proposed exemptions.

As the chief legal advisor for state agencies, including the Maryland State Police, the Office of the Attorney General would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the new exemptions to the firearm waiting period and ensuring compliance with state law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency serves as the state's central hub for public safety policy. The bill proposes a significant shift in firearm acquisition policy for law enforcement and permit holders, which falls under their mission to advise on criminal justice strategies and public safety initiatives.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for overseeing the state's annual operating budget. The bill involves a specific fiscal impact of $100,000 in general fund expenditures for system updates, which requires coordination with this agency for budget allocation.

The Department of General Services manages the Maryland Capitol Police. These officers qualify as law enforcement officers under the bill and would be directly eligible for the seven-day waiting period exemption when purchasing or transferring regulated firearms.

The Department of Natural Resources oversees the Natural Resources Police (NRP). NRP officers are law enforcement personnel who would benefit from the proposed exemptions to the standard firearm waiting period.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency employs law enforcement officers, including those within the Division of Parole and Probation and the Baltimore Pretrial Complex, who would be eligible for the expedited firearm transfer process established by this bill.

The Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) oversees the MDTA Police. Its officers would qualify for the law enforcement officer exception for the sale, rental, or transfer of regulated firearms under the bill.
The University System of Maryland was identified in the fiscal note as an information source. It employs campus police officers who would be eligible for the exemptions created by the bill.

Saint Mary's College of Maryland was identified in the fiscal note as an information source. It employs law enforcement officers for campus security who would qualify for the bill's waiting period exceptions.

The Maryland Center for School Safety provides training for School Resource Officers (SROs). These officers are law enforcement personnel who would be subject to the bill's waiting period exceptions when obtaining regulated firearms.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Baltimore County to grant property tax credits for dwellings owned by public safety officers and employees of the Baltimore County public school system. The county government is responsible for defining the specific amount, duration, and eligibility criteria for these credits.
qa_results.responsible_party: The governing body of Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Public safety officers, Baltimore County public school system employees, and the Baltimore County government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances but will cause a significant decrease in Baltimore County property tax revenues starting in FY 2027. The Department of Legislative Services estimates that revenue loss could exceed $5.0 million annually, depending on the credit's implementation details. There is no reported impact on county expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor must sign or veto the legislation, which mandates that a local jurisdiction (Baltimore County) grant specific property tax credits.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the General Assembly and state agencies; it would likely be responsible for reviewing the legality and implementation of a state-mandated local tax credit.
The bill provides a direct fiscal benefit via a property tax credit to employees of the Baltimore County public school system, an area of the workforce overseen by MSDE.
Many state troopers reside in Baltimore County and would qualify for the property tax credit under the 'public safety officer' provision, impacting personnel recruitment and retention for the agency.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency's correctional officers and parole/probation agents residing in Baltimore County would qualify as public safety officers eligible for the mandated tax credit.

PTAAB is the second-level administrative appeal body for property tax matters and specific tax credit programs; it may be called upon to adjudicate eligibility disputes for this newly mandated credit.
The Maryland Tax Court is the highest administrative review body for tax controversies and has jurisdiction over appeals related to property tax assessments and credits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires each county board of education to allow the use of therapy dogs in public schools. Each board must adopt a policy for the handling and use of these dogs, which must include certification requirements, guidelines for handlers, specific locations and times where dogs are permitted, notification protocols for the school community, and plans for managing allergies or fears among students and staff.
qa_results.responsible_party: County boards of education
qa_results.stakeholders: Public school students, faculty, staff, parents, and therapy dog handlers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not specify a direct state or local funding allocation. Local school systems will likely experience a minor fiscal impact related to the administrative costs of developing and implementing the required therapy dog policies and managing notification requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary oversight agency for Maryland's public K-12 education system, the Department of Education is responsible for the state-level policies that govern county boards of education and their implementation of new school-based programs like therapy dog initiatives.

This agency focuses on fostering inclusive learning environments and addressing the emotional well-being of the school community. Therapy dogs are specifically intended to provide emotional support and comfort to students, falling directly within the agency's mission to support student well-being.

The Department of Disabilities is a cross-disability policy leader that advocates for accessible environments. While therapy dogs are distinct from service animals, the policy requirements regarding allergies and student discomfort overlap with the agency's work on barrier-free environments and inclusive school settings.

The OAG would likely provide legal counsel to the State Department of Education and county boards in developing these policies, ensuring compliance with federal and state laws regarding animal presence in public facilities and addressing liability concerns related to handlers and dogs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires nonprofit entities that receive at least 50% of their annual funding from Maryland state or local government grants, the state capital budget, or local impact grants to report their funding details to the Comptroller. The reports must include the amount of funding received and a description of how it was used. The Comptroller is then required to provide an annual summary of these reports to the General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit entities (501(c) corporations) receiving significant public funding, the Comptroller's Office, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not contain the Fiscal and Policy Note; however, the bill's requirements involve administrative costs for the Comptroller's Office to collect and summarize reports and compliance costs for affected nonprofit organizations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly designates the Comptroller as the agency responsible for receiving, collecting, and summarizing reports from nonprofit entities, and subsequently reporting that information to the General Assembly.

As the central coordinating body for state grant activities, this office is highly relevant because the bill creates new financial transparency and reporting requirements for nonprofits receiving state, county, or municipal grants.

The Secretary of State regulates the registration and oversight of charitable organizations (501(c) nonprofits). This bill adds a specific fiscal reporting layer for a subset of the organizations already under its regulatory purview.
The bill impacts the oversight of state-funded entities, specifically those receiving money from the state capital and operating budgets, which DBM helps formulate and manage.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill identifies 'Local Impact Grants' as a trigger for reporting requirements; these grants are funded by gaming revenue overseen by this agency.

The Board approves significant state expenditures, including capital budget items and grants, which are the primary funding sources that trigger the reporting requirements for nonprofits under this bill.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies and would be responsible for auditing the Comptroller’s implementation of this reporting system and the accountability of the public funds described.

This authority specifically oversees the allocation of Local Impact Aid, which is explicitly named in the bill as one of the types of funding that requires a recipient nonprofit to report to the Comptroller.
The OAG would likely provide legal counsel to the Comptroller regarding the interpretation of nonprofit qualifications and compliance enforcement related to the new reporting mandates.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Comptroller and other departments involved in grant-making and would be responsible for signing this transparency measure into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits deed fraud, including the intentional fraudulent sale, lease, or conveyance of real property by someone who does not own the property, as well as obtaining property through deception, intimidation, or undue influence. It establishes the Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund to support law enforcement, provide legal services for victims, and offer emergency housing assistance. The bill also creates a Task Force to Study Deed Fraud and requires the Maryland Department of State Police to report specific disaggregated data regarding deed fraud incidents.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of deed fraud, Maryland property owners, state and local law enforcement agencies, and legal services providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $48,900 in FY 2027 for administrative staffing, and the bill mandates a $200,000 appropriation in FY 2028 to capitalize the Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund. The Department of State Police estimates that one-time programming costs to update the National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS) could exceed $1,000,000. Local law enforcement agencies will also likely incur significant programming costs. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase by $200,000 annually starting in FY 2028 to reflect the grant fund operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Department of State Police as the administrator of the newly created Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund and requires the agency to collect and report disaggregated data on deed fraud incidents as part of its mandated crime reporting program.
The bill mandates that the Administrative Office of the Courts provide staff for the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud and includes a representative of the Judiciary on the task force.

The Governor is responsible for appointing members to the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud, designating its chair, and is mandated to include a $200,000 appropriation for the grant fund in the fiscal year 2028 budget.

The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a designated member of the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud, and the agency deals with property records and neighborhood revitalization affected by fraud.
The Attorney General is a designated member of the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud, and the office is generally responsible for consumer protection and advising the State on criminal law matters.
The agency oversees the state budget, including the mandated appropriation of $200,000 in fiscal 2028 and the personnel costs associated with the new grant program mentioned in the fiscal note.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund separately and investing its funds.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the newly established Deed Fraud Prevention Grant Fund.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud, a specialized body that fits this categorization for state government study groups tasked with investigating specific policy areas.
This office is responsible for vetting candidates to serve on the state's commissions and task forces, including the Governor's appointees to the Task Force to Study Deed Fraud.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new felony offense and a misdemeanor for deed fraud, impacting the state's correctional and parole/probation systems overseen by this agency.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits Maryland state and local government units from denying licenses, permits, registrations, or services, and educational institutions from expelling or refusing to admit individuals, based solely on their refusal to disclose expunged criminal records. It also requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Judiciary to remove all references to criminal cases from the Maryland Electronic Courts (MDEC) system where the only charge was cannabis possession and the case was disposed of before July 1, 2023.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with expunged criminal records, specifically those with past cannabis possession charges; applicants for state and local government licenses and services; and applicants to educational institutions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures will increase for the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Judiciary to implement necessary updates to the MDEC system. The bill also establishes misdemeanor penalties for violations of disclosure prohibitions, which may result in minimal increases in state revenues from fines and minimal increases in state and local expenditures for law enforcement and incarceration.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly prohibits the Maryland Electronic Courts (MDEC) system and Maryland Judiciary Case Search, both managed by the Administrative Office of the Courts, from referring to specific cannabis-related cases.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services remove specific cannabis-only charges from the MDEC system and Central Repository.

The bill prohibits educational institutions from expelling or refusing to admit individuals based on their refusal to disclose expunged information, which impacts MSDE's oversight of state educational entities.
As the coordinating body for higher education, MHEC is relevant to the bill's provisions regarding educational institutions' admission and expulsion policies related to expunged criminal records.

The bill prohibits units from denying licenses or permits based on the refusal to disclose expunged information. The Department of Labor manages numerous professional trade licenses that are directly affected.

The Maryland Department of Health licenses dozens of health-related professions and facilities; the bill's restrictions on using expunged records for licensing denials directly impact their regulatory units.
The MVA issues licenses and permits that fall under the bill's prohibition on denying such documents based solely on the refusal to disclose expunged criminal charges.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the state agencies impacted by this bill and would be involved in defending or enforcing the criminal penalties established for violations of non-disclosure protections.

As a system of 12 public universities, USM is directly impacted by the bill's prohibition on educational institutions using a refusal to disclose expunged information as grounds for expulsion or denial of admission.
Morgan State University, as an independent state educational institution, must comply with the bill's provisions regarding admissions and expulsions related to expunged criminal information.
As a public educational institution, Saint Mary's College is subject to the bill's requirements concerning student admissions and the non-disclosure of expunged records.
The Comptroller's office issues various business licenses and is therefore subject to the provision that prohibits license denial based on the refusal to disclose expunged criminal history.
The Maryland State Police use criminal records for various licensing and permit functions (such as firearm permits) and will be affected by the removal of certain cannabis charges from MDEC.

While the MCA is primarily a regulatory agency for current industry, the bill's focus on historical cannabis possession expungements is relevant to the broader policy framework governing cannabis in Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows intercepted wire, oral, or electronic communications and related evidence to be used in criminal trials in Maryland if the court determines the case involves a crime against a person, the evidence is material and highly probative, and the interception was not conducted by Maryland law enforcement. The party wishing to use the evidence must provide 14 days' notice to the opposing side.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (District Court and Circuit Court)
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of crimes, criminal defendants, and the legal community (prosecutors and defense attorneys)

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly alters the rules of evidence admissibility in criminal trials and hearings before the District and Circuit Courts, which the Administrative Office of the Courts supports and oversees.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency representing indigent individuals in criminal cases, the expansion of admissible intercepted communication evidence directly impacts their legal strategies and the evidence they must challenge or utilize in court.

The OAG handles all criminal appeals and provides legal advice to the state. Changes to evidence admissibility for intercepted communications will likely result in increased litigation and appeals where the OAG serves as the state's representative.

The OSP investigates and prosecutes misconduct and government-related crimes. The ability to use intercepted communications (not initiated by law enforcement) as evidence of material facts is highly relevant to their prosecutorial work.

While the bill specifies the exception applies to interceptions not made by law enforcement, the MSP is the primary state law enforcement agency and will be impacted by the rules governing evidence provided by third parties in criminal cases.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office coordinates statewide public safety policy and criminal justice grants. The bill represents a significant policy shift regarding privacy and the admissibility of evidence in criminal proceedings.

The Governor's Office oversees the execution of state laws and public safety initiatives. This legislation requires executive approval and aligns with the office's role in governing criminal justice standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill significantly reduces Maryland's primary tax rates by establishing a flat 3% individual income tax rate for filers with federal adjusted gross income over $10,000 and reducing the corporate income tax rate from 8.25% to 3%. It also cuts the general sales and use tax rate from 6% to 3%, repeals the sales and use tax on specific data and information technology services, and reduces tax rates on alcoholic beverages and cannabis to 3%. Additionally, the bill modifies the taxation of net capital gains, applying an additional 3% tax while providing a $10,000 exemption for individuals aged 65 and older.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland individual and corporate taxpayers, general consumers, residents aged 65 and older, and businesses in the information technology and software publishing sectors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill will result in a substantial reduction in State General Fund revenues and distributions to special funds, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future Fund, due to significant rate cuts across individual income, corporate income, and sales and use taxes. Local government revenues may also be affected by the reduction of the combined tax rate cap for admissions and amusement taxes from 11% to 8%.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's elected chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for implementing and managing the sweeping changes to individual and corporate income tax rates, as well as the broad reductions in sales and use tax rates.

The bill's substantial reductions in income and sales tax revenue will have a significant impact on state revenue estimates and the formulation of the annual operating budget, which this department oversees.

The reduction of the corporate income tax rate from 8.25% to 3% and the repeal of sales taxes on data, IT, and software publishing services are major economic development initiatives that directly affect the department's mission to attract and expand businesses in Maryland.

The bill impacts the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future Fund, which is funded through a percentage of sales and use tax revenue. Significant reductions in the sales tax rate will directly affect the funding available for the MSDE's landmark education initiatives.

As the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, the Tax Court will be responsible for adjudicating disputes arising from the new tax rates, net capital gains rules, and aged-based exemptions.

The repeal of sales and use taxes on IT services, computer systems design, and software publishing specifically targets and benefits the technology startup ecosystem that TEDCO supports through funding and resources.

This bill represents a major executive policy shift in the state's fiscal structure and revenue allocation, requiring oversight from the Governor's Office in coordination with the budget and various departments.

The Treasurer manages the state's financial assets and credit ratings; such a large-scale reduction in tax revenue could impact the state's fiscal health, borrowing costs, and the Board of Public Works decisions.

OLA will be responsible for conducting fiscal compliance audits of the Comptroller and other agencies to ensure the new tax rates and specific exemptions (such as for seniors) are accurately implemented and applied.

As the highest administrative authority on state spending, the Board's oversight of capital improvements and state contracts is directly impacted by the availability of tax revenues, which the bill significantly alters.
The bill alters sales and use tax rates for vehicle rentals and references the Transportation Article for vehicle definitions, which impacts revenues and regulatory frameworks managed by MDOT.

The team’s focus on economic mobility and data-driven government services is directly relevant to these major changes in income and sales tax, which affect the overall economic landscape for low-income families and small businesses.

MHEC’s administration of financial aid and the funding for the state's public colleges and universities depend on general fund revenues, which are substantially decreased by these tax rate reductions.
The bill creates a specific income tax exemption for the first $10,000 of net capital gains for individuals aged 65 and older, which is the primary demographic served by this department.

The repeal of sales taxes on IT services impacts the economic welfare and professional licensing environment for the information technology and software development sectors regulated by the department.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Comptroller and state agencies regarding the interpretation and enforcement of new tax laws and would represent the state in complex tax-related litigation.
Changes to tax law may lead to an increase in judicial proceedings or administrative appeals that require support from the AOC's technological and financial infrastructure.
The exchange uses adjusted gross income data to determine eligibility for health insurance subsidies; changes to state income tax thresholds and definitions may require administrative system updates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a legal framework for family members and interested parties to petition a court for reasonable visitation with an incapacitated or protected person. It creates a rebuttable presumption that such visitation is in the person's best interest, while allowing courts to impose restrictions or deny petitions based on specific criteria, such as the person's prior wishes or evidence of abuse. The bill also requires authorized decision-makers to disclose the individual's location or funeral arrangements upon request and provides civil immunity for health care facilities and decision-makers acting in good faith.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Incapacitated or protected persons, their spouses, adult children, adult grandchildren, parents, and adult siblings, as well as legal guardians and health care facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new legal cause of action for visitation with incapacitated or protected persons, directly impacting the operations, caseload, and procedures of the Maryland Judiciary, which the AOC manages and supports.

The department advocates for older adults and manages the Long-Term Care Ombudsman. Since many incapacitated or protected persons are seniors in nursing homes or assisted living facilities, this bill directly affects the residents and programs the department oversees.

The bill regulates visitation in health care facilities such as nursing homes and hospitals, which are licensed and regulated by MDH. It also references surrogate decision-making laws within the Health - General Article.

DHS oversees adult protective services and welfare programs for vulnerable adults who may be subjects of visitation petitions. The bill's focus on protected persons and legal guardianships overlaps significantly with DHS responsibilities.

Individuals with disabilities frequently fall into the category of protected or incapacitated persons. MDOD coordinates policy for these residents and ensures their rights to access and independence, which include visitation rights.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and the General Assembly. It would be responsible for interpreting how this new visitation title interacts with existing laws regarding healthcare, estates, and the rights of protected persons.

The Register of Wills maintains records for guardianships and powers of attorney, which the bill uses to define the interested parties who are eligible to petition for visitation with a protected person.

The agency serves veterans who may be incapacitated or residing in long-term care facilities, making the visitation rights and information requirements established in this bill relevant to their constituent advocacy.
As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of state departments impacted by this bill and is responsible for signing or vetoing the legislation.
DBM acts as the state's central fiscal authority and may be required to evaluate the fiscal impact on the judiciary or other state agencies tasked with responding to the new court processes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the governing body of a political subdivision, including Baltimore City, to designate noncontiguous 'blighted areas' as development districts under the Tax Increment Financing (TIF) Act. It defines a blighted area as one where a majority of buildings have declined in productivity due to obsolescence or depreciation to the point that repairs are no longer justified.
qa_results.responsible_party: The governing bodies of Maryland political subdivisions (counties and municipalities) and Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Local governments, property owners in blighted areas, and small businesses in construction or those located within redeveloped districts
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State finances. Local revenues and expenditures are projected to increase starting in FY 2027 as local governments issue TIF bonds and use those revenues for debt service and authorized development projects. Baltimore City is not expected to see an impact as its charter already allows for noncontiguous TIF districts.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary economic development agency, the Department of Commerce is responsible for stimulating investment and fostering job creation. Tax Increment Financing (TIF) is a core economic development tool, and this bill modifies the authority for local jurisdictions to use this tool, specifically targeting blighted areas which falls under Commerce's mission to support business expansion and community growth.

MEDCO is a quasi-public agency that issues revenue bonds to fund large-scale projects and industrial development. The fiscal note explicitly mentions that local revenues may be pledged to debt issued by MEDCO in TIF-related circumstances, making the agency a primary vehicle for the bond financing enabled by this bill.

The DHCD is specifically tasked with the rehabilitation of blighted areas and fostering the revitalization of neighborhoods. This bill defines 'blighted areas' and provides a financing mechanism (noncontiguous TIF districts) specifically designed to address these areas, directly aligning with DHCD's core mission.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth efforts and provides technical assistance to local governments for urban design and infrastructure management. The designation of development districts is a land-use planning function that impacts the demographic and economic research managed by the department.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and the General Assembly. This bill makes statutory changes to the Economic Development Article of the Maryland Code, requiring legal review and advisory services from the OAG.

This multi-agency initiative promotes sustainable growth and economic revitalization. Expanding TIF authority to noncontiguous blighted areas supports the initiative's goals of directing development into existing communities and balancing growth with resource conservation.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of state departments and signs or vetoes legislation passed by the General Assembly. This bill impacts state economic development policy, a key area of executive oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Public Ethics Law to restrict the conditions under which Legislative Branch officials may accept gifts of food and beverages. It eliminates the exemption for gifts provided to specific 'legislative units' (such as committees or delegations), requiring instead that all members of the General Assembly be invited and that the event be open to the public for the gift to be permissible. Additionally, it extends the advance notice period for lobbyists from 5 to 14 days for these events and requires the Department of Legislative Services to post event information on the General Assembly website within one business day of registration.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Ethics Commission; Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland General Assembly members, Legislative Branch officials and employees, regulated lobbyists, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided bill text does not include the official Fiscal Note. However, the bill's requirements for the Department of Legislative Services to manage online event notifications and for the State Ethics Commission to oversee modified lobbyist filings suggest a potential minimal administrative impact on state expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Maryland Public Ethics Law, which the State Ethics Commission is responsible for administering and enforcing. The changes specifically affect financial disclosure statements and lobbying reports filed with the Commission.

This agency is tasked with investigating and prosecuting violations of the Public Ethics Law. Amendments to the rules regarding gifts to legislative officials directly impact the OSP's oversight and enforcement mission.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the General Assembly and state agencies. They would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and implementation of these revised ethics standards.

While OLA is an auditing unit, it is an agency within the Department of Legislative Services (DLS). The bill places significant new administrative duties on DLS, including registering receptions and updating the General Assembly website within strict timeframes.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. The office also maintains an interest in the general integrity and application of public ethics laws across state government.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes mandatory qualifications, including specific licensure and training, for individuals appointed by Maryland courts as custody evaluators in family law cases. It also sets procedural requirements for court-ordered assessments and their costs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Administrative Office of the Courts
qa_results.stakeholders: Parents and children involved in contested custody or visitation cases, licensed mental health professionals, and court-contracted custody evaluators.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local finances and operations are not materially affected by the bill. Small businesses may see a minimal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires child custody evaluators to complete training programs that conform to guidelines established by the Administrative Office of the Courts (AOC). The AOC is also the central support agency for the judiciary, which oversees the appointment of these evaluators.

The bill establishes qualifications for custody evaluators based on licensure in fields such as psychiatry, psychology, marriage and family therapy, professional counseling, and social work. These professions are regulated by various boards under the jurisdiction of the Maryland Department of Health.

As the state's primary social service and child welfare provider, DHS employs and works with social workers and clinical professionals who are often involved in child custody assessments or meet the professional criteria to serve as evaluators.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the state and the judiciary; it would be responsible for advising on the implementation of these new statutory standards within the Family Law Article.

The bill's focus on evaluating the health, safety, and welfare of children in contested custody cases aligns with the GOC's mission to lead policy action and support networks for child well-being and family stability.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that engaging in nonconsensual sexual contact with another person in connection with a first-, second-, or third-degree burglary constitutes a third-degree sexual offense, which is a felony. It also updates the Maryland sex offender registry tiers to include these specific acts, classifying offenders as Tier I, II, or III based on whether the victim is a minor and the specific age of the minor.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of sexual offenses, individuals charged with or convicted of burglary and sexual contact offenses, local law enforcement agencies, and the Maryland Judiciary.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal increase in State expenditures due to enhanced incarceration penalties and changes in sex offender registration classifications. State revenues are not affected. Local revenues may see a minimal decrease because third-degree sexual offenses (felonies) do not carry the fines associated with fourth-degree sexual offenses (misdemeanors). Local expenditures are not expected to be affected as offenders are likely to be housed in State correctional facilities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is primarily responsible for managing Maryland’s adult correctional system and the state’s Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which includes the sex offender registry. The bill directly impacts the registration tiers and felony classifications that govern this registry and inmate management.

The Maryland Judiciary handles the trials, convictions, and sentencing for the criminal offenses defined in this bill. The fiscal note indicates potential impacts on circuit court workloads and judicial record-keeping systems like Case Search.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency represents indigent residents in criminal cases where incarceration is a possibility. Upgrading certain sexual contacts from a misdemeanor to a felony directly affects the caseload and defense strategy for their clients.
As the state's chief legal office, the OAG handles criminal appeals and provides legal counsel on the interpretation of the Criminal Law and Criminal Procedure articles modified by this legislation.
The MSP is responsible for investigating major crimes across the state, including the types of sexual offenses and burglaries expanded by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency serves as the central hub for public safety policy and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies, making changes to sexual offense and registration categories highly relevant to their mission.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This category includes the Maryland State Commission on Criminal Sentencing Policy, which is listed as an information source and monitors sentencing trends for the felony offenses altered by this bill.
The Governor’s Office oversees all executive agencies and is responsible for signing the bill into law and directing high-level public safety initiatives.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes November 11 as a tax-free day for veterans in Maryland for purchases under $2,000, requiring proof of veteran status. The Comptroller may suspend the tax-free day.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland veterans and retail vendors
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are estimated to decrease by approximately $41,700 and Blueprint for Maryland’s Future Fund revenues by $5,700 in FY 2027, totaling a $47,500 reduction. Future years show similar decreases based on forecasted sales growth. There is no impact on expenditures or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office oversees the state's budget and legislative process; this bill impacts general fund revenues and creates a new state-level tax benefit for veterans.

As the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller is responsible for implementing sales tax exemptions and is specifically granted the sole authority to suspend the Veterans' Day tax-free day.
The agency manages the state’s annual operating budget and estimates revenues; the bill's reduction of general fund and special fund revenues impacts fiscal planning.
The bill reduces revenue for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future Fund, which is the primary funding mechanism for MSDE’s initiatives and public K-12 education standards.
MDOT is the parent agency for the Motor Vehicle Administration, which produces the official state identification cards and licenses used to verify veteran status for the exemption.
The bill is entirely focused on providing a benefit to veterans; this agency serves as the primary advocate for Maryland's military community and helps them navigate such state benefits.
The MVA is responsible for issuing driver's licenses and identification cards with the specific veteran notation required as proof of eligibility under the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes uniform procedures for filling vacancies on county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners. It requires that vacancies for elected board positions occurring 55 days or more before the candidate filing deadline for the mid-term primary election be filled via election at the next general election. If a vacancy occurs 54 days or less before the deadline, or if no qualified candidates file for the election, the remaining board members must appoint a replacement through a public process involving advertising, livestreamed interviews, and a public vote. The bill also mandates that vacancies for appointed positions be filled within 60 days.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Boards of Education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of Maryland county school boards and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners, prospective school board candidates, local boards of elections, and registered voters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to increase local administrative expenditures for county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners due to new requirements for advertising vacancies and livestreaming candidate interviews. Additionally, local boards of elections may incur costs to include vacancy-filling contests on general election ballots. No specific Fiscal and Policy Note was included in the provided text to confirm exact state or local dollar impacts.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that vacancies on county boards of education and the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners be filled through elections if they occur before specific deadlines, requiring the Board of Elections to manage and supervise these processes in accordance with the Election Law Article.

The bill directly impacts the governance and administration of the state's public K-12 education systems. Additionally, the State Board of Education (within the department) retains authority over the removal of local board members as specified in several sections of the bill.

The Governor holds appointment authority for certain school boards mentioned in the bill, such as those in Baltimore and Caroline Counties. The bill alters how vacancies are handled, which impacts the Governor's executive appointment and oversight duties.

The Office of Appointments is responsible for vetting candidates for state boards and commissions. As the bill modifies procedures for filling vacancies—some of which are filled by Governor appointment—this agency would be responsible for recruiting and vetting qualified individuals.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to state agencies, including the State Department of Education and the State Board of Elections. It would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the revised vacancy and election procedures.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill grants collective bargaining rights to graduate assistants, including teaching, research, and administrative assistants, as well as fellows and postdoctoral interns, at the University System of Maryland (USM), Morgan State University (MSU), and St. Mary’s College of Maryland (SMCM). It requires the establishment of separate collective bargaining units for these eligible graduate assistants at each institution.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public Employee Relations Board (PERB)
qa_results.stakeholders: Graduate assistants, research assistants, teaching assistants, administrative assistants, fellows, and postdoctoral interns at public four-year higher education institutions; University System of Maryland; Morgan State University; St. Mary’s College of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase for USM institutions and MSU to reimburse the Public Employee Relations Board (PERB) for collective bargaining expenses; PERB's reimbursable revenues and expenditures increase accordingly. Administrative and personnel expenditures (salaries and fringe benefits) at USM and MSU may increase, potentially significantly, depending on the outcome of future collective bargaining negotiations. St. Mary's College of Maryland is unlikely to be affected in the near term as it currently reports no graduate assistants. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly designates the Public Employee Relations Board (PERB) as the governing body responsible for overseeing the establishment of bargaining units, conducting elections, and managing collective bargaining activities for graduate assistants.

The bill grants collective bargaining rights to thousands of graduate assistants at University System of Maryland (USM) constituent institutions, requiring USM to establish new bargaining units and engage in labor negotiations.

As a primary implementing institution, Morgan State University is specifically required by the bill to establish a separate bargaining unit for its graduate assistants and engage in the collective bargaining process.

As the state's central fiscal and personnel authority, DBM is responsible for the budget formulation and oversight regarding personnel costs. Negotiated increases in stipends or benefits for graduate assistants would impact the state's annual operating budget.

The bill explicitly includes St. Mary's College of Maryland as an institution that must provide collective bargaining rights to graduate assistants, even though the fiscal note indicates no such positions currently exist at the college.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state higher education institutions and the Public Employee Relations Board, and would likely represent these entities in disputes or legal interpretations arising from new collective bargaining agreements.

The Comptroller manages the state’s central payroll and acts as a fiscal watchdog. Changes in compensation or union dues for graduate assistants would require coordination with the state's payroll systems and fiscal reporting.

The commission is the state's coordinating board for public colleges and universities. While institutions manage their own labor relations, the bill impacts the general policy and financial landscape of the institutions MHEC oversees.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of higher education institutions and would be responsible for auditing the financial impact and adherence to state law regarding these new bargaining units and their associated expenditures.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill limits the amount of earnings that can be withheld for child support and arrearages to 25% of an individual's disposable earnings if their income does not exceed 250% of the federal poverty guidelines, unless the individual is found to be voluntarily impoverished. It also requires withholding notices to include information about these limits and allows employees to contest withholdings that exceed them.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services (specifically the Child Support Administration)
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-to-moderate income child support obligors, child support recipients, employers, and the Department of Human Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase by at least $3.8 million in FY 2027, which includes $3.1 million for one-time programming costs and salaries for additional staff. This is funded by approximately $1.3 million in general funds and $2.5 million in federal funds. Federal fund matching revenues increase accordingly. Ongoing annual expenditures are estimated to be between $800,000 and $900,000. No material fiscal impact is expected for local governments or the Judiciary.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Child Support Administration within DHS, which is the primary agency responsible for calculating withholding limits, issuing notices to employers, and managing the increased caseworker workload and system programming required by the new 25% cap.

The bill explicitly establishes the Office of Administrative Hearings as the venue for employees to appeal the results of a Child Support Administration investigation regarding whether earnings withholding exceeds the new statutory limits.

The bill defines 'earnings' to include unemployment insurance benefits, which are administered by the Department of Labor. These benefits will now be subject to the bill's new 25% withholding cap for child support obligors meeting the income criteria.

DBM is responsible for the state's personnel system and budget. This bill has a significant fiscal impact (at least $3.8 million in FY 2027) and requires the creation of multiple new staff positions within the executive branch.

The bill amends the Family Law Article governing the issuance of earnings withholding orders by the court system and introduces new legal criteria and hearing requirements for obligors who contest these orders based on the 25% limit.

As the agency responsible for managing the central payroll for over 100,000 state employees, the Comptroller's office must implement these withholding limits for any state worker subject to a child support order.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Human Services and the Child Support Administration, and would be involved in defending the state's implementation of these new limits or interpreting the 'voluntarily impoverished' exceptions.

The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Human Services and the overall state budget, and the bill's significant fiscal impact on executive agencies requires high-level administrative coordination.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Public Service Commission, in consultation with the Maryland Energy Administration, to study the costs and benefits of requiring electric companies to contract for at least 80% of their load-serving capacity. It also mandates a joint study on the feasibility and impacts of Maryland withdrawing from the PJM Interconnection capacity market model or the regional transmission organization altogether, potentially joining or forming an alternative organization.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public Service Commission and Maryland Energy Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Electric companies, electricity ratepayers, and PJM Interconnection, LLC
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund expenditures increase by $600,000 in fiscal 2027 for consultant services needed to conduct the studies. Special fund revenues increase correspondingly through assessments on regulated public service companies. No material impact on local governments or small businesses is expected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission is the primary agency responsible for conducting the studies mandated by the bill, which include analyzing electric company contracts and options for withdrawing from the PJM Interconnection capacity market.
The Maryland Energy Administration is jointly responsible for conducting the studies and making recommendations regarding capacity market models and regional transmission organizations.

As the independent advocate for residential utility consumers, this agency has a high interest in studies concerning electricity costs, PJM capacity market impacts on ratepayers, and the potential transition to new regional transmission organizations.
The Governor's Office is the recipient of the final report and oversees the state's energy policy; the bill's findings specifically reference the impact of PJM on State energy policies.
The bill focuses on the responsiveness of the electricity grid to state energy policies, which includes climate commitments and greenhouse gas reduction goals managed by the MDE.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the PSC and MEA and would likely be involved in reviewing the legal frameworks for withdrawing from PJM or establishing multistate compacts.

The bill explicitly calls for studying the development of a multistate compact and potential changes to Maryland's membership in regional transmission organizations, which is the core function of this governmental category.
Changes to capacity market models and electricity costs significantly impact the economic climate and business operating costs, which are primary concerns for the Department of Commerce.
The agency is responsible for accelerating clean energy adoption; changes in the capacity market and grid management directly affect the economic viability of renewable energy projects.
Grid reliability and the stability of regional transmission organizations are critical components of the state's homeland security and emergency preparedness infrastructure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund within the Office of the Attorney General to provide additional funding for its Antitrust Division. The fund will be composed of civil penalties for antitrust violations, court-awarded damages, attorney's fees, and supplemental state appropriations. The bill also mandates that the Governor include a budget appropriation sufficient to fund one new full-time investigator position for the division from fiscal year 2028 through 2033.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland consumers, businesses, and the Antitrust Division of the Office of the Attorney General.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill redirects civil penalty revenue (up to $10,000 per violation) from the General Fund to the newly created Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund. It also mandates an increase in state expenditures from fiscal year 2028 through 2033 to cover the salary and benefits of one new full-time investigator position.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Governor to include a specific appropriation in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2028 through 2033 to support a new position within the Office of the Attorney General.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the newly established Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund.
The bill specifies that the State Treasurer shall hold the Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund separately and invest its money in the same manner as other state funds.

The bill establishes the Fair Pricing and Market Competition Fund specifically to provide additional operating funds for the Antitrust Division of the OAG. The Attorney General is tasked with administering the fund and creating a new investigator position.

As the agency responsible for formulating the state budget and managing personnel positions (PINs), DBM is impacted by the bill's requirement for a specific budget appropriation and the creation of a new Position Identification Number for an investigator.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Administrator of Elections to take corrective action regarding election misinformation and disinformation, including disseminating accurate information, seeking injunctions for removal of content from online platforms, and issuing subpoenas. It also prohibits the use of deepfakes with the intent to influence voters or misrepresent facts about the electoral process, establishing criminal penalties for violations, and authorizes the State Board of Elections to pursue civil litigation to recover costs associated with correcting false information.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Administrator of Elections and the Maryland State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters, election officials, political candidates, political action committees, and online media platforms.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland State special fund revenues (Fair Campaign Financing Fund) and general fund revenues may increase annually beginning in fiscal 2027 due to criminal fines of up to $5,000 and the recovery of costs through civil actions. State expenditures are not directly affected as the State Board of Elections already monitors misinformation. Local government finances are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Elections is the primary agency responsible for the bill's implementation. The legislation explicitly mandates the State Administrator and the Board to maintain a reporting portal, investigate material, issue corrective information, seek injunctions for content removal, and file civil actions to recover costs.

The bill explicitly tasks the State Board of Elections with referring reports of election misinformation or disinformation to the Office of the State Prosecutor for investigation and criminal prosecution. This aligns with the agency's mission to protect the integrity of the electoral process.

The OAG serves as the legal representative for state agencies, including the State Board of Elections. The agency would be responsible for litigating the civil actions, seeking the injunctions for the removal of misinformation from online platforms, and managing the enforcement of subpoenas authorized by the bill.

The legislation creates a new misdemeanor offense and authorizes the State Board of Elections to file new types of civil actions (injunctions and cost-recovery suits). These legal proceedings will be managed by the state court system, for which the AOC provides the administrative and financial infrastructure.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a new criminal misdemeanor punishable by up to five years in prison. Since incarceration is a potential penalty, the Office of the Public Defender will be responsible for providing legal representation to indigent residents charged with violations related to election deepfakes or misinformation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The creation of a new misdemeanor offense with a potential five-year prison sentence impacts the state's correctional system. Individuals convicted under this law would fall under the custody or community supervision of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

The bill includes specific exemptions and disclosure requirements for television and radio broadcasters regarding the use of deepfakes in news or paid advertisements. As the operator of Maryland Public Television (MPT), the Commission must ensure its broadcasts comply with these new election law standards.

The bill addresses technically complex issues like deepfakes and generative AI. As the state's primary agency for IT policy and cybersecurity, DoIT may be involved in providing technical standards or assisting election officials in identifying manipulated digital media.

State Police specialized units may be required to investigate criminal activity involving the digital creation or dissemination of fraudulent deepfakes, particularly in cases involving cybercrime or coordinated disinformation campaigns that exceed local jurisdiction.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, including the State Board of Elections, and is responsible for signing or vetoing the legislation and overseeing the enforcement of the new election laws.

As the state's chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller is impacted by the bill's potential to generate new general fund revenue through the recovery of damages, court costs, and attorney's fees in civil actions filed by the State Board.

The Treasurer's Office acts as the custodian for state funds, including the Fair Campaign Financing Fund, which is the designated recipient of fines collected for criminal violations of the Election Law Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires landlords of properties served by on-site wastewater (septic) systems to ensure the systems are inspected and pumped out before a new tenant occupies the property, starting July 1, 2028. It also mandates that contracts for the sale of such properties include a provision requiring the purchaser to have the system inspected and pumped out as a condition of sale, with certain exceptions for family transfers. Additionally, the bill extends the deadlines for the Maryland Department of the Environment to adopt regulations for on-site wastewater professionals and for those professionals to obtain licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and the State Board of On-Site Wastewater Professionals
qa_results.stakeholders: Landlords, real property buyers and sellers, tenants, on-site wastewater service professionals, and local health departments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues for the On-Site Wastewater Professionals Fund may be affected starting in FY 2027 due to the delay in licensing deadlines, though the impact is unquantifiable. Local governments may see increased administrative costs and fee revenues; for instance, Prince George's County estimates annual expenditures of $100,000 for staffing and $17,000 in permit revenue. Small business landlords will face increased costs for required inspections and pumping services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is primarily relevant to MDE as it regulates on-site wastewater systems and manages the State Board of On-Site Wastewater Professionals. The bill directly modifies MDE's timeline for adopting regulations and licensing these professionals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of On-Site Wastewater Professionals, which is categorized under this umbrella, is the entity responsible for licensing inspectors and pumping services. The bill extends the deadlines for their regulatory and licensing mandates.

The bill requires failing systems to be reported to 'delegated approval authorities,' which are typically local health departments overseen by MDH. MDH is responsible for public health standards related to sewage disposal.

On-site wastewater systems (septic) are the primary sewage disposal method in rural areas. This agency is relevant as it advocates for rural residents who will be most impacted by the new inspection and pumping requirements for property transfers and rentals.

By adding new requirements to the Real Property Article regarding sales contracts and leases, the bill may lead to an increase in litigation or administrative disputes that the Judiciary would need to process.
The bill imposes new mandates on landlords of properties with septic systems, which affects the management of affordable housing and rental stocks in areas served by private wastewater systems.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor for MDE and MDH. Its Consumer Protection Division may also be involved in enforcing or advising on the new real estate disclosure requirements created by the bill.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees MDE and is responsible for signing the bill into law and ensuring the updated implementation dates are met by state departments.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the termination provision for the nonprofit organizations navigator position within the Department of Commerce, making the role permanent. The navigator is responsible for providing technical assistance to nonprofit organizations regarding state grant programs, resolving procedural delays, and representing nonprofit interests on the Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures are expected to increase by $92,200 in FY 2028 to convert the existing contractual nonprofit organizations navigator position into a permanent regular position. Costs are projected to grow annually, reaching $105,300 by FY 2031. No fiscal impact is anticipated in FY 2027 as the position is already funded through that fiscal year. There is no local government fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly pertains to the Department of Commerce, as it repeals the termination date for the Nonprofit Organizations Navigator position located within the department, making the role and its technical assistance duties permanent.

The Nonprofit Organizations Navigator is statutorily required to serve on the Maryland Efficient Grant Application (MEGA) Council, which the Governor's Grants Office leads and coordinates to streamline state and federal funding processes for nonprofits.

DBM is responsible for the state's personnel system and budget formulation; as noted in the fiscal note, the bill requires the conversion of a contractual position to a permanent regular state position starting in FY 2028.

The Governor's Office oversees executive departments like Commerce and houses the Governor's Grants Office. The Governor is also responsible for designating or approving the administrative framework for executive positions such as the navigator.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the use of surveillance-based price setting and wage setting. It defines surveillance-based setting as the use of surveillance data (personal, behavioral, or biometric information) in conjunction with automated decision systems to offer customized prices to specific consumers or customized wages to specific employees. Surveillance-based price setting is categorized as an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act. Employers are prohibited from surveillance-based wage setting unless the wages are based on specific job-related costs or location-based cost-of-living differences, and the employer must provide a plain-language disclosure regarding the data and logic used by the automated system.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Consumer Protection Division of the Office of the Attorney General and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland consumers, employees, job applicants, and businesses or employers that utilize automated decision systems for pricing and compensation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the associated Fiscal and Policy Note. However, the bill grants enforcement and investigative authority to the Office of the Attorney General and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, suggesting potential increases in state expenditures for administration and potential increases in general fund revenues from civil penalties and fines.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General is responsible for enforcing the Maryland Consumer Protection Act. This bill designates surveillance-based price setting as an unfair trade practice under that Act and explicitly authorizes the Attorney General to bring actions against employers for wage-setting violations.

The Commissioner of Labor and Industry, within the Department of Labor, is explicitly authorized by the bill to investigate complaints regarding surveillance-based wage setting and to mediate violations or seek legal action through the Attorney General.

The bill impacts business operations, retail pricing strategies, and the development/use of artificial intelligence in the private sector, all of which fall under the purview of economic development and business support managed by the Department of Commerce.

Surveillance-based pricing and wage setting via automated systems can often lead to unintended discriminatory outcomes. The Commission oversees anti-discrimination laws in employment and public accommodations, which may overlap with the enforcement of these new prohibitions.

While the bill applies to 'persons' and 'employers,' the insurance industry heavily relies on data-driven and automated price setting (e.g., telematics or behavioral data). This legislation could impact or overlap with existing regulations governing insurance rate-setting and consumer protection.

TEDCO supports and invests in early-stage technology and AI companies in Maryland. The new restrictions on 'automated decision systems' and surveillance data use directly affect the regulatory environment for many tech startups and the innovation economy.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office provides technical assistance to small businesses who must comply with these new pricing and payroll wage-setting regulations to avoid penalties under the Consumer Protection Act.

The board advises the Governor on policies that remove barriers to employment and ensure equitable access to the workforce; the prohibition of surveillance-based wage setting aligns with these workforce equity goals.

The bill explicitly states that its provisions do not diminish the right of covered employees to collectively bargain over terms and conditions of employment, a process overseen by PERB for the state's public workforce.

OAH often provides the impartial forum for contested cases involving labor law violations and state agency decisions, potentially including appeals related to the Commissioner of Labor and Industry's findings under this Act.

The team focuses on data-driven solutions for economic mobility and modernizing government. Prohibitions on algorithmic wage/price setting that might impact childhood poverty or economic stability are relevant to their strategic goals.
The judiciary will handle civil actions and requests for injunctive relief or damages brought by the Attorney General under the new provisions of the Commercial Law and Labor and Employment Articles.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the designation of assistant State fire marshals and requires the State Fire Marshal to adopt regulations governing their qualifications and training. It mandates the installation of automatic fire sprinklers and other specific life safety features in residential rental high-rise buildings undergoing substantial renovations (defined as costing 40% or more of the building's value) starting October 1, 2026. Additionally, the bill requires the State Fire Prevention Commission to establish a licensing and regulatory program for fire alarm system technicians and companies.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Fire Marshal and the State Fire Prevention Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and tenants of residential rental high-rise buildings, fire alarm system technicians and companies, and local/municipal fire officials.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State revenues will increase via the establishment of license fees for fire alarm system technicians and companies, which are intended to offset the direct and indirect costs of the licensing program. State expenditures will increase for the State Fire Marshal to implement the new regulatory requirements and manage the licensing process. Local governments may experience minor administrative impacts related to the designation of fire marshals and the enforcement of high-rise safety standards during building permit reviews.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Fire Marshal’s Office is a specialized unit within the Maryland State Police. This bill directly grants new authorities to the State Fire Marshal, including the approval of local fire marshals, the adoption of training regulations, and the oversight of fire safety in high-rise residential properties.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
