agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the central hub for public safety policy and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies, making it a primary agency for assessing the impact of expanded trafficking definitions on statewide crime trends.

OCSA enforces the state's Controlled Dangerous Substances Act; as this bill modifies the legal definition of trafficking involving CDS (cannabis), it directly relates to the agency's regulatory and enforcement sphere.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes municipalities to allow code enforcement, parking enforcement, and traffic enforcement officers to use body-worn cameras. It classifies these officers as 'law enforcement officers' for the purposes of legal exceptions to wiretapping and electronic surveillance prohibitions when using body-worn digital recording devices in the line of duty. Municipalities that choose to implement these cameras are required to develop and publish a usage policy consistent with standards set by the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
qa_results.responsible_party: Municipal governments
qa_results.stakeholders: Municipal code enforcement officers, parking enforcement officers, traffic enforcement officers, municipal governments, and individuals interacting with municipal enforcement officers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is permissive, allowing but not requiring municipalities to authorize the use of body-worn cameras. For municipalities that choose to do so, local expenditures will increase for the procurement, maintenance, and data storage of cameras, as well as for the administrative costs of developing and publishing required policies. There is no direct impact on state revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends Section 10-402 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, which governs wiretapping and electronic surveillance. This directly impacts the rules of evidence and judicial procedures regarding the admissibility of recordings from body-worn cameras in court.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires municipalities to develop body-worn camera policies consistent with the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission (MPTSC). The MPTSC is an independent body housed within DPSCS that establishes the training and operational standards for officers statewide.

As the state's chief legal office, the OAG is responsible for interpreting and upholding the rule of law, including the wiretapping and electronic surveillance statutes modified by this bill. They provide legal guidance to agencies on the implementation of surveillance policies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency serves as the central hub for public safety policy and administers grants to local governments. It coordinates statewide initiatives related to criminal justice and public safety enforcement, including the use of body-worn cameras.

While the bill focuses on municipal enforcement, the expansion of the definition of 'law enforcement officer' within the wiretap statute and the coordination of body-worn camera standards are relevant to the state’s primary law enforcement agency which follows similar MPTSC protocols.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill designates the Natural History Society of Maryland as the official State natural science museum.
qa_results.responsible_party: Natural History Society of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Natural History Society of Maryland and the residents of Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill text does not include the associated Fiscal and Policy Note; however, designating an entity as a state symbol or museum typically has no fiscal impact on state or local government revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation, including this bill which designates the Natural History Society of Maryland as an official State symbol.
The Secretary of State is responsible for maintaining official state records and certifying state documents, including legislation related to official State symbols and designations.

As the central depository for government records and the publisher of the Maryland Manual, the Archives is the primary agency responsible for documenting and maintaining the official list of State symbols and designations.
The office will be responsible for incorporating the newly designated State natural science museum into its marketing strategies, travel guides, and promotional materials for the state.

As the parent agency of the Office of Tourism Development, the department oversees the promotion of state-designated cultural and scientific institutions to attract visitors and stimulate economic growth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows individuals who are sole owners or specific co-owners of marine vessels to designate a transfer-on-death beneficiary on the vessel's title. It also expands existing law to allow co-owners of motor vehicles to designate a transfer-on-death beneficiary. These designations allow the vessel or vehicle to pass to the beneficiary upon the death of the owner or last surviving co-owner without going through the formal probate process.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) and the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and co-owners of marine vessels and motor vehicles in Maryland, and their designated beneficiaries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues for the Department of Natural Resources and the Transportation Trust Fund are expected to increase beginning in fiscal 2027 as owners pay fees to update titles with beneficiary designations. Illustrative estimates suggest DNR revenues could increase by approximately $269,540 and MVA revenues by $1.0 million in fiscal 2027. State general fund revenues may decrease minimally due to reduced probate fees and inheritance taxes as property bypasses estate administration. There is no impact on local finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly tasks the Department of Natural Resources with establishing and managing the transfer-on-death (TOD) process for marine vessels, including processing applications, issuing certificates of title, and adopting necessary regulations.

The bill alters the motor vehicle laws administered by MDOT's Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) to allow co-owners of vehicles to designate TOD beneficiaries, impacting the department's titling operations and Transportation Trust Fund revenues.

As a unit of MDOT, the MVA is directly responsible for implementing the expanded TOD beneficiary designation program for motor vehicles, processing beneficiary applications, and issuing updated certificates of title.

The bill allows vessels and motor vehicles to bypass estate administration via TOD designations, which directly reduces the volume of probate assets and impacts the probate fees and inheritance taxes collected by this agency.

By allowing assets to pass outside of probate, the bill impacts the judicial oversight of estate administration. The AOC provides the administrative and financial infrastructure for the court system, including the Registers of Wills.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is impacted by the potential decrease in general fund revenues from inheritance taxes and probate fees resulting from the TOD bypass authorized by the bill.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Transportation, and would likely assist in drafting the regulations and reviewing the legal forms required to implement the new TOD designations.

DBM is the central fiscal authority responsible for estimating state revenues; the bill's impact on special funds (DNR and MDOT) and general fund revenues (via probate fees) requires their fiscal oversight.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive departments (DNR and MDOT) responsible for implementing the bill and must ultimately sign or veto the legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the $300 annual limit on the Maryland income tax credit that individuals may claim for expenses incurred to butcher and process antlerless deer donated to qualified 501(c)(3) venison donation programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Individual deer hunters, 501(c)(3) venison donation programs, and food-insecure populations receiving donated meat.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to decrease by an estimated $380,000 annually from fiscal 2027 through fiscal 2029 due to increased tax credit claims. The Comptroller's Office can implement these changes using existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for administering the income tax credit, processing claims, and receiving annual reports from venison donation programs as mandated by the bill.

The bill's eligibility requirements depend on compliance with state hunting laws and regulations managed by DNR. DNR also administers a related Venison Donation Grant Program and was a consulted source for the fiscal note.
The authority manages the state's wholesale food distribution infrastructure and was cited as an information source for the fiscal impact on the venison donation ecosystem.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor for the state agencies involved and would oversee legal questions regarding the immunity from liability for donated food referenced in the bill.
DBM oversees the state's budget and revenue forecasting; the bill is projected to decrease general fund revenues by $380,000 annually through FY 2029.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments involved in the implementation of this tax policy and is responsible for the final signing of the legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Department of Assessments and Taxation to create and maintain a database of statewide and local geographic images, including aerial photography and GIS visualizations, to aid in property appraisals. The Department of General Services is tasked with procuring the system, and local governments are required to reimburse the state for the costs associated with the database.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) and Department of General Services (DGS)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland property owners, county governments, Baltimore City, and state tax assessment officers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase for the imaging database, which is estimated to cost $1.0 million annually. This cost is offset by mandated reimbursements from counties and Baltimore City. Local expenditures increase by at least $1.0 million annually starting in FY 2027. Both State and local property tax revenues are projected to increase by a potentially significant amount (estimated at $1.4 million for the State and $15.0 million for local governments) beginning in FY 2029 due to improved property assessment accuracy.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (an executive agency) to report to the General Assembly regarding new privacy policies developed under the Governor's administration. Additionally, the Governor signs or vetoes such legislation.

As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller must review and approve the procurement contract for the statewide geographic imaging system. Additionally, the Comptroller is the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog; the bill's impact on property assessments directly affects the state's assessable base and related tax revenues.

The Treasurer sits on the Board of Public Works, which is responsible for approving the major state procurement contract required for the uniform system of geographic images. The bill also impacts special fund revenues (Annuity Bond Fund) used for debt service on state bonds managed by the Treasurer.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies. The bill's requirement for SDAT to develop privacy policies to protect the identity of individuals captured in aerial imagery likely requires legal guidance to ensure compliance with privacy laws and constitutional protections.

The bill references the Major Information Technology Development Project Fund, which is managed by DBM. DBM also oversees the state budget and fiscal accountability, including the mechanics of how counties will reimburse the State for the costs of the geographic image database.

The bill explicitly mandates that the Department of General Services procure a uniform system, including tools and services, to prepare, install, and maintain the new geographic image database. DGS is further required to consult with relevant units to define procurement requirements.

The bill involves the creation of a major database for geographic images and GIS visualizations, which falls under the strategic IT direction and cybersecurity standards managed by DoIT. The bill also explicitly mentions the Office of Information Technology within the Department of Assessments and Taxation.

As the agency responsible for land use and technical data analysis, MDP is likely to be one of the 'affected or relevant units of State government' consulted by DGS during the procurement of the geographic information system visualizations and mapping tools.

The Board of Public Works must review and approve the significant state procurement contract (likely exceeding $200,000) for the uniform system of geographic images and appraisal aids required by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill permits individuals operating bicycles, play vehicles, or unicycles to enter an intersection and cross the highway while facing a red traffic signal, provided they follow a pedestrian control 'walk' signal in their direction and yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and pedestrians lawfully in the intersection.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Bicyclists, unicyclists, operators of play vehicles, pedestrians, and motorists
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State finances and operations are not materially affected. Local government expenditures may decrease in certain jurisdictions like Montgomery County, which estimates potential savings of $394,000 to $985,000 because the bill eliminates the need for specialized signage at intersections with leading pedestrian intervals. Revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary executive agency for Maryland’s multi-modal transportation network, MDOT oversees the State Highway Administration and Motor Vehicle Administration, both of which are directly responsible for the implementation and regulatory oversight of the traffic laws modified by this bill.

A unit of MDOT, the SHA is directly responsible for the planning, design, and maintenance of state highways and traffic signals. The bill affects how cyclists interact with SHA-managed intersections and may impact the need for specific signage at these locations.

The MVA manages the Maryland Vehicle Law and driver safety programs. This agency would be responsible for updating the Maryland Driver's Manual and educational materials to reflect the new rules for cyclists and pedestrians at intersections.

The MSP is the primary law enforcement agency for state highways and is responsible for enforcing the Maryland Vehicle Law. Officers would need to be trained on the new legal standard allowing cyclists to cross intersections during pedestrian 'walk' signals.

The AOC manages the administrative and financial infrastructure of the judiciary, which handles the adjudication of traffic violations. Changes to vehicle laws directly impact court proceedings and public record systems like Case Search.

The MTA operates large-scale bus and rail systems that interact with cyclists at signalized intersections. Changes to cycling behavior at crosswalks impact the safety and operational protocols for transit vehicle operators.

The MDTA manages toll facilities and maintains its own police force. This agency would be responsible for implementing and enforcing the new crosswalk rules on its properties, such as bridges and turnpikes.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for MDOT, the State Police, and the Judiciary. They would likely provide legal guidance on the interpretation of the new statute and represent the state in any related litigation.

The bill impacts the interaction between cyclists and pedestrians in crosswalks. MDOD is a cross-disability policy leader that advocates for accessible and safe transportation and pedestrian environments for individuals with disabilities.

MDP coordinates land use and sustainable growth policies. Bicycle transit policy is a significant component of urban design and community vitality, areas where MDP provides technical guidance to local governments.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD provides legal representation for indigent residents in traffic cases. Changes to the Maryland Vehicle Law regarding right-of-way and signal compliance directly impact their legal defense strategies in traffic court.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the state's efforts to promote sustainable transit, including biking. The bill aligns with its mission to improve transit-oriented neighborhoods and alternative transportation methods.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to establish three specialized sickle cell disease clinics in Montgomery County, Harford County, and the Eastern Shore. These clinics must operate under a hub-and-spoke model to provide comprehensive care, including pain management, mental health services, and infusion therapy. Additionally, the bill creates a scholarship program for medical residents specializing in classical hematology with a focus on sickle cell disease and mandates a $6,138,000 appropriation in fiscal year 2028 for clinic operations and community outreach.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals living with sickle cell disease in Maryland, medical residents specializing in hematology, and sickle cell disease-focused community-based and nonprofit organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates a $6,138,000 appropriation in fiscal year 2028 to support clinic operations, staffing, and social support services. A portion of this funding must be allocated to community-based and nonprofit organizations. State expenditures will increase to establish the clinics and the scholarship program, though the bill directs the Maryland Department of Health to utilize federal funding for the scholarships to the extent practicable.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency for public health and healthcare financing, MDH is explicitly tasked with establishing the three specialized sickle cell clinics, implementing the medical resident scholarship program, and submitting annual reports to the General Assembly.

This bill mandates a specific general fund appropriation of $6,138,000 for fiscal year 2028 and involves the management of new state personnel and training funds, which falls under DBM’s central budget and personnel oversight.

The bill requires the Governor to include a specific appropriation in the annual budget bill and aligns with the office's core mission of spearheading statewide initiatives for public health and addressing social determinants of health.

The MHCC is responsible for planning health system needs and regulating the distribution of healthcare facilities; establishing three new specialized clinics likely requires coordination with the State Health Plan and regulatory oversight.

The bill requires the new clinics to collaborate with social services agencies to address social determinants of health—such as housing and nutrition—which are core areas of responsibility for DHS and its local departments.

MHEC is the state's coordinating board for financial aid and scholarships; it would have high relevance to the establishment and standards of the proposed medical resident scholarship program for classical hematology.

The bill mandates that one of the specialized clinics be located on the Eastern Shore; the RMC advocates for rural healthcare access and manages grants that support healthcare infrastructure in these specific regions.
OLA would be responsible for auditing the fiscal compliance and performance of the new $6.1 million clinic program and the distribution of medical residency scholarships.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Commerce to establish and maintain an online portal where businesses and nonprofit organizations can report instances of a governmental unit taking longer than 60 days to process applications for licenses, permits, or registrations. The Department is also required to submit an annual report to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee detailing the complaints received, while ensuring that the data is anonymized to protect the privacy of the organizations involved.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Businesses, nonprofit organizations, and Maryland state, county, and municipal governmental units.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Commerce to develop and maintain a new online complaint portal and to generate annual reports for the General Assembly. While the provided bill text does not specify a funding amount, the Department will incur costs associated with the implementation and administration of these requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Department of Commerce to create, maintain, and report on the new complaint portal regarding governmental processing delays.

This agency is tasked with modernizing government services, reducing wait times, and using data-driven decision-making to eliminate inefficiencies across state agencies, which aligns directly with the bill's intent to track and report on licensing delays.

As the agency responsible for the state's IT infrastructure and modernizing digital government services, DoIT would likely be involved in the technical implementation and security of the required portal.

DBM oversees the fiscal and personnel authority of the state and evaluates government efficiency; the complaints generated by the portal would directly reflect the performance of state personnel systems and budgetary allocations under DBM's oversight.

The Comptroller issues various business licenses and acts as a fiscal watchdog; it is a 'governmental unit' whose processing times for business applications would be subject to public complaints through the portal.

The Department of Labor manages the licensing of dozens of professional trades and occupational safety; it is a high-volume licensing unit that would be directly impacted by public reporting of its application processing times.
MDH is responsible for the licensing and certification of healthcare facilities and professionals, making it a key 'governmental unit' subject to the reporting requirements of the bill.
MDE issues various pollution control and environmental permits; the bill's 60-day reporting threshold would apply to its administrative processing of these certifications and permits.
The MVA handles vehicle registrations and commercial endorsements for businesses; its processing times would be subject to scrutiny and public reporting via the Department of Commerce portal.
The State Police handle various permits and licensing (such as firearms and specialized security roles) that are subject to the processing time complaints defined in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the time period from 5 years to 10 years before a court is required to dismiss charges of first-degree murder or first-degree rape against a defendant found incompetent to stand trial. It also mandates that the court provide notice and an opportunity to be heard to the State's Attorney and the victim or their representative before dismissal, and allows the State to petition for an extension of the charge for extraordinary cause.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary, Maryland Department of Health, and the Office of the Public Defender
qa_results.stakeholders: Defendants found incompetent to stand trial for first-degree murder or first-degree rape, crime victims and their representatives, State's Attorneys, and public defenders.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $159,700 in FY 2027, rising to $218,100 by FY 2031, primarily for the Office of the Public Defender to hire an additional attorney and cover psychiatric expert fees. The Maryland Department of Health may also see an indeterminate increase in expenditures due to extended hospital commitments. Local State's Attorneys' offices and the Judiciary are expected to manage the bill's requirements within existing resources. No impact on revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates changes to court dismissal timelines and requires courts to facilitate hearings and victim notifications for incompetency cases.
The extension of dismissal timelines for violent crimes directly impacts MDH facilities where IST defendants are committed, potentially increasing lengths of stay and facility costs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: OPD must provide continued legal representation and psychiatric evaluations for indigent defendants over the extended 10-year period, resulting in significant fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires notification to the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which is managed by DPSCS, and relates to broader public safety policy.
OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies involved in the criminal justice system and handles criminal appeals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the hub for public safety policy, this office advises the Governor on the criminal justice strategies regarding violent offenders.
Identified in the fiscal note as an agency that can implement the bill within existing resources, OAH provides a forum for administrative reviews related to state agency decisions.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs or vetoes legislation; this bill impacts multiple executive departments and overall state public safety policy.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland restaurants to provide customers with written disclosures identifying any main food allergens (such as milk, eggs, fish, shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame) that are ingredients in menu items. Restaurants may provide these disclosures on their menus, through digital formats like QR codes, or via separate allergen charts and booklets.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and local health departments
qa_results.stakeholders: Restaurant owners and operators, customers with food allergies, and state and local health inspectors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Health and local health departments are expected to enforce the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. While the bill establishes penalties for noncompliance, they are not expected to materially affect State or local finances. Small business restaurants will experience a meaningful impact as they must adapt menus or create disclosure materials to comply.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for enforcing public health laws and food service facility regulations. The bill directly amends the Health – General Article and the fiscal note explicitly states MDH will work with local health departments to enforce the new allergen disclosure requirements.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and would be responsible for interpreting the new statutory requirements and potentially overseeing the prosecution of the criminal misdemeanors and civil penalties established for violations.

As the state's primary economic development agency, Commerce is relevant because the bill has a 'meaningful' fiscal impact on small businesses within the restaurant sector, requiring compliance costs for new signage, menu printing, and digital updates.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Since the fiscal note highlights a meaningful impact on small business restaurants, this office is relevant as it provides technical assistance and advocacy for the small business owners who must comply with these new regulatory mandates.

The bill establishes that violations are misdemeanors subject to criminal fines and civil penalties of up to $5,000 to be collected in the District Court, directly impacting judicial caseloads and administrative processing of penalties.

The OAH provides an impartial forum for residents and businesses to challenge decisions made by the Department of Health. Restaurant owners contesting enforcement actions or penalties related to allergen disclosures would have their cases heard by OAH ALJs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends Section 13-517 of the Education Article, which governs the Automated External Defibrillator (AED) program managed by MIEMSS. The amendment redefines 'facility' to exclude restaurants subject to the new health disclosure laws, affecting the regulatory scope of the program.

The bill directly amends the Education Article regarding the definition of 'Facility.' As the agency overseeing the implementation of the Education Article, MSDE is relevant to statutory changes within that code section.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the procedures for nominating and electing presidential electors in Maryland. It requires presidential elector nominees and alternates to execute a pledge to vote for the candidates of the political party or unaffiliated candidate that nominated them. The bill establishes that an elector who refuses to vote, presents an unmarked ballot, or votes in violation of their pledge vacates the office. It also designates the State Administrator of Elections to preside over the meeting of electors and outlines specific procedures for filling vacancies and submitting amended certificates of ascertainment.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Administrator of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Presidential elector nominees, alternate presidential elector nominees, political parties, unaffiliated presidential candidates, and Maryland voters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact, as it can be implemented with existing resources by the State Board of Elections.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the State Administrator of Elections to preside over the meeting of presidential electors, manage the substitution process for vacancies, examine and count ballots, and prepare the necessary certificates for the Governor and federal authorities.

The Governor is specifically required by the bill to certify the State's presidential electors in the certificate of ascertainment, sign amended certificates if substitute electors are appointed, and deliver these documents in accordance with federal law.

As the primary legal advisor to the Governor and the State Board of Elections, the OAG will be responsible for providing guidance on the implementation of these procedures, ensuring compliance with the federal Electoral Count Reform Act, and defending the state's elector selection process.
The bill mandates that presidential electors take their constitutional oath before the Clerk of the Supreme Court of Maryland (part of the Judiciary/AOC) before casting their votes.
The bill requires the meeting of presidential electors to take place in the State House in Annapolis, a facility whose use and historical integrity are overseen by the State House Trust.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program (VEIP) in Maryland, effectively ending the requirement for biennial motor vehicle exhaust and emissions equipment inspections.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration and the Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Motor vehicle owners in Maryland, independent contractors operating emissions inspection facilities, and the Motor Vehicle Administration.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The repeal of the Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program will lead to a significant loss of state special fund revenue from the elimination of vehicle inspection fees. Conversely, state expenditures will decrease as the Motor Vehicle Administration and Department of the Environment will no longer incur costs to administer the program or pay independent contractors to operate inspection facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill repeals the Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program (VEIP). Under current law, the Secretary of the Environment is jointly responsible with the MVA for establishing and managing this program to ensure compliance with the federal Clean Air Act and State emissions standards.

As the primary administrator of vehicle services, the MVA is responsible for the daily operation of the VEIP, including scheduling tests, collecting fees, and managing the independent contractors who operate the testing facilities.

The MVA is a unit of MDOT, and the department is responsible for the strategic planning and operation of the State's transportation networks, including the regulatory programs mandated for motor vehicles registered in Maryland.

Repealing the VEIP has significant fiscal implications, including the loss of millions of dollars in annual fee revenue and the elimination of expenditures related to the program's administration and independent contractor operations.

The VEIP is largely operated through major contracts with independent vendors. The Board of Public Works would be responsible for overseeing the termination or modification of these significant state procurement contracts following the program's repeal.

The Governor oversees the executive agencies (MDOT and MDE) responsible for the program and manages the state budget, which would be directly impacted by the repeal of program fees and associated expenditures.

The OAG provides legal counsel to MDE and MDOT. Repealing the VEIP requires legal review regarding compliance with the federal Clean Air Act and potential litigation related to the termination of existing testing facility contracts.

The Comptroller monitors state revenues and sits on the Board of Public Works. The repeal of the VEIP would impact the collection of vehicle-related fees and requires the review of major contract terminations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Council coordinates state efforts to protect the Bay. Vehicle emissions are a significant source of nitrogen deposition in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, so repealing the inspection program aligns with their environmental policy oversight.

This initiative coordinates sustainable growth and environmental stewardship across multiple agencies, including MDE. The repeal of an environmental regulatory program like VEIP impacts the state's broader sustainability and resource conservation goals.
The current law being repealed contains specific emissions testing exemptions for individuals at least 70 years of age whose vehicles meet certain mileage criteria.
The bill repeals existing provisions that provide emissions testing exemptions for vehicle owners with physical disabilities who meet specific annual mileage limits.
The bill repeals existing testing exemptions for active-duty members of the uniformed services who are deployed outside the U.S. or stationed in jurisdictions without emissions programs.
The Treasurer manages state funds and sits on the Board of Public Works, which would review the termination of significant service contracts associated with the VEIP.
The OLA conducts fiscal and performance audits of executive agencies. The repeal of a major program like VEIP would change the audit scope and fiscal controls monitored for the MVA and MDE.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands Maryland's identity fraud laws to specifically prohibit the use of personal identifying information, artificial intelligence, and 'deepfake' representations to cause harm, harass, or defraud individuals. It establishes criminal penalties for these acts, including misdemeanors and felonies depending on the number of victims and the nature of the crime, and authorizes victims to bring civil actions for injunctive relief and other damages.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of identity fraud and deepfake impersonation, law enforcement agencies, the Maryland judiciary, and individuals utilizing artificial intelligence technology.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local finances. While it may increase workloads for the Judiciary, the Office of the Public Defender, and law enforcement agencies due to the creation of new criminal classifications and civil causes of action, these impacts are expected to be manageable within existing resources. There may be a minimal increase in State fine revenues and potential incarceration expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly grants the Department of State Police the authority to initiate investigations and enforce this identity fraud section throughout the state, including in municipal corporations.
The bill explicitly authorizes the Attorney General to investigate and prosecute violations of the identity fraud statute and grants them the powers of a State's Attorney in these matters.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates new felony and misdemeanor offenses related to AI and deepfakes; the fiscal note indicates the OPD will require additional resources to handle the resulting increase in litigation and caseloads.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, this office is responsible for coordinating statewide initiatives to reduce crime and advising the Governor on criminal justice strategies like those proposed in the bill.

The bill creates a new civil cause of action and expanded criminal penalties, which the Judiciary must manage and process. The AOC provides the administrative and financial infrastructure for these judicial proceedings.
The bill specifically adopts the definition of 'artificial intelligence' found in the State Finance and Procurement Article, which falls under the regulatory and policy-making purview of DoIT.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The creation of new felonies for AI-driven identity fraud will directly impact the state's correctional system, as the agency is responsible for the management of adult correctional facilities and pretrial detention.
The bill specifically grants law enforcement officers of the Maryland Transportation Authority Police the authority to investigate identity fraud violations throughout the State.
The bill grants the Maryland Port Administration Police the specific authority to investigate violations of the identity fraud statute without jurisdictional limitation.
The agency's police force is included in the notification requirements for investigations, and the bill affects the law enforcement activities managed by the MAA at state airports.

The agency is responsible for unemployment insurance and protecting economic welfare; identity fraud, particularly via deepfakes, is a significant threat to the integrity of benefit systems managed by the department.
The department performs critical protection and advocacy work for older adults, who are frequently targets of sophisticated identity fraud and AI-generated scams.
As the state’s tax collector and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller's office is directly impacted by identity fraud used to obtain fraudulent tax refunds or benefits.
The MIA protects residents from unfair practices and fraud within the insurance industry, which includes the use of AI and deepfakes to obtain services or defraud providers.

AI and deepfake representations used to 'impersonate' or 'falsely depict' individuals can be used to defraud or mislead voters, directly impacting the Board's mission to ensure secure and transparent elections.
The OSP investigates criminal offenses threatening the integrity of state government; the use of deepfakes to impersonate officials or create false records falls within their watchdog mandate.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments impacted by this bill and is responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating statewide public safety initiatives.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the legal protections for Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts (SLATs) by specifying that an individual who creates an irrevocable trust for their spouse's benefit is not considered the settlor of that trust if they later become a beneficiary through the exercise of a power of appointment by the spouse or another individual. This prevents creditors of the original creator from reaching the trust assets.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals establishing trusts, spouses, trust beneficiaries, estate planning attorneys, and creditors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no significant impact on state or local government finances as it primarily governs the relationship between private trust creators, beneficiaries, and creditors.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency responsible for overseeing the administrative probate of estates and protecting legal records related to estate proceedings, the Register of Wills is directly impacted by changes to the Estates and Trusts Article regarding the definition of a trust settlor and the protection of trust assets from creditors.

The Administrative Office of the Courts supports the Maryland Judiciary, including the Orphans' Courts and Circuit Courts, which adjudicate disputes involving estates, trusts, and creditor claims. This bill modifies the legal framework these courts must apply in trust litigation.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the State and its agencies. It may be required to interpret or defend these changes to the Estates and Trusts Article, particularly in cases involving state claims against trusts or the enforcement of creditor rights.

The bill explicitly references the authority of a trustee to reimburse a settlor for taxes on trust income or principal. As the state's tax collector, the Comptroller has an interest in how trust structures and settlor status impact tax liability and revenue collection.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to allow deer bow hunting and turkey bow hunting on Sundays throughout their respective seasons across various counties and Baltimore City, effectively expanding Sunday hunting opportunities by removing or modifying existing date and time restrictions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Bow hunters, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, property owners, and residents of affected Maryland counties and Baltimore City.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal fiscal impact. There may be a slight increase in state special fund revenues from hunting license sales, while any administrative costs for the Department of Natural Resources to implement and enforce the expanded season regulations are expected to be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office oversees executive branch operations and holds the authority to sign or veto this legislation affecting state-regulated hunting activities.
As the primary agency for wildlife management and enforcement of hunting laws, the DNR is directly responsible for implementing the Sunday bow hunting authorizations provided in the bill.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Natural Resources and would review the bill's provisions for compliance with existing state law and the drafting of related regulations.
Expanding hunting seasons helps control deer populations that cause significant damage to crops, thereby supporting the economic viability of Maryland's agricultural industry.
DBM manages state agency budgets and monitors revenue; the expansion of hunting opportunities could affect DNR revenue from license sales and required expenditures for conservation and enforcement.
The bill impacts the outdoor recreation economy, which is a sector of focus for the Department of Commerce's efforts to stimulate private investment and economic growth.
Hunting is a key component of Maryland's heritage tourism; authorizing Sunday hunting increases the state's attractiveness to both domestic and international travelers.
The Council represents the interests of rural communities, for whom expanded hunting opportunities are vital for economic sustainability and managing the balance between land use and wildlife.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the criteria for criminal record expungement to include cases that were disposed of by a court with a 'no finding' designation or were designated as 'terminated without finding.' It allows individuals whose cases ended in these specific non-conviction outcomes to petition the court for the expungement of police, court, and other state-maintained records.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with criminal records containing 'no finding' or 'terminated without finding' dispositions, the Maryland Judiciary, and state and local law enforcement agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases the eligibility for expungement, which likely results in an increase in administrative expenditures for the Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (specifically the Criminal Justice Information System) to process additional petitions. However, as the Fiscal Note text was not fully provided, specific revenue and expenditure estimates are unavailable.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Administrative Office of the Courts is directly responsible for managing court records, including the 'Case Search' portal and the administrative systems that process expungement orders. This bill specifically mandates the expansion of expungement eligibility for certain court findings, requiring technical and procedural updates by the Judiciary.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS maintains the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which is the central repository for all Maryland criminal history records. The bill's expansion of expungement eligibility to cases with 'no finding' would require the agency to modify its record-clearing protocols and data systems.

The Maryland State Police are responsible for managing police records across the state. Expungement orders resulting from this bill would require the MSP to identify and destroy or seal both physical and electronic records of relevant cases as part of their statewide law enforcement duties.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Public Defender represents indigent residents who are the primary users of the expungement process. This bill creates a new legal pathway for their clients to clear records from cases that lacked an unequivocal conviction, directly impacting their legal service and advocacy workload.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, GOCPP advises on criminal justice strategies and tracks outcomes. This expansion of expungement law affects recidivism tracking, public safety data reporting, and overall justice policy which falls under their coordination mandate.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to nearly all state agencies, including the State Police and DPSCS. They would be responsible for providing legal interpretations of the new 'no finding' expungement criteria and defending state agencies in related legal challenges.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of all executive departments impacted by this bill (MSP, DPSCS) and is responsible for signing the legislation into law as part of its role in shaping criminal justice policy and economic opportunity.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Unemployment Insurance Modernization Act of 2026 updates the methodology for calculating unemployment insurance benefits and employer contributions in Maryland. It replaces fixed dollar amounts with percentages indexed to the state's average annual and weekly wages, setting the taxable wage base at 16% of the average annual wage by 2029 and the maximum weekly benefit at 40% of the state average weekly wage by 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employers and individuals claiming unemployment insurance benefits
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill transitions the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund's revenue and expenditure structure from fixed rates to indexed percentages. By increasing the taxable wage base and adjusting the weekly benefit amount formulas, the bill will affect both the total contributions collected from employers and the total benefits paid to claimants. Specific fiscal estimates were not provided in the bill text, but the indexing is designed to align the fund with current state wage levels.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for administering the state's unemployment insurance system, the Department of Labor is tasked with implementing the new benefit calculation methodologies, determining the average annual wage, and setting the taxable wage base.

The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Labor and its Secretary, who is specifically mandated by this bill to set the taxable wage base and maximum weekly benefit amounts according to new percentage-based formulas.

DBM oversees the statewide personnel system and the state budget; changes to the taxable wage base and unemployment benefit levels directly impact the state's financial obligations and costs as a participating employer for its own workforce.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Department of Labor and would be responsible for guiding the regulatory process required to implement the bill's modernization of benefit schedules and wage bases.

The Comptroller manages the central payroll for over 100,000 state employees and monitors state revenue; changes to the unemployment insurance taxable wage base affect payroll tax processing and financial reporting for state agencies.

The Treasurer is the custodian of the state's financial assets and would have oversight regarding the fiscal management of employer contributions and the impact of these changes on the state's long-term financial reporting and bond ratings.

The alteration of the taxable wage base and employer contribution requirements significantly impacts the business climate and economic costs for private-sector employers across the state, which is central to the Department of Commerce's mission.

Modernizing the unemployment insurance system (including formulas for benefits and taxable bases) requires significant updates to the state's IT infrastructure and claimant processing platforms, which fall under DoIT's strategic and procurement oversight.

The bill contains a specific provision regarding how payments to individuals serving as election judges are treated for the purpose of calculating unemployment benefit deductions, impacting the recruitment and compensation for this personnel pool.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of the Department of Labor; the repeal of existing benefit schedules and the introduction of new data-driven wage metrics will change the criteria and standards for future audits of the UI Trust Fund.

The board oversees the state's workforce development system, and unemployment insurance is a critical policy component that supports workers during career transitions and aligns with the state's economic safety net goals.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires all Maryland public middle schools to begin instruction no earlier than 8:00 a.m. and all high schools to begin instruction no earlier than 8:30 a.m. starting in the 2028-2029 school year. It allows for waivers from the State Board of Education for compelling reasons, though a lack of funding is explicitly excluded as a valid reason for a waiver. The bill also mandates that local boards of education and charter schools implement a public awareness campaign starting in the 2027-2028 school year to educate communities on the impacts of sleep deprivation and the benefits of later school start times.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education and local county boards of education
qa_results.stakeholders: Middle and high school students, parents, teachers, school administrators, coaches, local school systems, and public charter schools.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State revenues or expenditures. However, the bill creates a significant local mandate for school systems that do not currently comply. While some counties report no fiscal impact, others anticipate substantial increases in transportation expenditures. For example, Frederick County estimates first-year costs exceeding $11,000,000 and ongoing annual costs of $6,000,000 for additional buses, drivers, and maintenance personnel to accommodate shifted schedules.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the State Board of Education (part of MSDE) to oversee and grant waivers for school start times. Additionally, MSDE is required to assist county boards and charter schools with the implementation of a public awareness campaign regarding sleep deprivation.

As an independent state agency that provides tuition-free public education to middle and high school students, MSD would be subject to the instructional start time requirements or the waiver process outlined in the bill.

The MTA operates transit systems that many middle and high school students, particularly in the Baltimore region, rely on for transportation. Shifts in school start times would require significant scheduling adjustments for bus and rail services to accommodate new peak travel times.

As an independent unit within MSDE, the Center's work on student safety and emergency preparedness could be affected by changes in school schedules, particularly regarding student commutes and the security of schools during early morning hours.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the State Board of Education and the Department of Education, providing counsel on the interpretation of the law, the waiver process, and the development of regulations related to school instructional hours.

The GOC leads a whole-of-government approach to child well-being and education outcomes. This bill, focused on the health and academic impacts of sleep deprivation, aligns with the office's mission to improve the well-being of Maryland's youth.
The bill addresses the public health issue of sleep deprivation among adolescents. MDH may be involved in providing health data or resources for the public information campaigns mandated by the bill.

MDOT, as the parent agency of the State Highway Administration and MTA, would be indirectly impacted by changes in traffic patterns and peak commute hours resulting from staggered or delayed school start times across the state.

The MLDS Center tracks student and workforce data to analyze the effectiveness of educational policies. It would likely be the agency responsible for tracking the long-term academic and social outcomes of the transition to later school start times.
As the office responsible for signing legislation and overseeing executive agencies, the Governor's Office would oversee the implementation of this policy through the Department of Education.

qa_results.bill_summary: This constitutional amendment requires all Maryland counties and Baltimore City to adopt a charter form of government by December 31, 2032. It mandates that counties currently not operating under a charter must appoint a charter board by January 1, 2029, to draft a proposed charter for adoption by the Board of County Commissioners. The bill further requires that all county charters provide for an elected county executive and a county council elected via councilmanic districts.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Board of County Commissioners and local Boards of Election Supervisors
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and local governments of Maryland counties currently operating under commission or code home rule forms of government, and Maryland voters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Fiscal and Policy Note was not included in the provided text. Expected fiscal impacts include state expenditures for publicizing the constitutional amendment for the November 2026 general election and local expenditures for counties to establish charter boards, publish proposed charters, and restructure administrative systems to comply with charter home rule requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill is a constitutional amendment that must be submitted to the qualified voters of the State for a referendum in the 2026 general election. The State Board of Elections is responsible for managing the referendum process, certifying the ballots, and overseeing the administration of the election as mandated in Section 3 of the bill.

The Maryland Department of Planning provides technical assistance and policy guidance to local governments regarding governance and urban design. This bill mandates a total structural shift for all counties to Charter Home Rule, which would require significant planning services and inter-governmental coordination handled by this agency.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is involved in the administration of constitutional amendments. Section 3 of the bill specifically requires that all election returns regarding the amendment be made to the Governor for further proceedings in accordance with the Maryland Constitution.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the State and the General Assembly. This bill involves a significant constitutional change to county governance, which would require the OAG's review to ensure compliance with existing laws and to advise on the legal implementation of new charter requirements.

The Secretary of State is responsible for certifying official state documents and maintaining the Great Seal. This office plays a role in the formal certification process for constitutional amendments following a statewide referendum.

The Rural Maryland Council advocates for the 18 rural counties, several of which currently operate under commissioner or code home rule systems. This bill would force these jurisdictions to adopt charter home rule and councilmanic districts, fundamentally altering their local governance structure.

The DBM is the central fiscal authority for the state. While the primary impact is at the local level, DBM monitors fiscal notes related to statewide referendums and any administrative costs incurred by state agencies in the implementation of mandated structural changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits merchants from refusing cash for in-person retail transactions totaling between $5 and $300. It also bans merchants from requiring credit or debit card use or charging additional fees for cash payments. Certain transactions are exempt, including telephone, mail, and internet orders, as well as vehicle parking fees. Violations are deemed unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act, enforceable by the Office of the Attorney General.
qa_results.responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland retail merchants and consumers who use cash for purchases
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill establishes civil penalties that could increase state general fund revenues. Merchants who fail to comply after two warnings are subject to fines up to $5,000 for an initial violation and up to $10,000 for subsequent violations. The Division of Consumer Protection is responsible for enforcement, which may impact administrative expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates the Division of Consumer Protection within the Office of the Attorney General to enforce the new requirements, provide compliance opportunities to merchants, and assess fines for violations.

The bill imposes new operational requirements on retail merchants regarding payment methods, which directly impacts the business environment and the merchant community that the Department of Commerce supports and promotes.

DBM oversees the fiscal impact on the state budget, including the funding required for the Office of the Attorney General to manage enforcement and the potential general fund revenue generated from the civil penalties established in the bill.

As the state's fiscal watchdog and agency responsible for business licensing and economic forecasting, the Comptroller monitors retail transaction trends and the regulatory environment for Maryland businesses.

The Office of Administrative Hearings may be required to adjudicate contested cases and provide impartial hearings if merchants challenge the fines or enforcement actions taken by the Division of Consumer Protection.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the enforcement of state laws and coordinates statewide initiatives related to economic opportunity and consumer safety.
The team focuses on data-driven solutions for economic mobility and poverty; ensuring cash accessibility is a key issue for the economic participation of unbanked and low-income residents.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill exempts accredited religious educational institutions that were authorized to operate and have been in continuous operation in Maryland since before January 1, 2013, from the requirement to obtain a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) to operate in the State.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Accredited religious educational institutions operating in Maryland since before January 1, 2013, and the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no significant impact on the Maryland Higher Education Commission's administrative operations, special fund revenues, or expenditures. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the operations of the Maryland Higher Education Commission and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation that impacts state agency regulatory requirements.

This agency is the primary regulatory and coordinating body for postsecondary education in Maryland and is directly responsible for administering the certificate of approval process and enforcing the exemptions modified by this bill.

As the state's regulatory board for colleges and universities, MHEC will be the primary agency responsible for implementing the new exemption criteria for accredited religious educational institutions and managing the associated certificate of approval process.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to state agencies, including the Maryland Higher Education Commission, and would provide counsel on the legal interpretation of the exemption and its compliance with federal accreditation standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's state procurement laws to increase transparency and modify various procedures. Key changes include requiring state units to provide debriefings to unsuccessful bidders before a contract award is finalized, mandating that procurement contracts include clauses for equitable adjustments if changes in law increase a contractor's costs, and extending the timeframe for contractors to file a notice of claim from 30 to 60 days. It also refines ethics rules regarding conflict of interest for those who assist in drafting solicitations and streamlines the process for reviewing protests and contract claims.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Office of State Procurement (within the Department of General Services) and Maryland State procurement units.
qa_results.stakeholders: State agencies and procurement units, private contractors, unsuccessful bidders and offerors, and small businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill may result in a significant increase in State procurement expenditures across all funds, though a reliable estimate is currently unavailable. Expenditures could rise due to mandatory contract adjustments for changes in law, potential project delays caused by mandatory debriefing schedules, and extended timelines for contract claims. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances. Small businesses may experience a meaningful positive impact by receiving compensation for cost increases driven by legal changes.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Board's approval process by requiring that unsuccessful offerors receive debriefings before a contract award is presented to the Board for final approval. It also affects the contract modifications and claims that the Board oversees.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Board of Contract Appeals
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill significantly alters the legal procedures, timelines, and requirements for bid protests and contract claims, which are the primary matters adjudicated by the Board of Contract Appeals.

The bill explicitly tasks the Office of State Procurement, which is within DGS, to establish guidelines for contract debriefings. DGS is also a primary procurement unit affected by the procedural changes.
The bill requires procurement officers to seek the advice of the Office of the Attorney General on legal issues raised during bid protests and contract claims.

As a cabinet-level agency and primary procurement unit for massive infrastructure and transit projects, MDOT is heavily impacted by the changes to change orders, equitable adjustments, and contract claim procedures.
DBM serves as a primary procurement unit and central fiscal authority. The bill’s changes to procurement transparency, debriefings, and claim resolutions will directly alter their operations.

USM is a primary procurement unit with significant autonomy; however, changes to the State Finance and Procurement Article regarding transparency and claim procedures generally apply to or influence their procurement operations.
DoIT is the central procurement unit for IT services and is specifically mentioned in the bill's clauses regarding nonvisual access and information technology procurement standards.

The Comptroller sits on the Board of Public Works and reviews major state contracts; the bill's requirement for debriefings prior to BPW presentation affects the timing and approval workflow of the Comptroller's office.

The Treasurer sits on the Board of Public Works and oversees state spending; the bill's procedural changes to contract awards and claims impact the fiscal management and approval duties of the Treasurer.
MDH engages in high-volume procurement for healthcare services and medical supplies; the new requirements for equitable adjustments and protest timelines will affect their administrative processes.
As a primary procurement unit, Morgan State must adhere to the bill's new transparency and debriefing requirements for its capital and operational contracts.
As an independent public honors college and state agency, it functions as a procurement unit that will be subject to the altered contract claim and protest regulations.

The Governor oversees the executive agencies and the Office of State Procurement. The bill also specifies that debriefings must occur before awards are presented to the head of the unit (often a Governor's appointee).
OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies; changes in procurement law will require OLA to update its audit criteria for assessing how agencies handle protests, claims, and debriefings.
The bill references change orders involving local prevailing wage rates, which are administered by the Department of Labor. Procedural changes to these change orders affect their regulatory area.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Incarcerated Job Training Act requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to establish an apprenticeship program in skilled trades for incarcerated individuals. The program allows participants to work for state or local government agencies or private entities, earning at least the state minimum wage to develop marketable skills and accumulate funds for use upon their release.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, State and local government agencies, and private entities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates that employers pay participants at least the state minimum wage. The State is responsible for the guarding, transportation, and care expenses of participants assigned to State agencies. Municipalities, counties, and private entities are responsible for covering these costs for participants assigned to them. Wages are credited to the individual's account or may be used to support dependents if necessary.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the Maryland correctional system, DPSCS is explicitly tasked with developing, implementing, and managing the Incarcerated Individual Apprenticeship Program, including logistical care, security, and financial account management for participants.

The Department of Labor oversees the state's apprenticeship programs, workforce development, and minimum wage enforcement, all of which are central components of the job training and compensation requirements established by this bill.

DBM oversees the state's personnel system and annual operating budget; it will be responsible for fiscal oversight of the program's costs, particularly for participants assigned to other state agencies and the associated logistical expenses.

The Governor's Office provides executive oversight of all state departments and leads statewide initiatives aimed at economic opportunity and public safety, making this rehabilitative workforce program a significant policy priority for the administration.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor for DPSCS and the General Assembly; it would be responsible for reviewing the legality of apprenticeship contracts, program regulations, and inter-agency or private sector agreements.

The Comptroller manages the state’s central payroll and revenue collection; this bill requires that incarcerated individuals be paid at least minimum wage and involves complex fund transfers between employers, the Department, and individual accounts.

The GWDB creates pathways to employment and removes barriers for underserved populations; this program aligns with its mission to align training with high-demand skilled trades and oversee the state's workforce strategy.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP advises on criminal justice strategies and public safety; this bill represents a significant rehabilitative effort intended to reduce recidivism through marketable job skills.
MDOT is a major state employer with a vast network of skilled trades (maintenance, mechanical, and infrastructure) and could serve as a primary state agency participant for these apprenticeships.
DGS is responsible for the maintenance and construction of state-owned facilities, which are high-demand areas for the skilled trades prioritized by the apprenticeship program.

The Department of Commerce focuses on job creation and workforce training programs; while not the primary administrator, it facilitates the economic development and private sector partnerships needed for the program's success.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to conduct studies on emerging technologies and trends—such as artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and digital identity verification—to foster a safer and more transparent gambling environment. If the Commission lacks the necessary internal expertise or resources, it must collaborate or contract with Maryland higher education institutions, foundations, or private entities to perform these analyses.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland citizens, the gambling industry, institutions of higher education, foundations, and private consulting entities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by up to $100,000 in FY 2027 for the State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency to hire consultants to conduct the required studies. There is no projected impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Commission to submit technology studies and regular revenue reports to the Governor, who also oversees the strategic implementation of these emerging technologies across state agencies.
The Comptroller acts as the state’s chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog; the bill involves analyzing gaming revenues and competitive practices that impact the state's revenue collection.

The OAG is the legal advisor to the Lottery and Gaming Control Agency and would be involved in reviewing and drafting the contracts or collaboration agreements with higher education institutions and private entities.

The bill has an identified fiscal impact of $100,000 in general fund expenditures for consultancy services, which falls under DBM’s responsibility for overseeing the state's annual budget and fiscal accountability.

The bill specifically mandates studies on cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, blockchain, and digital identity verification. These are core areas of responsibility for DoIT, which sets IT policy and security standards for the executive branch.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission is an executive-level body tasked by this bill with conducting specialized inquiries, analyzing best practices, and providing formal legislative recommendations.

As a unit focused on data-driven solutions and modernizing government services, the team is highly relevant to the bill's mandate to test and pilot emerging technologies like AI to improve state program operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the Agency's Commission to conduct tech studies and requires the Agency Director to communicate and fully participate in the resulting research collaborations.

The bill requires collaboration with Maryland higher education institutions; the fiscal note explicitly identifies Morgan State as a potential collaborator that would require additional staffing and resources to support the bill.
The University System of Maryland is listed as a potential partner for the required studies, and its member institutions are designated as primary entities for collaboration and technical analysis.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of "baby food" to include infant formula and infant cereal. This change subjects these products to existing Maryland safety regulations, which include mandatory testing for toxic heavy metals (arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury), public disclosure of test results through websites and QR codes, and compliance with federal heavy metal limits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Infants and children under age 2, baby food manufacturers, and consumers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland Department of Health expenditures may increase to handle the additional workload, but these costs are expected to be absorbed within existing budgeted resources. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances, and the impact on small businesses is anticipated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH), specifically its Center for Food Processing, is the primary regulatory body responsible for licensing and inspecting food processing facilities in the state. The bill directly impacts MDH by requiring manufacturers to provide toxic heavy metal test results to the department and authorizing MDH to receive consumer reports regarding non-compliant products.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and is responsible for enforcing consumer protection laws. Expanding the definition of baby food for the purpose of testing and labeling increases the scope of regulatory compliance and potential enforcement actions handled by this office.

As the state's primary economic development agency, the Department of Commerce supports the manufacturing sector.
