The bill imposes new testing, labeling, and public reporting requirements on food manufacturers and distributors operating in Maryland, directly affecting the regulatory environment for these businesses.

The Governor's Office oversees all executive departments, including the Department of Health. The Governor is responsible for signing this legislation into law and ensuring the effective enforcement of public health standards across the state.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Comprehensive Community Safety Funding Act establishes an 11% excise tax on the gross receipts of federally licensed firearms dealers derived from the retail sale of firearms, firearm accessories, and ammunition within Maryland, as well as on firearm sales to Maryland residents by out-of-state dealers. The revenue generated from this tax, after deducting administrative costs, is distributed to several state funds, including the Maryland Violence Intervention and Prevention Program Fund, the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention, and the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Federally licensed firearms dealers, Maryland residents who purchase firearms or ammunition, the Maryland Department of Health, the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, and the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill creates a new state revenue source via an 11% excise tax on firearm-related retail sales. After the Comptroller's administrative costs are covered, the remaining revenue is distributed among several public safety and health funds: 26% to the Maryland Violence Intervention and Prevention Program Fund, 26% to the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention, 20% to the Coordinated Community Supports Partnership Fund, 20% to the Survivors of Homicide Victims Grant Program, 4% to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund, and 4% to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center. The specific dollar amount of projected revenue was not provided in the bill text.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly designates the Comptroller to administer the new Firearm, Firearm Accessory, and Ammunition Excise Tax, including collecting revenues, managing administrative cost accounts, and distributing funds to the specified programs.

The Department of Health is a major recipient of the tax revenue, with 26% of funds going to the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention and 4% going to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund, both housed within the department.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is a primary recipient of the tax revenue, receiving 20% of funds for the Survivors of Homicide Victims Grant Program and 26% for the Maryland Violence Intervention and Prevention Program Fund, which aligns with its mission to manage public safety grants and victim services.
The agency receives 20% of the tax revenue to support the Coordinated Community Supports Partnership Fund, which is managed under the Education Article for student and community well-being.

As the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, the Maryland Tax Court would be responsible for adjudicating disputes and appeals related to the assessment and collection of the newly created excise tax.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Comptroller regarding the implementation of the new tax and would be responsible for prosecuting the new criminal misdemeanor charges established for willful failure to file tax returns.
The Treasurer is responsible for the management and protection of state funds; this bill creates a new revenue stream and multiple special fund allocations that require custodial oversight.

DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and formulating the annual budget. This bill establishes a new 11% excise tax and mandates specific distributions that will impact the state's fiscal planning and revenue forecasting.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the various departments receiving funds (Health, Education, GOCPP) and is responsible for the overall fiscal policy and signing of this tax legislation.

The bill mandates that 4% of the tax revenue be distributed to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center at the University of Maryland Medical System, which is the primary teaching hospital for the University of Maryland, Baltimore (a USM institution).

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires law enforcement agencies to notify the State's Attorney within 24 hours if a student is identified as a suspect in a felony or crime of violence investigation. The State's Attorney is authorized to notify the local school superintendent, and mandatory follow-up notifications must be provided if a student is cleared as a suspect. The bill also incorporates data regarding student suspects into annual school safety reports and requires school officials to invite a student's attorney to relevant school conferences if the student is removed from their regular program due to their status as a suspect.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education, State Board of Education, local State's Attorneys, local school superintendents, and law enforcement agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Students (ages 5-21) in public and nonpublic schools, local school systems, school administrators, and law enforcement agencies

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments mentioned in the bill, including Education, State Police, and Juvenile Services. The Governor also has the authority to sign or veto this legislation.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the Maryland State Police and the Department of Education, which are tasked with new reporting and regulatory duties under this bill.

DBM oversees the state budget and fiscal accountability. Since the bill requires new reporting mechanisms and potentially increased administrative workload for several state agencies, DBM would evaluate the fiscal impact.

The bill requires annual reports to include the 'disability status' of students identified as suspects or arrested for reportable offenses, directly intersecting with the department's role in monitoring policy impacts on individuals with disabilities.

MSDE is a primary implementing agency. The bill requires the State Board of Education to adopt regulations, and the Department must submit annual reports to the Governor and General Assembly regarding reportable offenses and suspect notifications.

DHS oversees child welfare services. Investigations into students suspected of felonies or crimes of violence often involve coordination with social services to ensure stable and safe environments for vulnerable youth.

DJS manages and rehabilitates youth involved in the juvenile justice system. This bill's reporting requirements for students suspected of felonies directly impact the youth population under DJS supervision and their reintegration into school environments.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages criminal justice information and coordinates with local law enforcement. The bill's definitions and reporting protocols for crimes of violence and felonies relate to the broader criminal justice reporting infrastructure overseen by the department.

As a primary law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police will be directly responsible for identifying students as suspects in investigations of felonies or crimes of violence and notifying the State's Attorney within specified timeframes.

The GOC is dedicated to the well-being of children. This bill affects how children are treated within the education and legal systems when suspected of crimes, impacting their academic performance and long-term economic mobility.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP advises on public safety policy and manages funding for law enforcement. This bill significantly alters criminal justice reporting policies for students, aligning with the office's core mission of coordinating justice initiatives.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires reporting on the disability status of students arrested or suspected of crimes. ODHH advocates for deaf and hard-of-hearing students, who may be uniquely impacted by these reporting protocols or requiring specific support during disciplinary conferences.

The bill references the Courts Article for definitions of offenses and involves the disposition of reportable offenses. The AOC manages the information systems that may be utilized to track or verify these dispositions.

The bill requires data collection on the race, ethnicity, and gender of students suspected or arrested. MCCR monitors such data to ensure anti-discrimination laws are upheld and that reporting requirements do not result in disparate impacts.

As an independent unit within MSDE focused on school safety, MCSS is the primary coordinator for the safety protocols addressed in this bill, including managing information used to maintain a secure school environment.

The MLDS Center tracks student and workforce data. This bill requires the tracking of academic performance and standardized test scores for students removed from regular programs due to suspect status, which falls under MLDS's analytical purview.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that school principals invite a student's attorney to participate in conferences and manifestation determination reviews if the student is removed from their regular program. OPD frequently represents these indigent students.

As an independent state agency that operates as a school system, MSD's administration would be subject to the bill's requirements regarding notification of reportable offenses and suspect status for its students.

Disciplinary actions taken by schools in response to reportable offenses or suspect status can be challenged by students and their families. OAH often provides the impartial forum for these administrative hearings.

OLA conducts compliance audits of state agencies. They would be responsible for auditing MSDE and law enforcement agencies to ensure they are following the new statutory notification and data destruction requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill updates the Maryland Uniform Simultaneous Death Act to align with the national Uniform Simultaneous Death Act. It mandates that an individual must survive another by at least 120 hours to be considered a survivor for purposes of inheritance, property devolution, and insurance benefits. The bill also details evidentiary procedures for establishing death, including presumptions of death for individuals missing for five continuous years, and provides liability protections for third-party payors who distribute property in good faith.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary, Orphans' Courts, and Registers of Wills
qa_results.stakeholders: Property owners, estate beneficiaries, heirs, joint tenants, trustees, insurance companies, and other financial institutions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the Fiscal and Policy Note; however, the bill modifies legal standards for private property inheritance and is not expected to significantly impact state or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Register of Wills is the primary agency responsible for overseeing the administrative probate of decedents' estates and protecting legal records related to estate proceedings, which are directly impacted by the survival requirements and evidentiary procedures established in this bill.

The Administrative Office of the Courts manages the infrastructure for the state's court system, including probate proceedings and civil actions involving disputed assets which are subject to the new evidentiary standards and liability rules outlined in the bill.

The bill explicitly cites the Department of Health's role in issuing death certificates and determining death under the Health - General Article, which serve as the primary prima facie evidence for the survivorship determinations required by the Act.

As a 'payor' that manages pension and retirement plans (defined as 'governing instruments' in the bill), the agency is directly impacted by the 120-hour survival rule for the distribution of benefits to survivors and beneficiaries.

The bill impacts the insurance industry by defining insurers as 'payors' and insurance/annuity policies as 'governing instruments,' establishing new legal requirements for how proceeds are distributed in cases of near-simultaneous death.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Teachers & State Employees Supplemental Retirement Plans
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency manages voluntary retirement accounts that qualify as 'governing instruments' under the bill, making it responsible for applying the new survivorship timelines when distributing assets to beneficiaries.

The Treasurer's Office oversees various public funds and retirement programs, including the Maryland 529 program, which are considered governing instruments subject to the bill's provisions regarding survivorship and property devolution.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies (many of which are 'payors' under the bill) and manages civil matters that may arise from the distribution of assets under the new Uniform Simultaneous Death Act standards.

The MVA manages vehicle titling and registration, which frequently involves co-ownership with right of survivorship; the bill's provisions on co-owners and property devolution would govern how vehicle titles are transferred after near-simultaneous deaths.

As a provider of retirement savings accounts (Roth IRAs) which are 'governing instruments,' the agency must comply with the 120-hour survivorship rule for distributions to beneficiaries in simultaneous death scenarios.

The bill establishes that reports by government agencies regarding an individual's status (missing, dead, etc.) serve as prima facie evidence; as an agency that investigates fatal accidents and files such reports, MSP is relevant to the bill's evidentiary procedures.

The agency helps veterans navigate state benefits and manage the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund; survivorship rules established in this bill could affect the distribution of financial grants and benefits to the families of veterans.

The bill references the potential for property to escheat to the state if survivorship cannot be established; the Comptroller's role as the fiscal watchdog and manager of unclaimed property makes them relevant to these edge cases.
College savings and disability accounts managed by this agency include beneficiary designations that are governed by the survivorship and 'governing instrument' definitions in the bill.

The department advocates for older adults and handles public guardianship; the bill's changes to estate law and survivorship periods significantly impact the population the department serves regarding inheritance and estate planning.

As an insurer, the agency acts as a 'payor' under the bill's definitions and may be required to apply the 120-hour survivorship rule when distributing accident policy proceeds involving near-simultaneous deaths.

DBM oversees the statewide personnel system and benefits; as an 'employer' and 'payor' of various state benefits, it is impacted by the rules governing the distribution of employee-related assets and plans.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and overseeing the executive branch agencies (payors) that must implement the new survivorship standards for state-administered benefits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to develop and maintain a standardized flood risk disclosure statement. Starting July 1, 2027, vendors of residential real property are required to provide this completed disclosure form to potential purchasers before entering into a sales contract. The form includes details on the property's flood hazard zone status, flood insurance requirements, and history of flood damage or insurance claims.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Sellers and purchasers of residential real property in Maryland, and the Maryland Department of the Environment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to develop, publish, and maintain a flood risk disclosure form by June 1, 2027, which will likely result in administrative costs. While the provided text does not contain the specific Fiscal and Policy Note estimates, implementation involves state agency workload for form creation and maintenance. No specific local fiscal impact or state revenue changes are mentioned in the provided text.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates the Department of the Environment (MDE) to develop, publish, and maintain the real property flood risk disclosure statement form. MDE is also responsible for defining flood hazard areas in accordance with FEMA standards as outlined in the bill.

The Department of Labor oversees the licensing and regulation of real estate professionals. These licensees will be the primary parties responsible for ensuring that vendors comply with the new disclosure requirements during residential property transactions.

The bill significantly impacts the residential real estate market and the homebuying process. DHCD’s mission to provide safe and sustainable housing is directly supported by ensuring purchasers are informed of flood risks before entering into a contract.

The disclosure form requires specific information regarding whether a property is subject to federal flood insurance requirements and the history of insurance claims, which falls under the MIA's regulatory and consumer education mandate.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of the Environment in developing the form and enforces state consumer protection laws, which are relevant to real property disclosure mandates.

The Department of Planning coordinates land-use policy and provides technical assistance to local governments regarding sustainable growth and infrastructure, which includes managing and communicating environmental risks like flooding.

DNR provides technical expertise and management of the state's waterways and coastal resources. Their work on coastal storm surges and tidal inundation is directly relevant to the flood risk categories defined in the disclosure form.

MDEM is responsible for hazard mitigation and disaster preparedness. Flood risk disclosure is a key component of hazard education and long-term community resilience, which are core parts of the agency's mission.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable land-use policies and environmental stewardship. Requiring flood risk disclosures helps prevent urban sprawl into high-risk areas and aligns with 'smart growth' principles.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of the Environment and is responsible for the implementation of new state laws and the overall coordination of executive branch initiatives.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for compensation received as tips or gratuities by employees in food service facilities, hotels, businesses licensed for on-sale alcoholic beverage consumption, and taxi or passenger-for-hire services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller’s Office
qa_results.stakeholders: Employees receiving tips in the food service, hospitality, and transportation (taxi and passenger-for-hire) industries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues and local income tax revenues are projected to decrease by an indeterminate but potentially significant amount annually starting in fiscal 2027 due to the subtraction modification. The Comptroller’s Office can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's tax collector and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for implementing income tax subtraction modifications, updating tax forms, and managing the resulting impact on state revenue collections.

DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and formulating the annual budget. The fiscal note indicates a potentially significant decrease in general fund revenues, which directly impacts DBM's budgetary planning and resource allocation.

The bill's definitions for eligible 'passenger-for-hire services' and 'taxicab services' are explicitly linked to Title 10 of the Public Utilities Article, which is the regulatory framework overseen by the Public Service Commission.

As the chief executive office responsible for signing legislation into law and overseeing state fiscal policy, the Governor's Office would be responsible for the final policy direction of this significant tax change.

The Treasurer is the principal custodian of the state's financial assets and manages state funds. A significant reduction in income tax revenue affects the overall fiscal health and cash management overseen by the Treasurer.
The bill utilizes definitions of 'food service facility' found within the Health – General Article, which is the primary regulatory and oversight domain of the Department of Health.

The Department of Labor oversees workforce development and monitors the economic welfare of residents. The bill specifically impacts the net income of a large segment of the Maryland workforce, including those in the food service and hospitality sectors.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for supporting the expansion of businesses and workforce training. The industries targeted—hotels, food service, and transportation—are core sectors of the Maryland economy that Commerce supports through financial assistance and marketing.

The hospitality and service industries (hotels, restaurants, transportation) are fundamental to the tourism sector. Changes to the tax structure for tipped workers in these industries are highly relevant to the Office of Tourism Development's mission to support tourism-related jobs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Social Isolation and Loneliness Pilot Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health. The program provides grants to up to five eligible entities to cover operating costs for maintaining or expanding programs that provide socioemotional support to populations vulnerable to social isolation. The program specifically prioritizes youth, senior, and rural populations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Vulnerable populations experiencing social isolation and loneliness (specifically youth, seniors, and rural residents) and the organizations that provide them with socioemotional support services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill requires a mandatory General Fund appropriation of $100,000 in fiscal year 2028. This funding is designated for five grants of up to $20,000 each for eligible entities. The Maryland Department of Health is responsible for administering the program and must report on its progress and expenditures by December 1, 2029.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly establishes the Social Isolation and Loneliness Pilot Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health and mandates that the Department administer the program, award grants, and conduct a final evaluation and report.
The bill mandates that the Department of Health collaborate with the Department of Aging to prioritize senior populations when awarding grants under the program.
The bill mandates that the Department of Health collaborate with the Governor's Office for Children to prioritize youth populations when awarding grants under the program.

The bill mandates that the Department of Health collaborate with the Department of Housing and Community Development to prioritize rural populations and potentially relevant community programming when awarding grants.
The bill requires a specific appropriation of $100,000 in the Fiscal Year 2028 budget, which falls under the oversight and management of the Department of Budget and Management.
The Governor is required by the bill to include a specific appropriation in the annual budget for the program and is the recipient of the final program evaluation report due in 2029.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill prohibits employers from requiring employees or prospective employees to sign training repayment agreements as a condition of employment, making such agreements null and void. It authorizes the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to investigate violations and assess civil penalties, while also allowing affected individuals to bring civil actions for economic damages and restitution.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Commissioner of Labor and Industry
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employers, employees, prospective employees, and third-party training providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill establishes civil penalties for violations, including up to $10,000 for the first offense and $20,000 for subsequent offenses, which would likely increase state general fund revenues. State expenditures may increase to accommodate investigations by the Commissioner of Labor and Industry. Employers could face significant costs from civil judgments, including restitution and liquidated damages up to three times the restitution amount.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Labor and is responsible for signing the bill into law and directing its statewide implementation across executive agencies.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor to the Department of Labor and would represent the state in any legal challenges or enforcement litigation arising from the prohibition of training repayment agreements.
As the state's central personnel authority, DBM must ensure that state employment contracts and individual agency training policies comply with the new prohibition on training repayment agreements.
The Department of Commerce monitors labor regulations that affect the private-sector business climate; this bill directly impacts how employers manage financial investments in employee training.

The Department of Labor is the primary agency responsible for enforcing the bill. The Commissioner of Labor and Industry is empowered to investigate complaints, assess civil penalties, and oversee the prohibition.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Small businesses often utilize training agreements to protect investments in staff skills; this office would play a role in helping these businesses navigate and comply with the new regulatory requirements.

This bill impacts workforce development policy by regulating how training costs are handled between employers and workers, which is central to the board's mission of aligning training with economic growth.
The bill creates a private right of action, allowing employees or prospective employees to bring civil actions for economic damages and restitution in the state court system managed by this agency.
The Commission oversees training providers and career schools; because these entities are often the 'third party' recipients of training repayment funds, they may see a regulatory or fiscal impact.
The Commission oversees training providers and career schools; because these entities are often the 'third party' recipients of training repayment funds, they may see a regulatory or fiscal impact.
The bill mandates that civil penalties assessed by the Commissioner of Labor are subject to administrative hearing requirements, which are adjudicated by Administrative Law Judges at the OAH.
The bill specifically excludes training repayment agreements that are part of collective bargaining agreements, which are governed and overseen by the PERB.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes regulations to prevent waterborne diseases, specifically Legionnaires' disease, by requiring public water systems to maintain minimum disinfectant levels and perform regular testing. It mandates that water suppliers notify customers of system disruptions that could increase bacteria levels and requires owners of certain large buildings to implement water management programs. Additionally, the Maryland Department of the Environment and the Maryland Department of Health are tasked with investigating disease cases, maintaining public databases of water disruptions, and conducting public awareness campaigns on water safety.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and the Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Public water suppliers, residents and consumers of public water, owners and operators of buildings meeting ASHRAE Standard 188-2018, and state and local health departments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases state expenditures for the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to develop new regulations, conduct case investigations, perform water testing, and manage a public awareness campaign. State revenues will increase through the collection of civil penalties (ranging from $100 to $1,000 per day depending on the population served) for violations, which are directed to a new special fund within MDH. Local governments that operate public water systems will also incur additional costs related to disinfectant residual maintenance, system testing, and mandatory public notifications.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is primarily assigned to the Department of the Environment (MDE), which is responsible for establishing and enforcing minimum disinfectant residual levels, investigating water system violations, receiving system disruption records, and adopting regulations regarding nitrification and construction monitoring.

The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is a primary implementer of this bill, tasked with investigating Legionnaires' disease diagnoses, testing fixtures at exposure points, establishing a public registry of cases, developing a public awareness campaign, and managing a new special fund for penalties collected under the Act.

As a state agency that operates water treatment plants and distribution systems for various jurisdictions, MES is directly impacted by the new requirements for maintaining disinfectant residual levels and performing frequent system testing.

The PSC regulates public water utilities (suppliers of water) that are mandated by this bill to maintain specific disinfectant levels and provide written notices to customers regarding distribution system disruptions.

DGS manages and maintains state-owned facilities. The bill requires owners and operators of 'covered buildings' (under ASHRAE standards) to implement water management programs, and DGS would likely be responsible for compliance across the state's building portfolio.
The bill requires MDE and MDH to provide a comprehensive annual report to the Governor regarding Legionnaires' cases, violations, and legislative recommendations for waterborne pathogen control.
The bill creates a new special fund within MDH and mandates the distribution of penalties to this fund. The Comptroller oversees state revenue collection and fiscal management of such funds.
The Treasurer's Office is the principal custodian of state funds and would be involved in the management and protection of the new special fund created by the bill.
DBM oversees the state budget and would be involved in the fiscal implementation of the new mandates, including the public awareness campaign and the administration of the newly created special fund.

The OAG provides legal counsel to MDE and MDH for the development of regulations and would likely represent the agencies in enforcement actions or the collection of civil penalties described in the bill.

Older adults are a primary 'at-risk' and 'vulnerable' population for Legionnaires' disease. The bill mandates a targeted consumer education program, which would naturally involve MDOA's mission and outreach networks.

The bill involves the implementation of building standards (ASHRAE) and impacts professional trades such as HVAC and plumbing contractors who are licensed by the Department of Labor. Additionally, the department handles MOSH workplace safety standards.
The bill provides for hearings before MDE imposes civil penalties on water suppliers. OAH would be the independent agency responsible for conducting these administrative proceedings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS operates state prisons which, as large residential facilities, would likely qualify as 'covered buildings' required to implement the new water management programs specified in the bill.

The department operates the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, a long-term care facility. Such facilities house vulnerable populations and are specifically targeted for water management programs to prevent Legionella growth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill provides that individuals serving a sentence of life plus additional years for specific sexual crimes or sexual abuse of a minor may only be considered for parole once after becoming eligible. If a victim, their representative, or an advocacy group objects to the parole, it must be denied permanently. Additionally, the bill requires the Maryland General Assembly to remove records of legislative testimony provided by individuals convicted of crimes of violence from its website upon the request of a victim or their representative, establishing a restrictive process for subsequent access requests.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Parole Commission and the Maryland General Assembly
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals convicted of sexual crimes or crimes of violence, victims of these crimes, victims' families and advocacy groups, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: A Fiscal and Policy Note was not included in the provided text; however, the bill would likely increase administrative costs for the Maryland Parole Commission to notify victims and for the General Assembly to manage testimony removal and access requests. Long-term state expenditures may increase due to the permanent denial of parole for certain offenders, potentially increasing the length of incarceration.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Correctional Services Article to limit parole eligibility for individuals convicted of certain sexual crimes and requires the Parole Commission, which is housed within this department, to notify victims and permanently deny parole if a victim objects.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the Parole Commission and state agencies. It would be responsible for defending the constitutionality of the bill's provisions, such as the permanent denial of parole based on third-party objections and the removal of public records.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD represents indigent individuals facing potential incarceration and loss of liberty. This bill significantly impacts their clients by restricting parole to a single opportunity and creating a mechanism for permanent denial.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy and victim services, this office is relevant to the bill's focus on sexual offender accountability and the expansion of victims' rights in the parole and legislative process.
The judiciary will likely handle legal challenges and judicial reviews arising from the new parole restrictions and the novel procedures regarding the removal of public legislative testimony.

As the central depository for government and legislative records of permanent value, the agency is relevant to provisions requiring the removal of legislative testimony from public view and the management of substitute notices.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments, including those implementing the new parole requirements, and is responsible for signing or vetoing the legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill proposes a constitutional amendment to increase the size of the Maryland General Assembly starting in 2033, expanding the Senate to 48 members and the House of Delegates to 144 members. It also establishes staggered four-year terms for Senators beginning with the 2032 election and requires Delegates to vacate their seats if they run for a Senate seat with an overlapping term.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters, candidates for the General Assembly, and current members of the Maryland House of Delegates and Senate.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the Fiscal and Policy Note. However, constitutional amendments typically incur minor costs for the State Board of Elections to include the measure on the general election ballot, and the expansion of the General Assembly's membership in 2033 would result in increased state expenditures for legislative salaries, benefits, and administrative staff.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill proposes a constitutional amendment that must be submitted to the voters at a general election managed by the SBE. Furthermore, it alters the timing and method of State Senate elections to a staggered system, which directly impacts the agency's primary responsibility for election administration and ballot certification.

The bill increases the total membership of the General Assembly from 188 to 192 members (adding 1 Senator and 3 Delegates). This has a direct and permanent fiscal impact on the state's operating budget regarding legislative salaries, benefits, and administrative support costs, which DBM oversees.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for receiving the election returns of the constitutional amendment referendum as directed by Article XIV of the Maryland Constitution.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the General Assembly and the Governor. They would be responsible for reviewing the legal sufficiency of the proposed constitutional amendment and potentially defending the ballot language or implementation process.

DGS is responsible for the maintenance and management of state-owned facilities, including the State House. Increasing the number of legislators would require the agency to manage the physical infrastructure and office space needs for additional members and their staff.

The Archives maintains the official records of the General Assembly and the Maryland Manual. The change in the composition and election cycles of the legislature would require significant updates to the state's historical and administrative records managed by this agency.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Congressional Stock Trading Transparency Act requires the Maryland State Board of Elections to add an option to the certificate of candidacy for individuals running for the U.S. Senate or House of Representatives. This option allows candidates to pledge that, if elected, they and their spouse will not buy, sell, or exchange individual stocks during their term of office. The State Board of Elections must publish which candidates made this indication on its website.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections (SBE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Candidates for the U.S. Senate and the U.S. House of Representatives, spouses of congressional candidates, and Maryland voters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact. The State Board of Elections can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Elections is the primary agency responsible for managing the certificate of candidacy process. This bill directly mandates that the Board update its prescribed forms for congressional candidates and develop a digital mechanism to publish stock trading disclosure indications on its website.

The bill promotes transparency regarding candidate financial interests (stock trading), which aligns with the Commission's mission to manage financial disclosure programs. Additionally, the bill explicitly references the requirement for candidates to file financial disclosure statements with this Commission as a prerequisite for their certificate of candidacy.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of the State Board of Elections and is responsible for signing election-related legislation into law. The bill's focus on government transparency and public trust falls under the Governor's broad policy oversight.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor to the State Board of Elections. It would likely be tasked with reviewing the updated candidacy form for legal sufficiency and advising on any constitutional or federal legal issues related to the voluntary disclosure pledge.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows certain documents, such as a deed submitted for recordation, a certified intake sheet, or a HUD-1 settlement statement, to be used in court to establish a rebuttable presumption of real property ownership. The measure is intended to help new property owners engage in legal proceedings to protect their property while waiting for the official deed recordation process to be completed.
qa_results.responsible_party: Supreme Court of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: New real property owners, individuals involved in real property legal proceedings, and the Maryland Judiciary.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local government operations or finances, as indicated by the Department of Legislative Services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Maryland Judiciary by establishing new evidentiary standards in court proceedings involving real property. It also explicitly authorizes the Supreme Court of Maryland to adopt rules and forms to implement the act. The Administrative Office of the Courts supports the Judiciary and oversees court policies and the clerks of the circuit court who manage land records.

The Maryland Tax Court is the highest administrative review body for tax controversies, including real property assessments. As the bill creates a rebuttable presumption of ownership for use in proceedings involving real property, it would be highly relevant to the Tax Court's adjudication of property-related disputes.

The Register of Wills oversees the probate of estates, which frequently involve determining the ownership of real property. This bill provides a mechanism to establish a presumption of ownership using documents like settlement statements, which is critical during the time a deed is being processed for recordation following a death or estate transfer.

The Office of Administrative Hearings provides mediation and adjudication for various state agencies, specifically including home foreclosure disputes. The ability to use settlement documents as a rebuttable presumption of ownership would be a significant evidentiary tool in these real property-related proceedings.

This agency manages housing programs, low-interest mortgages, and community development. They were consulted for the bill's fiscal note as the legislation aims to protect new property owners and clarify ownership during the recordation process, which aligns with their mission of fostering sustainable housing opportunities.

As the chief legal office for the State, the OAG provides counsel to the Judiciary and executive agencies on changes to the rule of law. They would be involved in implementing and defending these new evidentiary standards in proceedings where state interests or state-represented parties are involved.

This board hears appeals regarding property valuations and tax credits. Proving ownership is often a necessary component of standing in such appeals, making the bill's rebuttable presumption a relevant evidentiary standard for their hearings.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits health care providers from using their own human reproductive material for assisted reproductive treatment without the recipient's informed consent. It mandates written informed consent for the use of donor material, prohibits the misrepresentation of donor identity or genetic history, and establishes civil liability and felony criminal penalties for violations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland health occupation licensing boards
qa_results.stakeholders: Recipients of assisted reproductive treatments, donors of reproductive material, health care providers, and children born from these treatments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill establishes a new felony offense and a civil cause of action, which may increase the workload of state and local court systems and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. Criminal fines of up to $5,000 may result in a minimal increase in state revenue. No specific funding is allocated by the bill.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulator of public health services and health care facility standards, the Department of Health (MDH) is responsible for the statutes under the Health - General Article, which this bill amends. MDH also coordinates the activities of the health occupations licensing boards that must receive reports of misuse or fraud under this bill.

The bill creates new civil causes of action for damages and establishes a new felony offense for unauthorized use of reproductive material. This directly impacts the judiciary through increased caseloads, the issuance of qualified protective orders, and the adjudication of both civil and criminal proceedings.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and its licensing boards. Additionally, its divisions investigating consumer and health care fraud would be relevant to the misrepresentation and informed consent violations outlined in the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new felony offense punishable by up to 10 years in prison. DPSCS would be responsible for the management and incarceration of any individuals convicted under this new provision.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Since the bill involves civil actions for damages resulting from improper medical conduct by health care providers, these claims may fall under the office's jurisdiction as medical injury claims that must be filed through arbitration before proceeding to trial.

The bill requires providers to report misuse to their licensing boards. Disciplinary actions taken by these boards against a provider's license are typically adjudicated through the OAH to ensure due process.

As a statewide law enforcement agency responsible for investigating major crimes, the Maryland State Police would be involved in investigating allegations of the new felony offense related to unauthorized assisted reproductive treatment.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementing these health standards and has the authority to sign or veto this legislation concerning medical ethics and consumer protection.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Out-of-State Driver Accountability Act requires county and municipal automated traffic enforcement programs (including speed cameras, red light cameras, and school bus cameras) to submit quarterly reports to the Maryland Department of Transportation's Vision Zero coordinator. These reports must include specific data on citations issued to out-of-state vehicles, such as registration plate numbers, state of registration, payment status, and delinquency status, as well as cumulative summaries of these statistics.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Vision Zero coordinator within the Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Out-of-state motor vehicle drivers and Maryland local governments (counties and municipalities) that operate automated traffic enforcement systems.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: While the Fiscal Note text was not provided in the source material, the bill creates a state and local fiscal impact through administrative mandates. Local jurisdictions will incur expenditures to modify citation systems and allocate staff time for compiling, updating, and submitting quarterly reports on out-of-state violations. The Maryland Department of Transportation will experience an increase in workload for the Vision Zero coordinator to manage the collection of these reports and collaborate with local enforcement programs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT) as it requires the 'Department' to designate a Vision Zero coordinator to receive and collaborate on quarterly reports from local automated traffic enforcement programs.

As a unit of MDOT, the MVA is responsible for vehicle registration and driver services. The bill's reporting requirements specifically concern registration plate numbers and the payment status of citations issued to out-of-state vehicles.
The SHA is the primary business unit within MDOT responsible for roadway safety and the implementation of Vision Zero. It also operates work zone speed control systems mentioned in the bill.

The Maryland State Police is the primary agency for enforcing motor vehicle laws. Data regarding out-of-state violators and automated enforcement trends is critical to their statewide traffic safety mission.

Automated traffic citations are legal documents that may be contested through the judicial system. The reporting on payment and past-due status intersects with the Judiciary's role in managing traffic citation data.

The MDTA operates toll facilities and automated enforcement systems, such as work zone speed control, and has a vested interest in the accountability and collection of citations from out-of-state drivers.
The bill explicitly references 'bus lane monitoring systems' as one of the automated enforcement programs; the MTA operates and manages the state's bus lanes and transit infrastructure.
The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Transportation and spearheads statewide safety initiatives like Vision Zero through policy and executive leadership.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDOT and would likely be involved in interpreting legal requirements for data sharing and inter-jurisdictional accountability of out-of-state drivers.
GOPI tracks progress on the Governor's key priorities, including public safety and Vision Zero, utilizing the data-driven reporting required by this bill to measure policy success.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises the Governor on public safety policy and coordinates statewide initiatives to reduce violations and enhance accountability, aligning with the bill's goal of out-of-state driver accountability.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the governing body of Baltimore County to grant a 100% property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on real property owned by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34, located at 730 Wampler Road in Middle River, Maryland.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore County Government
qa_results.stakeholders: Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34 and Baltimore County government
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State revenues or expenditures. Baltimore County property tax revenues may decrease by approximately $9,600 annually beginning in fiscal 2027, provided the county grants the optional credit. County expenditures are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly, including this bill which authorizes a specific property tax credit in Baltimore County.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Governor and the General Assembly, reviewing legislation for legal sufficiency and constitutionality.

The Maryland Tax Court is the state's highest administrative review body for tax controversies, including real property tax disputes, which could arise from the implementation or denial of the property tax credit authorized by this bill.

PTAAB hears appeals regarding property tax assessments and the rejection of property tax exemptions or credits at the county level; it would be the relevant appellate body for disputes concerning the credit authorized for the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 34.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a process for the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) to identify and penalize Maryland residents who have improperly registered their vehicles in another state. The process includes a 60-day warning period for residents to come into compliance, followed by civil fines of $7 per day for up to 60 days of continued noncompliance, and potential referral to local State's Attorneys for vehicle immobilization through towing or booting.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents with vehicles improperly registered out-of-state, the Motor Vehicle Administration, and local county State's Attorneys.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues (primarily Transportation Trust Fund) are estimated to increase by $15.4 million in FY 2027 and $6.2 million annually thereafter from registration fees and fines. State expenditures increase by $379,365 in FY 2027 for MVA to hire five additional customer service agents and cover operating costs. Local governments will receive additional revenues from shared registration fees and the collection of past-due automated enforcement citations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill's requirements, including issuing warnings, assessing civil fines, and managing the compliance process for improperly registered out-of-state vehicles.

As the cabinet-level agency overseeing the MVA, MDOT is responsible for the overall implementation of the bill and the management of the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), which is projected to see significant revenue increases and expenditure requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS receives a significant portion of its funding through the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF), which is sustained by vehicle registration surcharges that are expected to increase notably under this legislation.

DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget; this bill necessitates the creation of five new customer service positions and involves substantial shifts in special fund revenues and operating expenditures.

The Department of Health oversees public health financing, including the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, which receives a portion of the registration surcharges collected from vehicles brought into compliance by this bill.

The bill authorizes civil actions in rem to be brought against vehicles for persistent noncompliance, which would be processed through the judicial infrastructure managed by the Administrative Office of the Courts.
The Maryland State Police enforce the state's motor vehicle laws and will be responsible for roadside verification and reporting of registration compliance for Maryland residents.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the MVA and MDOT and would be responsible for advising on the legal standards of probable cause and the framework for the new enforcement and fine systems.
The OAH would provide the impartial forum for residents to challenge MVA decisions regarding civil fines or registration requirements as established by this bill.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies implementing this bill and is responsible for the final approval of the legislation and the associated budget impacts for MDOT and the MVA.

The State Treasurer's Office acts as the custodian of state funds, including the Transportation Trust Fund, and manages the banking and investment of the significant new revenues generated by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill permits fair housing testers to intercept and record oral communications without the consent of all parties, provided the tester is a party to the conversation and is working for a government agency or a qualified nonprofit civil rights organization to obtain evidence of a fair housing violation. The recorded content may only be used for the enforcement of federal, state, or local fair housing laws and is generally inadmissible in other legal proceedings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Civil Rights and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Fair housing testers, nonprofit civil rights organizations, housing providers, and individuals or entities involved in fair housing enforcement proceedings.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local finances or operations, as described in the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Commission on Civil Rights is the primary state agency responsible for enforcing anti-discrimination laws in housing. This bill provides a critical investigative tool by allowing fair housing testers to lawfully record oral communications during testing activities, which would directly impact the Commission's enforcement capabilities and evidence collection procedures.

The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development is tasked with expanding access to affordable housing and fostering healthy communities. Since fair housing testing is a vital component of ensuring equitable access to housing, this bill's provisions regarding the legality of interception of communications for fair housing evidence are highly relevant to the department's mission.

The bill amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article to establish new standards for the legality and admissibility of evidence derived from intercepted oral communications. The Administrative Office of the Courts is responsible for managing judicial policies and information systems related to court proceedings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Maryland law generally makes the interception of oral communications a felony without all-party consent. By creating a specific exception for fair housing testers, this bill directly affects the scope of criminal liability and potential defenses for individuals participating in such programs, which is relevant to the Office of the Public Defender's mandate to represent indigent clients.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies like the Commission on Civil Rights. They would likely handle the legal defense or administrative proceedings involving the new evidence standards created by this bill and investigate multi-jurisdictional housing discrimination cases.

The Maryland State Police are responsible for enforcing state laws, including the wiretap and electronic surveillance statutes being amended. The creation of a 'lawful' exception for fair housing testers affects statewide policing standards regarding the investigation of illegal interceptions.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the various departments involved in housing and civil rights enforcement and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation that significantly alters state evidence and surveillance laws.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires all Maryland institutions of higher education that receive State funds to develop and implement an academic forgiveness policy by August 1, 2026. This policy allows applicants to elect to have grades earned seven or more years prior to their application disregarded during the admissions process.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland institutions of higher education that receive State funds
qa_results.stakeholders: Applicants to Maryland higher education institutions with unsatisfactory academic records from at least seven years prior, and the institutions themselves.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not contain the Fiscal and Policy Note; however, the bill mandates that state-funded institutions of higher education develop and implement new academic policies, which would likely result in administrative costs for those institutions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary regulatory and coordinating board for higher education, the Commission is responsible for establishing statewide policies and overseeing both public and private institutions. This bill mandates a new academic forgiveness policy for all state-funded institutions, requiring the Commission's oversight and potential modification of the State Plan for Postsecondary Education.

This agency serves as the coordinating and regulatory board for Maryland's public and private colleges and universities. It will be responsible for ensuring that all state-funded institutions comply with the mandate to develop and implement an academic forgiveness policy by August 2026.

The University System of Maryland provides strategic leadership and financial stewardship for 12 public universities. As institutions that receive state funds, all member universities under this system will be directly required to implement the academic forgiveness policy for their admissions processes.

As a state-funded public university with its own independent Board of Regents, Morgan State University is directly mandated by the bill to develop and implement an academic forgiveness policy that disregards older unsatisfactory grades during the admissions process.

As an independent public honors college that receives state funds, Saint Mary's College of Maryland is required to implement the academic forgiveness policy as specified in the legislation for eligible applicants.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to nearly all state agencies, including public universities and higher education boards. The office would be responsible for providing legal counsel to institutions as they draft and implement their academic forgiveness policies to ensure compliance with the law and Title 15 of the Education Article.

The MLDS Center tracks student records and academic outcomes to analyze the effectiveness of educational programs. Policies that disregard past grades in admissions for returning students would impact the agency's data tracking and its research on student success pathways and completion rates.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs legislation into law. This bill establishes a new statewide mandate for state-funded higher education institutions, falling under the office's responsibility for enforcing state laws and overseeing executive branch operations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Aging to conduct annual financial stress tests for continuing care retirement community (CCRC) providers, hire two analysts to perform these tests, and publish financial stability grades on its website. It also mandates quarterly meetings between providers and resident associations, requires the disclosure of meeting agendas and minutes to residents, and requires that resident members of a provider's governing body be elected by the residents and hold equal authority regarding asset and financial control.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
qa_results.stakeholders: Continuing care retirement community providers, residents of CCRCs (subscribers), and the Maryland Department of Aging
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase for the Maryland Department of Aging to hire two analysts for financial stress testing and report preparation. The Department must also maintain these results publicly on its website. No specific local fiscal impact or state revenue changes are identified in the bill text.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Aging is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill. It is explicitly required to conduct annual financial stress tests for continuing care retirement community (CCRC) providers, hire analysts, oversee the grading process via its Financial Review Committee, and maintain a public database of these grades.

The bill mandates that the Department of Aging hire two analysts to perform the stress tests. DBM is responsible for overseeing state personnel and the fiscal impact of these new positions, as well as managing the budget allocation required to fulfill the bill's mandates.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the Department of Aging. They would be responsible for providing counsel on the implementation of the financial stress tests, the legal implications of assigning public financial stability grades to private providers, and defending the agency in potential litigation.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Aging and is responsible for signing the legislation. The office also manages the state budget process, which must account for the new personnel and administrative costs introduced by the bill.

CCRCs often contain nursing homes and assisted living units regulated by the Department of Health. While MDOA handles the 'continuing care' contractual aspect, MDH oversees the licensing and health standards of the medical components within these communities, leading to regulatory overlap.

The MHCC regulates the distribution of healthcare facilities and maintains transparency regarding the cost and quality of nursing homes and outpatient centers. The bill's financial grading of CCRCs complements MHCC's mission to provide consumers with health system performance data.

CCRC providers may challenge the results of the financial stress tests or the stability grades assigned by the Department of Aging. OAH would serve as the impartial forum for these administrative appeals and hearings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly tasks the 'Department’s Financial Review Committee'—a specialized body—with assigning grades to indicate the financial stability of CCRC providers.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Health & Higher Educational Facilities Authority
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Many CCRCs are non-profit entities that utilize MHHEFA for low-cost bond financing. Mandatory financial stress tests and the resulting public stability grades could impact the creditworthiness and financing terms for these institutions.

Many continuing care facilities are vital infrastructure and economic drivers in rural counties. RMC advocates for the interests and service accessibility for residents in these areas, who would be directly impacted by the financial stability of local CCRCs.

While CCRCs are regulated by Aging, the financial nature of continuing care contracts (often including prepaid care) shares characteristics with long-term care insurance. MIA's role in monitoring insurer solvency aligns with the bill's intent to conduct financial stress testing for care providers.

The Department of Disabilities advocates for accessible and community-based housing for residents with disabilities. Many CCRC residents utilize these facilities for specialized care and disability services, making the financial stability of these providers a matter of disability policy interest.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill criminalizes benefits exploitation by prohibiting individuals from knowingly recruiting, harboring, transporting, or obtaining someone for the purpose of misappropriating their government benefits through deception, coercion, exploitation, or isolation. Violators are guilty of a felony and face up to 25 years of imprisonment and/or a maximum fine of $15,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Recipients of government benefits (including Medicare, Medicaid, SNAP, Social Security, and veterans benefits), elderly and disabled adults, and individuals at risk of being exploited for their public assistance.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $1,573 in FY 2026 for one-time programming changes for the Judiciary. Otherwise, the bill is not expected to materially affect State or local finances. The Office of the Public Defender's request for additional staffing was evaluated but deemed unnecessary by the Department of Legislative Services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies that the Administrative Office of the Courts requires general fund expenditures for one-time programming changes to the judicial systems to implement the new criminal charges established by this bill.

The OAG contains the Senior and Vulnerable Adult Asset Recovery Unit, which handles cases related to the exploitation of vulnerable adults. This bill expands criminal prohibitions for benefits exploitation, which directly aligns with the OAG's advocacy and enforcement mission.

The bill explicitly protects 'Government Benefits' managed by DHS, including SNAP, TANF, TDAP, and PAA. DHS is the primary agency responsible for delivering these services and protecting recipients from fraud and exploitation.
The bill's definition of protected government benefits includes Medicare, Medicaid, and WIC, which are programs managed or overseen by the Maryland Department of Health.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a new felony with a significant prison sentence of up to 25 years. DPSCS would be responsible for the management, incarceration, and community supervision of individuals convicted under this new law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies that OPD would be responsible for handling felony cases generated by this bill for indigent individuals, potentially impacting their workload.

The bill specifically addresses coercion that exerts financial control over elderly adults. MDOA is tasked with elder abuse prevention and protecting the rights of older adults, making the bill highly relevant to their mission.

The bill defines coercion to include exerting financial control over a disabled adult. MDOD advocates for the rights of individuals with disabilities and works to ensure their independence, which is directly threatened by benefits exploitation.
The bill specifically lists 'veterans benefits' as a protected class of government benefits, making the agency relevant as an advocate for veterans receiving these funds.

The bill's definition of 'government benefits' includes pension benefits. SRA manages the retirement plans for over 420,000 members and would have an interest in laws protecting those disbursements from exploitation.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency, MSP is responsible for investigating major crimes and felonies. This bill creates a new felony offense that MSP troopers and investigators would need to enforce.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the central hub for public safety policy. This bill introduces a new criminal justice strategy focused on protecting vulnerable populations from financial crime, which falls under GOCPP's policy advisory role.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor to annually proclaim May as Maryland Native Plant Month to recognize the environmental benefits of plants that occur naturally in the state. The proclamation urges educational and environmental organizations and businesses to observe the month through appropriate programs, events, and activities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Educational and environmental organizations, businesses, and the general public of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the associated Fiscal and Policy Note; however, establishing a commemorative month via gubernatorial proclamation typically has no impact on state or local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Governor to annually proclaim May as Maryland Native Plant Month and mandates the content of the proclamation.
The bill uses the definition of 'native plant' provided in the Agriculture Article and relates to the department's work in plant health and environmental stewardship.

The bill recognizes the benefits of native plants to Maryland's natural environment, which is the core mission of DNR. The agency would likely be involved in the programs and events mentioned in the proclamation.
The proclamation specifically urges educational organizations to observe Maryland Native Plant Month with programs and activities, impacting K-12 schools managed by MSDE.
The bill's focus on native plants as a benefit to the natural environment aligns with MDE's mission to restore and protect land and water resources.
As a state-chartered organization that funds environmental education and restoration projects, the Trust would likely be a primary entity observing the month and creating associated programming.
This multi-agency initiative coordinates the state's environmental stewardship and resource conservation efforts, making the promotion of native plants highly relevant to its mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes the deadline for the Office of the Attorney General to submit its annual report regarding the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit from November 30 to October 1. It also specifies that the report must cover activities from the preceding fiscal year and include actions taken by the Department of the Environment and the Department of Natural Resources in response to the unit's findings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Office of the Attorney General, Maryland Department of the Environment, Department of Natural Resources, Governor of Maryland, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local operations or finances. The change is primarily administrative, intended to align reporting dates and periods with other department enforcement reports to reduce administrative burden.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) as it houses the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit. The Attorney General is specifically tasked with the new reporting deadline and period requirements established by the act.

The bill requires the annual report to include actions taken by the Maryland Department of the Environment in response to the Unit's findings. Additionally, the reporting date change is intended to align with MDE's existing annual enforcement and compliance reporting cycle.

The bill explicitly requires that the annual report include activities and actions taken by the Department of Natural Resources in response to the findings and recommendations of the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit.
The Governor is one of the primary recipients of the annual report mandated by this bill regarding the activities of the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Voting Rights Act of 2026 establishes protections against voter intimidation, deception, and obstruction, and prohibits local governments from implementing election policies that result in material disparities for protected classes based on race, color, or language minority status. It expands public notice requirements for administrative policy changes affecting voting rights and authorizes civil actions by the Attorney General and aggrieved parties to enforce these protections, with court-ordered remedies including expanded voting hours, additional polling locations, and other measures to ensure equitable access.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Elections, local boards of elections, municipal corporations, and the Maryland Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters (particularly members of protected classes), local governments, county boards of education, and election administrators
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local election boards will incur administrative costs to meet enhanced public notice and website maintenance requirements. Local governments may face increased expenditures for legal defense, litigation costs, and the implementation of court-ordered remedies. The bill mandates that prevailing plaintiffs (excluding the state/local government unless the action is frivolous) are entitled to reimbursement of attorney's fees and reasonable costs from the opposing government entity.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County as the exclusive venue for certain actions and mandates that the Judiciary provide expedited pretrial and trial proceedings with automatic calendar preference for these cases.

The bill's focus on preventing voter suppression and protecting 'protected classes' from discrimination based on race, color, or language minority status aligns with the Commission's core mission of enforcing anti-discrimination laws.

DBM serves as the state's central fiscal authority and will be impacted by the staffing and operational resources required by the State Board of Elections and the Office of the Attorney General to implement and enforce the Act's mandates.

The bill specifically expands the definition of administrative policies affecting voting rights to include assistance for voters with disabilities and requires meaningful notice of changes for these residents.
