DHCD is required to provide state-level housing data and collaborate with the Department of Planning to provide technical assistance to local jurisdictions for the development of the Housing element.
The bill requires the Department of Commerce to provide local jurisdictions with the best available state-level data on economic development to support the newly required Economy element.
The Department of Labor is explicitly required to provide local jurisdictions with the best available state-level data on the labor force for the preparation of the Economy element.

The bill specifies that the Ecology element must address agricultural resources and preservation, and allows for priority preservation area subelements developed in accordance with the Agriculture Article.
The new Resilience element must be informed by the State Resilience Strategy and the State Hazard Mitigation Plan, both of which are central to MDEM's mission and statutory responsibilities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Equity element of local plans must be informed by the annual report of the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities, which falls under this category of executive bodies.
The bill requires the Economy element of local plans to be informed by the Maryland State Plan for Postsecondary Education, which is developed and overseen by MHEC.
The Municipal Growth subelement of local plans must ensure that public schools are sufficient to accommodate student populations consistent with rated capacity standards established by the IAC.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the various state agencies (Planning, Environment, etc.) tasked with implementing these new regulatory requirements and reviewing local land use elements.
SHA is specifically required to coordinate with the Department of Planning and DNR to provide jurisdictions with updated information on habitat connectivity and wildlife crossings.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows an individual who is the sole owner of a vessel to designate a beneficiary to take ownership of the vessel upon the owner's death, bypassing the standard estate administration process. The owner can add, change, or cancel a 'transfer-on-death' (TOD) designation on the vessel's certificate of title by applying to the Department of Natural Resources. Upon the owner's death, the beneficiary must apply for a new certificate of title and provide necessary documentation and fees.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Individual sole owners of vessels in Maryland and their designated beneficiaries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Boat Act Fund special fund revenues may increase starting in FY 2027; for illustrative purposes, if 10% of eligible owners apply for a new title at the $20 fee, revenues would increase by $265,540. State general fund revenues may decrease minimally due to lower probate fees and inheritance taxes collected by registers of wills. There is no expected impact on State expenditures or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the Department of Natural Resources is responsible for managing the application process for beneficiary designations, issuing new certificates of title, and collecting the associated fees and taxes specified in the bill.

The bill allows vessels to pass to beneficiaries outside of traditional estate administration (probate). This directly impacts the Register of Wills' primary responsibilities of auditing estate accounts and collecting inheritance taxes and probate fees, which the fiscal note indicates may decrease as a result.

The Maryland Department of Health maintains vital records; the bill requires a surviving beneficiary to provide a death certificate issued by the department as part of the application for a new vessel certificate of title.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM is relevant due to the bill's impact on state revenues, including an increase in special fund revenues for the State Boat Act Fund and a potential decrease in general fund revenues.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller oversees the general fund and revenue collection; the bill has a noted impact on general fund revenues derived from inheritance taxes and probate fees.

The AOC provides administrative and financial infrastructure for the Judiciary, including the Orphans' Courts served by the Register of Wills, and was a primary information source for the fiscal analysis of the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transfers the administration of the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program from the Maryland Energy Administration to the Maryland Clean Energy Center. It also updates the reporting requirements for the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund by raising the threshold for detailed accounting of disbursements to amounts exceeding $10,000 and changing the metric for program evaluation from electricity savings to greenhouse gas emissions reductions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Clean Energy Center
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations, local jurisdictions, State agencies, and eligible Maryland businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures are projected to increase by $131,300 in fiscal 2027, primarily to fund a new position at the Maryland Clean Energy Center to manage the transferred loan program. These costs are expected to reach $165,100 by fiscal 2031. There is a minor corresponding decrease in administrative expenditures for the Maryland Energy Administration. No impact on State revenues or local government finances is expected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MEA is the primary agency affected by the bill, as it is the current administrator of the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program being transferred and is responsible for the modified reporting requirements for the Strategic Energy Investment Fund.

MCEC is the agency receiving the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program and will be responsible for its management, supervision, and administration, including the hiring of new personnel to manage the fund.
The bill explicitly states that the State Treasurer shall hold the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Fund, maintaining its role as the principal custodian of the state's financial assets.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Fund, serving the office's role as the state's fiscal watchdog and chief financial officer.

The bill alters reporting requirements for the Strategic Energy Investment Fund to include estimates of greenhouse gas emissions reductions, which directly aligns with MDE's mission to lead the state's climate change initiatives and monitor air quality.
DBM oversees the state's budget and personnel system; it will be responsible for the fiscal adjustments related to the transfer of program funds and the reduction of administrative costs within MEA.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to state agencies and will be involved in the legal transfer of authority and the repeal of regulation-making powers associated with the program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Strategic Energy Investment Advisory Board receives the annual report for the Strategic Energy Investment Fund, the content and scope of which are directly modified by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that the registered owner of a Class G (trailer) vehicle is liable for payment of video tolls recorded at toll collection facilities. It outlines the administrative process for issuing notices of toll due and citations, provides mechanisms for the transfer of liability under specific conditions such as leasing or theft, and authorizes the Motor Vehicle Administration to refuse or suspend vehicle registration for failure to pay tolls and associated civil penalties.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Transportation Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Registered owners of Class G (trailer) vehicles, the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA), and the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to increase non-budgeted revenues for the Maryland Transportation Authority by enabling the collection of video tolls and civil penalties from trailer owners. While the specific Fiscal and Policy Note text was not included in the provided document, the bill's provisions for toll liability and enforcement via registration holds imply an increase in state revenue collection and potential administrative costs for MDTA and MVA.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The MDTA is the primary agency responsible for managing electronic toll collection and is authorized by this bill to hold Class G (trailer) vehicle owners liable for video tolls and issue associated citations.
The MVA manages registration records for Class G vehicles and is mandated by the bill to refuse or suspend registrations for owners with delinquent toll violations.
As the parent department for both the MDTA and MVA, MDOT is the primary proponent of this departmental legislation aimed at refining toll collection and liability enforcement.
The AOC oversees the judicial infrastructure for the District Court, which is the venue for individuals who elect to stand trial to contest liability for toll violations and penalties.
The OAG provides legal counsel and representation to the transportation agencies regarding the implementation, enforcement, and adjudication of toll liability laws.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies implementing the bill and is responsible for the final signing and high-level policy direction of the state's transportation and revenue strategies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the requirements and standards for obtaining a variance from land use regulations within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area. It establishes a rebuttable presumption that an existing accessory structure already provides reasonable use of a property, prohibits certain types of variance applications (such as those for unpermitted uses or mitigation adjustments), and requires applicants to demonstrate a substantial need for a variance that is not based on personal preference or financial gain. Additionally, it mandates that local boards of appeals hear cases on the record and grant deference to the findings of fact made by administrative officers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Critical Area Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Property owners with land in Critical Area zones, local government planning and zoning departments, and local boards of appeals.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal fiscal impact on state and local governments. While there are no direct state expenditures or revenues, local jurisdictions will incur minor administrative costs to update their local Critical Area programs and adjust variance procedures to comply with the new statutory requirements. No state funding is allocated by this legislation.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Critical Area Commission, which is the primary body responsible for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program, is housed within the Department of Natural Resources. This bill was introduced at the request of the Commission and directly modifies the legal standards the Commission uses to oversee local land use programs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This council integrates efforts across multiple departments to protect the Chesapeake Bay. This bill alters core legal standards for the Critical Area Protection Program, which is a key component of the state's unified approach to Bay restoration and water quality goals.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth policy. Because this bill modifies the requirements for local land use variances and standards for development within the Critical Area, it directly intersects with the department's role in guiding local government planning and urban design.

The MDE is responsible for protecting Maryland's water and land resources. The Critical Area Protection Program is a regulatory framework aimed at safeguarding the environmental health of the bays, which aligns with MDE's mission of enforcing pollution control and environmental laws.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the Critical Area Commission. These changes to variance standards and the requirements for local boards of appeals will require significant legal review and defense in the event of challenges to local or state decisions.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates 'Smart Growth' and environmental stewardship. The bill's changes to land use classification and variance standards are designed to reduce sprawl and protect habitat, which are core objectives of the Smart, Green & Growing initiative.

The Department of Agriculture manages resource conservation and farmland preservation within the state. Since many properties in the Critical Area are agricultural, changes to variance standards for structures and land use may impact farming operations and resource conservation efforts.

This is a departmental bill requested by the Critical Area Commission, signifying it is part of the executive branch's legislative agenda. The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and high-level policy related to environmental protection and economic opportunity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement that photographs on identification cards, driver's licenses, and moped operator's permits issued by the Motor Vehicle Administration be in color.
qa_results.responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents applying for or renewing identification cards, driver's licenses, or moped operator's permits.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund expenditures decrease by approximately $114,000 in fiscal 2027 and $152,000 annually thereafter due to reduced printing and material costs. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the state's budget, specifically reducing special fund expenditures from the Transportation Trust Fund by approximately $152,000 annually due to lower printing costs for the Motor Vehicle Administration.

As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration, MDOT is the primary sponsor of this departmental bill and manages the Transportation Trust Fund, which will realize the resulting expenditure savings.
The bill is a departmental initiative from the executive branch and aligns with the Governor's mandate to oversee state department operations and manage the state's annual budget effectively.

The bill's purpose is to modernize government services by removing an obsolete technical requirement to improve efficiency and eliminate waste, which directly aligns with this office's mission to streamline public services and enhance accountability.

State Troopers are primary end-users of driver's licenses and state-issued identification cards for field verification during traffic stops and criminal investigations; a change in the photograph format from color to black and white directly affects their visual identification procedures.

The MVA is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill, as it issues the identification cards, driver’s licenses, and moped permits that are the subject of the repealed color photograph requirement.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administrator to enter into reciprocal agreements with other jurisdictions for the enforcement of traffic violations recorded by automated systems, such as red light and speed cameras. Under these agreements, the Motor Vehicle Administration may refuse to register or reregister a motor vehicle if the owner has outstanding automated enforcement violations in a participating jurisdiction.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland motorists with out-of-state violations, out-of-state motorists with Maryland violations, the Motor Vehicle Administration, local jurisdictions, and the District Court.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local revenues are expected to increase starting as early as FY 2027 as the bill facilitates the collection of unpaid automated enforcement citations from out-of-state drivers. State revenues will accrue to the General Fund, Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), and nonbudgeted funds (MDTA), including a $30 administrative flag fee for vehicle reregistration. Local revenues will increase from paid citations, and local expenditures will increase accordingly as these funds must generally be used for public safety purposes. The Motor Vehicle Administration and the District Court can implement the bill using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) and the entity that requested this departmental bill, MDOT is the primary stakeholder responsible for the policy's implementation and the achievement of state safety goals like Vision Zero.

The bill explicitly authorizes the Motor Vehicle Administrator to enter into reciprocal agreements with other states and empowers the MVA to refuse vehicle registration or reregistration for unpaid automated citations.

SHA operates many of the automated speed monitoring systems that will benefit from enhanced enforcement capabilities and will see a direct increase in citation revenues collected from out-of-state drivers.
MDTA operates automated enforcement systems and receives nonbudgeted revenues from citations; the bill will directly impact its ability to collect fines from non-resident violators.

The AOC manages the administrative and financial infrastructure of the District Court, where contested automated enforcement citations are adjudicated. The bill may lead to a change in court caseloads.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor to MDOT and the MVA and will likely be involved in drafting, reviewing, and ensuring the legal compliance of reciprocal agreements with other jurisdictions.
As the primary statewide law enforcement agency focused on highway safety and traffic control, MSP is a stakeholder in policy changes intended to reduce speeding and red-light violations.
The Governor's Office oversees statewide initiatives such as public safety and highway safety (Vision Zero) and is responsible for the final approval of this legislation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the state's central hub for public safety policy and funding, coordinating initiatives to reduce crime and violence, which includes the enforcement of traffic safety laws.

The implementation of reciprocal enforcement will require secure and efficient data exchange between Maryland and other states, falling under DoIT's oversight of IT infrastructure and cybersecurity standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment to assess administrative penalties for violations of laws governing water use, dam safety, and wetlands construction. It also expands the department's ability to issue corrective orders and establishes standardized administrative hearing procedures.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Entities involved in water appropriation, dam maintenance, or wetlands development, including local governments and small businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund revenues are projected to increase by an estimated $250,000 in FY 2027 from new administrative penalties. This revenue is expected to offset $250,000 in general fund expenditures for the Maryland Department of the Environment in FY 2027 due to contingent budget language. Future years will have ongoing but indeterminate revenue increases. Local governments and small businesses may incur costs if they are non-compliant with the regulations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) requested this bill to expand its own enforcement authority. The bill specifically authorizes MDE to impose administrative penalties, issue corrective orders, and manage funds related to water resources, dam safety, and wetlands.

The bill provides for administrative hearings for persons accused of violations before MDE can impose penalties. The OAH conducts these formal hearings and mediations for state agencies, including MDE, to ensure due process.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to MDE and handles civil and criminal appeals. This bill modifies enforcement mechanisms, penalty assessment criteria, and lien procedures that the OAG will be responsible for overseeing and litigating.

The fiscal note identifies a direct budgetary impact managed by DBM. The FY 2027 budget includes a $250,000 reduction in MDE's general fund appropriation contingent on the enactment of this bill, with a corresponding increase in special fund expenditures from the new penalties.

MDOT and its business units are major state-level developers that manage infrastructure projects frequently requiring wetlands permits and waterway construction authorizations. The bill's expanded penalty framework for non-compliance directly impacts MDOT's regulatory obligations.

As a unit of MDOT, SHA manages thousands of miles of state highways and bridges. Highway construction and maintenance often involve dredging, filling, or waterway modifications that are subject to the wetlands and dam safety regulations modified by this bill.

DNR manages Maryland's public lands, state forests, and waterways. The bill's focus on water appropriation, dam safety, and wetlands restoration aligns with DNR's core mission to protect terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems and restore the Chesapeake Bay.

As a departmental bill, this reflects the Governor's executive policy. The Governor's Office oversees MDE and is responsible for the state's annual budget, which includes the general fund savings and special fund increases generated by this bill's enforcement provisions.

The bill establishes that administrative penalties can become liens on real and personal property when recorded with the Clerk of the Circuit Court. The AOC manages the judicial infrastructure and records systems necessary to facilitate these legal and financial proceedings.

The BPW oversees tidal wetlands licensing and the acquisition or sale of state property. The bill's focus on wetlands enforcement and the Maryland Clean Water Fund is relevant to the Board's role in safeguarding environmental infrastructure and fiscal integrity.

Maryland farmers are major users of water for irrigation and livestock. The bill's strengthened enforcement of water appropriation and use permits directly impacts the agricultural community and MDA's mission to protect natural resources within the industry.

MDP coordinates sustainable growth and resource conservation. The bill's enforcement changes for wetlands and waterway construction are relevant to MDP's role in implementing 'smart growth' strategies that balance economic development with environmental stewardship.

MES manages water and wastewater treatment plants and environmental restoration projects. As an entity that operates state environmental infrastructure, MES's operations are impacted by stricter enforcement and penalty structures for water quality and appropriation.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on environmental stewardship and reducing urban sprawl. The bill supports the initiative's goals by strengthening the regulatory framework intended to protect the state's water resources and wetlands from unlawful development.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller monitors state revenues. The bill increases special fund revenues for the Maryland Clean Water Fund and the Private Dam Repair Fund, which the Comptroller's office must track and report on.

The Treasurer's Office is the custodian of the state's financial assets and manages the investment of public funds, including the various special funds receiving increased penalty revenue under this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill repeals the requirement that a notarized bill of sale be submitted to the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration when transferring ownership of certain used vehicles in private transactions, particularly when the sale price is more than $500 below the retail value. This change is intended to streamline the vehicle transfer process and facilitate the Motor Vehicle Administration's transition to an electronic titling system.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents and businesses involved in the private-party sale or transfer of used vehicles.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local finances are not materially affected. The bill simplifies administrative procedures for the Motor Vehicle Administration and taxpayers without significantly impacting revenues or expenditures. Approximately 10,500 private sales per year that previously required a notarized bill of sale will be impacted.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) and the entity that requested this departmental bill, MDOT is directly responsible for the planning and implementation of the legislative change to modernize transportation network operations.

The bill directly amends the operational requirements for the MVA by repealing the notarized bill of sale requirement for used vehicle transfers to facilitate the agency's transition to an electronic titling system.

This is a departmental bill requested by the administration, and the Governor's Office is responsible for overseeing the legislative package and the modernization initiatives of the executive agencies.

As the state's chief financial officer and revenue watchdog, the Comptroller is relevant because the bill alters the verification process for fair market value, which is used to calculate vehicle excise tax revenue.

DBM oversees the state's fiscal accountability and revenue estimation; the bill affects excise tax verification, which has a potential, albeit minimal, impact on the state's financial reporting and revenue collection.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Transportation and the MVA, and would be responsible for ensuring the legislative repeal and subsequent regulations are legally sufficient.

The Secretary of State oversees the commission of notaries public. The bill's removal of a notarization requirement directly impacts the regulatory scope of one of the common use cases for notary services in Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment to adopt regulations requiring accredited lead paint abatement service providers—including contractors, supervisors, inspectors, and risk assessors—to be covered by a reasonable performance bond or liability insurance.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Accredited lead paint abatement service providers (contractors, supervisors, and inspectors), property owners, and tenants of pre-1978 residential buildings.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local finances. The Maryland Department of the Environment and the Maryland Insurance Administration can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. There may be a minimal increase in special fund revenues from civil and administrative penalties. Small businesses providing lead paint abatement services will likely experience increased costs due to mandatory insurance or bonding requirements, which may be passed on to consumers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulator for the Lead Poisoning Prevention Program, the Department of the Environment is responsible for adopting and enforcing the regulations authorized by this bill regarding performance bonds and liability insurance for lead abatement contractors.

The Maryland Insurance Administration regulates the insurance industry in the state and will be responsible for reviewing the rates and policies of the new insurance products developed to meet the requirements of this bill.
The OAG serves as legal counsel to the Department of the Environment and investigates criminal cases related to lead abatement fraud, which the bonding and insurance requirements aim to mitigate.
The Department of Health coordinates statewide lead poisoning prevention efforts and blood lead surveillance; the efficacy of lead abatement services directly impacts their public health mission.
The agency manages affordable housing and neighborhood revitalization; the bill's requirements protect property owners and tenants in the residential units overseen by the department.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies a meaningful economic impact on small businesses providing lead abatement services, a constituency supported by this office through advocacy and procurement guidance.

As the agency responsible for the maintenance and renovation of state-owned facilities, the department must ensure that lead abatement contractors hired for state projects comply with the new bonding and insurance requirements.

The OAH handles appeals for contested cases involving executive agencies, including potential disputes over lead paint abatement accreditation modifications or revocations resulting from these new regulations.

The IAC oversees public school renovations; since many schools contain lead-containing substances, the accreditation and bonding of contractors performing this work is relevant to school facility safety.
The Comptroller manages state revenues, including the Lead Accreditation Fund which receives accreditation fees and penalties related to lead abatement service violations.
DBM oversees the state budget and special fund revenues, including the fiscal impact on the Lead Accreditation Fund as noted in the fiscal analysis.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementing this departmental bill and has final authority over the signing of the legislation and approval of related regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the regulatory requirements for issuing heavy weight port corridor permits for vehicles transporting international freight from the Seagirt Marine Terminal. It removes the requirement that specific highways be designated by the Secretary of Transportation as part of a 'heavy weight port corridor' and instead mandates that regulations establish specific routes and authorized destinations for these vehicles.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation (Secretary of Transportation)
qa_results.stakeholders: Motor carriers and trucking companies transporting international freight in sealed seagoing containers, the Seagirt Marine Terminal, and the Maryland Department of Transportation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill updates the regulatory framework for heavy weight port corridor permits. As the provided text does not include the Fiscal Note, specific revenue and expenditure estimates are not available; however, the bill primarily concerns administrative adjustments to permit issuance and route designation.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary executive agency for Maryland's transportation network, the Secretary of Transportation is directly responsible for adopting regulations, establishing routes, and issuing the heavy weight port corridor permits modified by this bill.
The bill focuses on permits for transporting international freight from the Seagirt Marine Terminal, which is a major facility managed by the Maryland Port Administration.

SHA manages the state's numbered highways where these heavy weight vehicles operate. The bill's removal of the 'heavy weight port corridor' designation requirement and the creation of specific routes directly impacts SHA's infrastructure and route management.
The MVA regulates vehicle services and compliance; it is often the business unit within MDOT responsible for the administrative systems that issue vehicle permits and enforce motor vehicle laws.
The Maryland State Police is responsible for enforcing motor vehicle laws and highway safety, including the weight and axle requirements for heavy vehicles operating under these specific permits.
The MDTA operates toll facilities and maintains a dedicated police force that manages and secures primary heavy weight routes near the Port of Baltimore.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor for the Department of Transportation and will be involved in the drafting and legal review of the updated permit regulations.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies implementing these rules and is responsible for signing the legislation into law.
The bill facilitates the movement of international freight, which is a key component of the state's economic development and international trade strategies led by the Department of Commerce.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Supporting Inclusive Community Adaptation Act requires the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to facilitate community participation in project planning and establishes the Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund. This fund is designed to provide grants to state agencies, local governments, and nonprofits for nature-based projects that address climate change vulnerabilities. The bill also mandates DNR to create online tools and training for local jurisdictions, evaluate climate risks on state-owned lands, and updates the Shore Erosion Control Construction Loan Fund to allow for loan forgiveness and the retention of interest earnings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Local jurisdictions (counties and municipalities), nonprofit organizations, state agencies, property owners in coastal or flood-prone areas, and residents of communities vulnerable to climate change hazards like sea-level rise and extreme storms.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill establishes the Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund and allows the Shore Erosion Control Construction Loan Fund to retain its interest earnings, which would otherwise accrue to the General Fund. The bill prohibits General Fund appropriations for the new grant fund in fiscal year 2027. While it establishes a mechanism for grant distribution and loan forgiveness, specific appropriation amounts are not mandated in the text of the bill. Local governments may experience a positive fiscal impact through access to new grants and technical training.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is a departmental request from DNR, which is tasked with administering the new Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund, facilitating community participation, developing climate planning tools and websites, and assessing climate risks on DNR-managed lands.

The State Treasurer is required to hold and invest the money in the two new special funds established by the bill (Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund and Shore Erosion Control Construction Loan Fund) and ensure interest earnings are credited to the funds.

The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund and the Shore Erosion Control Construction Loan Fund as part of its fiscal watchdog and revenue management duties.

MDE leads state climate change initiatives and regulates water resources. The bill’s focus on nature-based restoration and climate resilience directly overlaps with MDE's mission to restore water resources and lead the state's climate response.

MDEM is the state authority for disaster preparedness and hazard mitigation. The bill's emphasis on projects to reduce climate vulnerability, such as flood mitigation and sea-level rise resilience, aligns with MDEM’s mission to minimize loss of life and property from hazards.

The bill requires DNR to provide training to local jurisdictions to incorporate climate adaptation into local comprehensive plans, a process typically overseen and supported by MDP's Planning Services and urban design functions.

The Trust is a primary grant-maker for nature-based restoration and community outreach in Maryland. The establishment of a new Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund for similar projects represents a significant development in the Trust's core policy area.

As a multi-agency initiative coordinating DNR, MDE, and MDP on sustainable growth and environmental stewardship, this legislation directly implements the initiative's core goals of balancing development with environmental resilience.
DBM oversees the state’s annual operating budget and will be involved in the allocation of funds to the new special funds and the management of administrative expenses authorized by the bill.

The bill requires the development of a user-friendly website as a central access point for mapping, datasets, and analytical models, which falls under DoIT’s mandate to coordinate IT strategic policy and digital government services.

The BPW reviews and approves major state expenditures and contracts. Projects funded by the new Resilience Through Restoration Capital Grant Fund or contractual agreements with local governments/nonprofits may require BPW oversight.
The OAG serves as legal counsel to DNR and would be responsible for reviewing the contractual agreements and grant frameworks established by the bill to ensure legal sufficiency.

The bill establishes significant new state policy regarding climate equity and community participation, which aligns with the Governor’s Coordinating Offices' mission to spearhead statewide initiatives and resolve community issues.

The Council advocates for the 18 rural counties of Maryland, many of which are coastal and significantly impacted by the sea-level rise and flooding issues addressed by the bill's grant funding and planning tools.

DGS manages state-owned facilities and construction projects. The bill's requirement for resilience projects on DNR lands (state parks and forests) may involve DGS's construction and infrastructure maintenance expertise.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the scope of the Pamela J. Kelly Tree-Mendous Maryland Program to include the advancement of forest health and resilience. It allows the program to promote and maintain native trees and shrubs on public lands, community open spaces, school grounds, and rights-of-way, in addition to the program's existing authority to plant trees and shrubs in these areas.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Public land managers, community organizations, schools, and Maryland residents interested in forest conservation and the maintenance of native plant species.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State finances or local government finances. It alters the purposes for which existing donated and granted funds may be used by the Department of Natural Resources, potentially affecting the timing of fund deployment without changing overall revenue or expenditure levels.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency administering the Pamela J. Kelly Tree-Mendous Maryland Program and the author of this departmental bill, DNR is the primary entity responsible for expanding the program's scope to include forest health, resilience, and the maintenance of native trees and shrubs.

The bill expands the program's purpose to include the promotion and maintenance of trees on rights-of-way, which are primarily managed and operated by the Department of Transportation and its business units.

The State Highway Administration is responsible for maintaining state-numbered highway rights-of-way, which are specifically designated as areas for native tree planting and maintenance under the program.
The program targets school grounds for the planting and maintenance of native trees and shrubs; the Department of Education oversees the state's public school system and its facilities.

DGS manages the maintenance and infrastructure of state-owned facilities and public lands, which are identified as key target areas for the program's expanded focus on forest maintenance and resilience.
The bill's focus on advancing forest health and resilience aligns with MDE's mission to protect and restore Maryland's natural resources and safeguard the environment.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Council coordinates state efforts to restore the Chesapeake Bay; forest health and the planting of native species are critical components of watershed protection and regional restoration goals.
The Trust provides grants for tree plantings and on-the-ground restoration; its mission and funding activities directly support the expanded goals of advancing forest health and native plantings.

This multi-agency initiative promotes environmental stewardship and sustainable growth, matching the bill's objectives of fostering forest resilience and maintaining native trees in public and community spaces.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Vulnerable Road User Protection Act of 2026 authorizes the State Highway Administration (SHA) to establish safety corridor speed monitoring systems in highway segments identified as high-risk for vulnerable road users, such as pedestrians and cyclists. The bill establishes a tiered civil penalty system based on the severity of the speeding violation, ranging from $40 to $425. It also allows local jurisdictions to operate these systems on State highways within their borders under a permit from the SHA.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Highway Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Motorists, pedestrians, bicyclists, individuals using wheelchairs or mobility devices, the Maryland Department of Transportation, and local law enforcement and transportation agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues increase from civil penalties collected via safety corridor speed monitoring systems. These revenues are first used to cover SHA's implementation and administrative costs, with the remainder distributed to the Transportation Trust Fund for highway safety and system preservation. State expenditures increase to implement and manage the program. Local jurisdictions may see increased revenues and expenditures if they choose to operate these systems under State permits.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly authorizes the State Highway Administration to implement and administer the safety corridor speed monitoring system program, identify high-risk areas for vulnerable road users, and manage the procurement of necessary technology.

As the parent department of the State Highway Administration and the Motor Vehicle Administration, MDOT oversees the comprehensive transportation network and manages the Transportation Trust Fund, which receives surplus revenue generated by the fines.

The MVA is responsible for enforcing the civil penalties by refusing or suspending vehicle registrations for non-payment and ensures these violations are not recorded on driving records per the bill's requirements.

The Maryland Judiciary, through the District Court, has exclusive original jurisdiction over these civil infractions. The AOC manages the court systems, uniform citation forms, and the processing of contested cases and fine collections.

The bill explicitly prohibits automobile insurers from using safety corridor civil penalties as a basis for reclassifying insureds or increasing premiums, requiring regulatory oversight by the MIA to ensure compliance.
The Comptroller is tasked with distributing the revenue collected from civil fines to a dedicated special fund for the State Highway Administration and the Transportation Trust Fund.
DBM oversees the state's fiscal accountability and will manage the budgetary impacts of the new special fund and the supplemental funding distributed to the State Highway Administration.

The MDTA manages toll facilities and already utilizes automated speed monitoring; the bill's updates to automated enforcement and safety corridor definitions may impact their operations and enforcement policies.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor for state agencies like MDOT and SHA and will be responsible for providing counsel on the implementation, regulatory standards, and legal defense of the automated enforcement program.
The Governor's Office oversees executive branch operations and this departmental bill reflects the administration's public safety priorities regarding vulnerable road users and infrastructure safety.

The MSP is involved in statewide traffic enforcement and highway safety; the bill specifies that automated citations are only applicable if a police officer does not issue a manual citation at the time of the violation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises the Governor on public safety policy and coordinates statewide initiatives to reduce traffic-related fatalities and enhance pedestrian safety.

The bill defines 'vulnerable road users' to include individuals using wheelchairs and mobility devices, aligning with the department's mission to ensure safe and accessible transportation for Marylanders with disabilities.
The Treasurer manages the state's financial assets and the Transportation Trust Fund, and sits on the Board of Public Works which would approve major contracts for speed monitoring technology.

Older adults are significantly impacted by pedestrian safety measures and are often vulnerable road users; the creation of safety corridors supports the department’s mission to foster safe communities for seniors.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to identify priority watersheds every five years, beginning in 2028. Local subdivisions with designated priority watersheds must conduct flood-related watershed studies to map inundation areas and assess potential impacts on infrastructure and roads under various flooding scenarios and sea-level rise projections. The bill clarifies that the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program can be used to fund these studies, sets a maximum annual budget authorization of $20 million for the program, and mandates that 40% of the program's funding benefit underserved or overburdened communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland subdivisions (counties and municipalities), residents of flood-prone areas, and underserved or overburdened communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill authorizes the Governor to include up to $20,000,000 annually in the State budget for the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program starting in FY 2026. Subdivisions are required to provide a minimum match of 25% for nonfederal capital project costs and at least 50% of the nonfederal share for federally funded projects. Starting in FY 2029, grants specifically for conducting flood-related watershed studies are capped at 5% of the program's total annual appropriation. The bill also requires at least 40% of program funds to benefit underserved or overburdened communities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of the Environment (MDE) is the primary agency responsible for implementing this bill. It is tasked with designating priority watersheds, developing guidelines for watershed studies, reviewing and approving studies and GIS maps submitted by subdivisions, and administering the comprehensive flood management grant program.

MDEM is specifically named as a consulting agency for designating priority watersheds and developing study guidelines. Furthermore, Section 2 of the bill mandates MDEM to lead an evaluation of natural hazard-specific plan requirements in coordination with other agencies and report recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly.

The Department of Planning is required to be consulted on the designation of priority watersheds and the development of study guidelines. Additionally, its State Clearinghouse is responsible for reviewing project applications for grants under the comprehensive flood management program.

The Department of Natural Resources is mandated to be consulted by MDE during the designation of priority watersheds and the creation of study guidelines. It also participates in the inter-agency evaluation of hazard-planning requirements led by MDEM.

The Department of Agriculture is specifically included in the list of agencies MDE must consult when designating priority watersheds and developing guidelines for subdivisions to conduct watershed studies.

The Board of Public Works must approve the Department of the Environment's use of State debt proceeds and the awarding of grants to subdivisions for watershed studies, capital projects, and property acquisitions under the comprehensive flood management grant program.

The bill authorizes the Governor to include up to $20 million annually in the State budget for the comprehensive flood management grant program. DBM is responsible for formulating the budget and overseeing these fiscal allocations.

As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller is responsible for reviewing and approving the grants and expenditures authorized under the comprehensive flood management grant program established by this bill.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the State Treasurer participates in the approval of grants and the use of State debt proceeds for the flood management initiatives outlined in the bill.

The Governor's Office is responsible for the overall execution of state law, including the potential inclusion of up to $20 million in the annual budget for the grant program. The bill also requires MDEM to report its hazard-planning recommendations directly to the Governor.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the standards and procedures for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program. Key changes include extending the local program comprehensive review cycle from 6 to 10 years, clarifying growth allocation standards by using the term 'contiguous and adjoining' instead of 'adjacent,' and specifying the dates used to determine mapping mistakes for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays. Additionally, the bill requires that damages assessed for illegal tree cutting in the Critical Area be paid to the local jurisdiction rather than the State and expands the list of professionals authorized to prepare tree replanting plans.
qa_results.responsible_party: Critical Area Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Local jurisdictions within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, property owners, developers, and qualified professionals such as foresters and landscape architects.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to have a direct impact on State or local finances. According to the Department of Natural Resources, the bill's provisions largely reflect current practices, including the disposition of damages for illegal tree cutting to local governments. Small businesses are expected to experience minimal or no economic impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency for the bill, as it houses the Critical Area Commission, which requested the legislation. The bill also involves the State Forester and shifts the payment of damages for tree clearing violations from the Department to local jurisdictions.
The bill explicitly references the Attorney General's role in bringing legal actions for violations of tree clearing regulations within the Critical Area.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth. The bill alters standards for growth allocation, mapping mistakes, and local program reviews, which are core planning and land use functions.

The bill's focus on water quality, habitat protection, and climate resiliency in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays aligns with the Maryland Department of the Environment's mission to protect water resources and lead climate initiatives.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the body that integrates the efforts of various departments to protect and restore the Chesapeake Bay, the Council is directly relevant to legislation that updates the standards for the Critical Area Protection Program.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable growth and land-use policies that preserve natural treasures like the Chesapeake Bay; the bill directly updates the regulatory framework for these efforts.

The bill specifies that circuit courts are responsible for assessing damages for illegal tree cutting, which the Administrative Office of the Courts supports through its management of the judicial infrastructure.

Transportation infrastructure projects in coastal areas are frequently subject to Critical Area standards. Updates to locational standards and program reviews can impact the planning and execution of transportation networks.

The Critical Area program includes resource conservation standards that affect agricultural land, particularly regarding nutrient runoff and the preservation of farmland mentioned in the bill's locational standards.
The bill's standards for growth allocation and intensely developed areas directly influence where and how housing can be built or expanded within the State's critical areas.

The Trust's mission involves restoration and environmental education for the Bay. Changes to the Critical Area Protection Program provide the regulatory backdrop for the restoration work funded by the Trust.
The bill includes specific growth allocation standards for several rural counties, directly impacting development policy in the rural jurisdictions the Council advocates for.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes several revisions to the regulation of financial institutions in Maryland and the administration of the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund. Key changes include extending the deadline for state-matched investments in the fund to June 30, 2030, expanding the fund's purpose to provide financial assistance to consumers in low-to-moderate income (LMI) areas, and creating new assessment offset credits for banks and credit unions that offer 'Maryland Opportunity Accounts.' Additionally, it adds cybersecurity incidents to the legal definition of an 'emergency' that warrants bank closures and repeals certain obsolete certification and filing fees.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of Financial Regulation (OFR) within the Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: State-chartered banking institutions, credit unions, and consumers and businesses located in low-to-moderate-income (LMI) census tracts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to decrease State special fund revenues by an estimated $25,000 in FY 2027, growing to at least $52,000 by FY 2031 due to the new assessment offset credits for financial institutions offering Maryland Opportunity Accounts. Special fund expenditures are projected to increase by approximately $14,000 in FY 2029 and FY 2030 due to the extension of the deadline for the Office of Financial Regulation to match private donations to the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund. Local government finances are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This is a departmental bill requested by the Department of Labor. The Office of Financial Regulation (OFR), a unit within the Department of Labor, is the primary regulator responsible for administering the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund, setting assessment offset credits for banking institutions and credit unions, and overseeing the regulation of financial entities under the bill.

The bill explicitly designates the State Treasurer as the custodian of the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund. The Treasurer is responsible for investing the money of the fund and ensuring interest earnings are credited appropriately.

The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the interest on all State money allocated by the State Treasurer to special funds. The bill adds the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund to the list of funds exempt from the general requirement that interest accrues to the General Fund.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the Commissioner of Financial Regulation. The fiscal note also mentions that the Securities Division of the OAG regulates the financial services industry alongside OFR.

The bill discusses the Governor's emergency powers to proclaim the closure of banking institutions, and specifically expands the definition of 'emergency' to include cybersecurity incidents that necessitate such closures.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM is involved in the budgetary oversight of the special funds affected by this bill, including the decrease in special fund revenues and increase in expenditures related to the MCIV Fund.

The bill introduces 'cybersecurity incident' as a legitimate 'emergency' reason for a banking institution to close. DoIT is responsible for the state's cybersecurity policy and may be involved in the technical standards or response definitions relevant to this provision.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes the earliest date that candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor who participate in the gubernatorial public campaign financing program can receive distributions from the Fair Campaign Financing Fund. The bill moves the earliest distribution date from January 1 of the election year to July 1 of the year before the election.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and the Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor participating in the gubernatorial public campaign financing program.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local finances. It alters the timing of when public matching funds are distributed to qualifying candidates but does not change the total amount of funding available or the revenue sources of the Fair Campaign Financing Fund.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This is a departmental bill requested by the State Board of Elections, which is the primary agency responsible for managing the gubernatorial public financing program and authorizing all fund distributions.

The Comptroller's Office is responsible for administering the Fair Campaign Financing Fund and is legally mandated to make distributions from the fund promptly upon authorization by the State Board of Elections.
The bill directly alters the timing of public funds available to candidates seeking the office of Governor, which is the principal executive agency of the state.
The bill directly affects the distribution of public financing to the gubernatorial ticket, which includes candidates for the office of Lieutenant Governor.
The Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to the State Board of Elections and would oversee any legal interpretations or disputes regarding the timing of campaign fund distributions.
The Treasurer is the principal custodian of all public funds, including the Fair Campaign Financing Fund, and oversees the state's banking services used for these distributions.
As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the budget process, including the mandated appropriations required by the Maryland Fair Elections Act for the Fair Campaign Financing Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes competitive proof of concept (POC) procurements as an authorized method for Maryland State agencies to solicit and evaluate goods, services, or technology. It allows for a multi-phase procurement process that includes testing, evaluation, or pilot projects and can transition directly into full implementation or deployment without a separate solicitation. The bill requires oversight and approval from the Chief Procurement Officer or the Secretary of Information Technology and mandates that such procurements be posted on eMaryland Marketplace Advantage.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of General Services and Department of Information Technology
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State government agencies, private vendors, small businesses, minority business enterprises (MBEs), and veteran-owned small business enterprises (VSBEs).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no material impact on State or local finances. It is expected to create operational efficiencies for agencies that utilize the proof of concept method. There are no estimated changes to State revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary requester of this departmental bill, DGS (housing the Chief Procurement Officer) is responsible for providing approvals for most competitive proof of concept procurements and is mandated to adopt the necessary regulations and policies.

The bill requires units to obtain approval from the Secretary of Information Technology before conducting any IT-related proof of concept procurement and mandates DoIT's consultation in the development of regulations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Special Secretary of this office is responsible for establishing MBE participation guidelines for these procurements and has the authority to exempt them from Small Business Reserve (SBR) designations.
The OAG is specifically required to be consulted by the Special Secretary when establishing MBE guidelines for this new procurement method and acts as the primary legal advisor on procurement law.
The Secretary of Transportation is a required consultant for establishing the MBE participation guidelines for competitive proof of concept procurements.

The BPW oversees and approves significant state procurement contracts; as this bill allows for full implementation and deployment awards following a proof of concept, resulting large-scale contracts would fall under their review.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the agencies implementing this procurement reform and manages the Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller will be responsible for reviewing and approving major state contracts awarded through this new procurement process.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Treasurer will review and approve significant state expenditures and contracts resulting from the competitive proof of concept method.
As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the efficiency of state operations and the allocation of funds that may be utilized for these new procurement methods.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the Council on Open Data to the Council for Open Data and significantly reduces its membership from 37 to 11 members. It establishes the State Chief Data Officer as the chair of the council, modifies the definition of 'data' to include non-final statistical or factual information, and expands the council's duties to include advising on data initiatives and building partnerships to connect Maryland data with communities and social service organizations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Information Technology
qa_results.stakeholders: State government agencies, local government entities, the State Chief Data Officer, and representatives from the private, academic, and nonprofit sectors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's requirements are expected to be handled using existing budgeted resources, resulting in no additional impact on state expenditures or revenues. Local government operations and finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for state IT policy, DoIT requested this bill and serves as the lead implementing agency. The Council's Chair is changed to the State Chief Data Officer, and DoIT remains responsible for staffing the Council.
The bill significantly impacts GOPI by removing its Director as the Vice Chair of the Council and eliminating the statutory requirement for GOPI to share staffing responsibilities for the Council.

The Council for Open Data is an executive body that reports to the Governor. The Governor is responsible for appointing the local and private-sector members and has the authority to designate staff for the Council.

The Secretary of Human Services is removed from the Council’s membership. However, the bill expands the Council's mission to specifically include connecting data with social service organizations, which is central to DHS's operations.

The Secretary of Health is removed from the Council’s membership. However, the bill expands the Council's mission to include connecting data with social service organizations, which aligns with MDH's healthcare and public health missions.

The State Archivist is removed from the statutory membership of the Council, which impacts the agency's role in providing guidance on data preservation and sound records management within the state's open data framework.
The bill specifically tasks the Council with inviting and encouraging the judicial branch to utilize state open data portals and adopt policies consistent with the State's open data standards.
The Secretary of Agriculture is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of the Environment is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Natural Resources is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Planning is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Transportation is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Commerce is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of General Services is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The State Superintendent of Schools is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of State Police is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Budget and Management is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Adjutant General is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Emergency Management is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Secretary of Labor is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.
The Governor’s Homeland Security Advisor is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Executive Director of MIEMSS is removed from the statutory membership of the Council as part of a reduction in total members from 37 to 11.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires buses on fixed local routes funded by a county or municipality to allow passengers to board and exit at the entrance of early voting centers if the center is located within one-half mile of the route. This requirement applies during the days and hours that early voting centers are open. The bill exempts express or commuter bus routes, the Maryland Transit Administration, and the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Elections and local governments or municipal corporations operating transit services
qa_results.stakeholders: Registered voters in Maryland, particularly those utilizing public transportation, and local government transit agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State finances. Local government expenditures are expected to increase starting in FY 2028 due to additional bus operating mileage, public communication of route changes, and temporary site improvements for accessibility. Prince George's County estimated an expenditure increase of at least $37,300 in FY 2028. Some costs may be partially offset by increased bus fare revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Elections is the primary agency for this departmental bill, responsible for managing early voting centers and informing the public about their locations and accessibility.

The bill explicitly requires bus stop deviations to be consistent with accessibility requirements; the MDOD is the lead agency in ensuring equal access and independence for Marylanders with disabilities regarding transportation and public services.
The Maryland Department of Aging advocates for older adults, who are a significant demographic utilizing public transportation to access essential community resources such as early voting centers.

While state-run MTA routes are excluded, MDOT manages the state's comprehensive transportation strategy and coordinates with the local jurisdictions whose transit systems are mandated to implement route deviations under this bill.

As the chief legal advisor to the State Board of Elections and nearly all executive departments, the OAG will interpret the requirements of the bill and provide legal guidance on compliance and implementation.
The Governor's Office oversees the State Board of Elections and the departmental legislative agenda, and is responsible for the final signing or vetoing of the legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Data Privacy and Protection Act of 2026 establishes standards for the collection, maintenance, and retention of personal information by Maryland State government units, requiring that such data be limited to the minimum necessary for legitimate purposes and deleted or de-identified when no longer needed. It mandates that State units designate Privacy Officers and post online privacy notices, while tasking the Department of Information Technology (DoIT) with setting privacy standards for third-party IT contracts. Additionally, the bill requires State and local government entities to implement procedures to prevent the unauthorized sale or redisclosure of sensitive personal and geolocation data.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Information Technology (DoIT), individual units of State government, and local government entities.
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents, State and local government units and agencies, and third-party IT contractors.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary department behind the bill, DoIT is tasked with establishing guidelines, standards, and policies for privacy notices, adopting regulations and model templates, and defining security and privacy requirements for State contracts.

All State units and instrumentalities that keep personal records must submit an annual report to the Secretary of General Services, who is also responsible for adopting regulations governing the reporting process.

The Secretary of Budget and Management is responsible for adopting regulations to exempt specific personal records from certain transparency requirements, based on recommendations from the Secretary of Information Technology.

The bill requires each unit of State government to designate a Privacy Officer to coordinate with the Department of Information Technology and the Office of the Attorney General to ensure legal compliance with data privacy standards.

The MVA is a primary source of the personal information elements expanded in the bill, such as driver's license numbers and state identification card numbers, and must comply with new collection, retention, and notice standards.

The bill expands the definition of 'personal information' to specifically include genetic and health-related data, including mental health, substance use disorder, and disability data, which are core data sets managed by MDH.

The MLDS Center's primary mission involves collecting and linking individual-level student and workforce records. The bill’s new requirements for data de-identification, limited retention, and expanded personal information definitions directly impact their core operations.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the implementation of this departmental legislation across all executive agencies and ensures units appoint required Privacy Officers.

DHS manages significant volumes of personal records for over one million residents, including sensitive economic assistance and protective services data, making the new collection and retention limits highly impactful.

The Comptroller handles sensitive individual and corporate tax data as well as central payroll for all state employees, all of which fall under the bill's expanded data protection and reporting requirements.

The bill explicitly exempts information contained in public records accepted by the State Archivist for deposit from certain request and notice requirements, making the agency a critical repository for exempt data.

The Treasurer's Office manages financial assets and banking services involving personal information and oversees Maryland 529, necessitating compliance with new privacy officer and contract security mandates.
MHEC collects extensive personal data for financial aid, scholarships, and student records, which will be subject to the bill's requirements for limited retention and secure deletion.

MHBE manages highly sensitive health and financial data for state residents. The bill's updated definitions and contract requirements for third-party data processors will impact their operations and vendor agreements.

The department administers unemployment insurance and professional licensing, both of which involve significant personal data. Licensing materials are specifically noted in the exemptions section of the bill.

As a large state instrumentality, USM and its member universities must comply with privacy officer designations, website privacy notices, and annual reporting to DGS regarding personal records of students and staff.

MSDE oversees vast student records and child care provider data. The bill's standards for minimum data collection and the legitimate government purpose requirement will apply to their information management systems.

While information concerning criminal law enforcement and the penal system is exempt from certain notice requirements, MSP remains a state unit that must comply with the bill's general administrative data privacy standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland State Board of Elections to designate a specific contact person for the Address Confidentiality Program to handle inquiries from program participants and local boards of elections. It also clarifies that local boards must use a participant's actual address for absentee ballot purposes and authorizes the State Board of Elections to adopt related regulations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, stalking, harassment, or human trafficking who participate in the Address Confidentiality Program, and local boards of elections.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Board of Elections can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources, resulting in no impact on state revenues or expenditures. There is no anticipated material effect on local government finances or small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates that the State Board of Elections designate a contact person for the Address Confidentiality Program and authorizes the Board to adopt regulations to implement the program's requirements for election-related purposes.

The Secretary of State is the agency responsible for administering the Address Confidentiality Program. This departmental bill was requested by the Secretary of State to improve interagency coordination regarding the program's use in elections.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Secretary of Information Technology to use revenues from resource sharing agreements within the Information Technology Investment Fund to support State-owned communication sites, facilities, and telecommunications equipment, including program management for these activities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Information Technology
qa_results.stakeholders: Department of Information Technology, Maryland state agencies, and private telecommunications companies participating in resource sharing agreements.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill expands the authorized use of resource sharing agreement (RSA) revenues within the Information Technology Investment Fund but does not change overall State revenues or expenditures. RSA revenues, which totaled $738,247 in fiscal 2024, may now be redistributed to support the infrastructure and program management linked to those agreements at the discretion of the Secretary.
