agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill authorizes funding for perimeter fence system replacements and other security upgrades at various state correctional institutions.

The bill authorizes over $50 million for the Community College Construction Grant Program and includes additional funding for the Facilities Renewal Grant Program, both administered by the Commission.
The bill provides extensive funding for the Community College Construction Grant Program and facilities renewal projects which are coordinated by the Commission.
The bill provides capital funding for the construction of new student residences and support facilities on the school's campuses.

The bill authorizes hundreds of millions in capital funding for major construction, renovation, and infrastructure projects across numerous USM campuses, including UMB, UMCP, Bowie State, Towson, Salisbury, and UMBC.
The bill provides over $140 million in capital funding for campus electrical infrastructure upgrades and the construction of a new science center.
The bill authorizes capital funding for campus infrastructure improvements and the renovation of Montgomery Hall.
The bill provides major capital funding for neighborhood revitalization, business development, homeownership, and rental housing programs managed by DHCD.
The bill authorizes $3 million for the Maryland Arts Capital Grant Program to assist arts organizations with facility acquisition and expansion.
The bill provides significant funding for wastewater treatment upgrades, flood management, water quality improvement projects, and the Drinking Water Revolving Loan Fund.
The bill authorizes funding for the State Water and Sewer Infrastructure Improvement Fund, which supports facility improvements for state institutions managed by MES.
The bill provides capital funding for the design of the New Cheltenham Youth Treatment Center and alters prior year authorizations for youth detention facilities.
The bill authorizes capital funding for the design and construction of new barracks and garages at the Waterloo, Annapolis, and Forestville locations.
MSDE is involved in the administration of aging school grants and the Public Library Capital Grant Program funded by the bill.
The bill provides $12.7 million for the Public Library Capital Grant Program and involves the agency in the administration of these facility grants.
The bill alters and extends the termination dates for grants under the Senior Centers Capital Grant Program from prior bond loans.
The bill reduces a prior capital authorization for the renovation and expansion of Studio A at MPT.
The bill provides a capital grant for the Banneker-Douglass-Tubman Museum, an entity overseen by commissions within this office.

The bill alters prior year capital authorizations by removing funding previously intended for the construction of a new State Veterans Home in Sykesville and funding water plant upgrades at Charlotte Hall.
The bill provides capital funding for the restoration of and improvements to the exterior and grounds of the Maryland State House and Old Treasury building.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Budget Reconciliation and Financing Act of 2026 adjusts the Maryland state budget by authorizing the transfer of approximately $716 million from various special funds to the General Fund, altering mandated appropriations for programs such as tobacco use reduction and community supports, and modifying funding formulas for community colleges and private nonprofit higher education institutions. The bill also shifts financial responsibility for a portion of teacher retirement costs and assisted outpatient treatment programs to county governments and modifies state income tax provisions regarding depreciation deductions for manufacturing entities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland county governments, community colleges, private colleges and universities, manufacturing businesses, and state residents receiving health and education services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The act significantly increases state General Fund revenues through approximately $716.6 million in transfers from special funds (including the Strategic Energy Investment Fund and Bay Restoration Fund) and approximately $137 million in new annual revenues from increased county contributions toward teacher retirement. State expenditures are reduced by capping growth in the Senator John A. Cade Funding Formula and lowering mandates for various grant programs. Local governments face increased annual expenditures due to the higher teacher retirement cost-sharing and new requirements to reimburse the state for assisted outpatient treatment programs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As an Administration request, this bill is the Governor's primary vehicle for reconciling the annual state budget and financing statutory requirements. It includes mandates for the Governor to publish budget books online and manage the State's fiscal stabilization.

The Comptroller is specifically required to pay quarterly grants to counties, manage distributions from the Local Reserve Account to the General Fund, and administer tax law changes regarding depreciation for manufacturing entities.

The bill affects various state trust funds, debt service calculations for General Obligation bonds used to replace special fund allocations, and manages transfers between the General Fund and dedicated accounts where the Treasurer serves as custodian.
The bill alters mandated appropriations for the Maryland Healthy Soils Program, the Maryland Native Plants Program, and the Urban Agriculture Water and Power Infrastructure Grant Fund.

As the central fiscal authority, DBM is responsible for formulating the budget adjustments, overseeing the Revenue Stabilization Account, and managing the various fund transfers and supplemental appropriations mandated in the act.
The bill impacts commerce-related funds including the Cannabis Business Assistance Fund and mentions the Department of Social and Economic Mobility.

The bill impacts various MSDE programs including the Lacrosse Opportunities Program, the Coordinated Community Supports Partnership Fund, and Driver Education in Public High Schools. It also relates to funding for the Interagency Commission on School Construction.
The bill authorizes the 9-1-1 Trust Fund to support MDEM program operations and allocates Strategic Energy Investment Fund proceeds to MDEM for resiliency efforts.
The bill provides funding for the Air and Radiation Administration from the Strategic Energy Investment Fund and authorizes significant transfers from the Bay Restoration Fund.

The bill significantly impacts MDH through funding changes for tobacco use reduction, the Advance Directive Program, maternal and child health quality initiatives, and county reimbursements for assisted outpatient treatment programs.
The bill specifically alters the authorized use of funds for the Alfred D. Noyes Children’s Center to provide drug treatment services at other facilities or reopen it for children.

The bill alters funding for the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program and the Career Pathways for Health Care Workers Program, and requires the Department to reimburse the Local Reserve Account for paid leave expenses.
The bill impacts Program Open Space (POS), the Waterway Improvement Fund, the Rural Legacy Program, and the Natural Resources Police, including salary and operational funding.
The bill allocates funding for the operation of Jefferson Patterson Park and Museum and allows for the distribution of noncapital historic preservation grants through the Maryland Historical Trust.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill impacts funding and eligibility for scholarship and loan repayment programs specifically for police officers and probation agents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Service and Civic Innovation
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill alters the participation targets for the Young Adult Service Year Option Pathway within the Maryland Corps Program.

The bill impacts MDOT through the use of the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund, the establishment of right-of-way frameworks for transmission infrastructure, and MVA penalty distributions.
MHEC is responsible for calculating and administering the Sellinger Program, the Cade Funding Formula for community colleges, and various scholarship programs impacted by the bill.
The bill provides funding for the Aviation Command through the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund and mentions the State Police Gun Center.
The bill authorizes the IAC to reallocate federal funding for school HVAC upgrades to ensure compliance with the American Rescue Plan Act.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill alters mandated General Fund appropriations to MARBIDCO for rural business loans and the Next Generation Farmland Acquisition Program.
The bill alters the distribution of uninsured motorist penalty fees collected by the MVA to the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund.
The bill significantly alters the use and distribution of the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF) which MEA manages, including clean energy gap financing.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS is a primary recipient and user of the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF) impacted by the bill.
The bill modifies the required amounts county governments must pay toward the retirement costs for local employees (Teachers) within the state pension system.
The bill affects funding via the Cigarette Restitution Fund and higher education research grants for which Morgan State is eligible.
The MVA is responsible for assessing penalties for vehicle security lapses and managing the associated fund distributions affected by the bill.
The bill specifically requires the Office of Legislative Audits to audit expenditures made for the Career Pathways for Health Care Workers Program.
The USM is impacted by higher education research grants and adjustments to the Joseph A. Sellinger and Cade funding formulas.
The Commission is a designated recipient of recreation and open space funds via the Program Open Space distribution formula altered by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires certain health insurance carriers, including insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations that provide coverage for chemotherapy, to also cover scalp cooling systems used to prevent or reduce hair loss during cancer treatment.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy, health insurance carriers, and the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues for the Maryland Insurance Administration increase minimally in FY 2027 due to $125 rate and form filing fees. State expenditures for the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program are estimated to increase between $11,600 and $302,800 annually beginning in FY 2027. Local governments with fully insured health plans may also experience increased expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulator of Maryland's insurance industry, the MIA is responsible for implementing the mandate, reviewing rate and form filings from insurance carriers to ensure compliance with the new requirement, and handling consumer complaints related to the coverage of scalp cooling systems.

DBM manages the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. The fiscal note identifies a notable increase in state expenditures (ranging from $11,600 to over $300,000) because the program typically covers mandated benefits even when largely self-insured.

The bill explicitly includes 'managed care organizations' (MCOs) among the entities required to provide coverage. The Maryland Department of Health oversees the state's Medicaid program and the MCOs that provide health services to its members.

MHBE administers Maryland Health Connection, the state's insurance marketplace. While the fiscal note indicates the bill currently targets large group and grandfathered plans, any new state mandate influences the broader regulatory landscape and standard health benefits for plans managed through the exchange.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the MIA, DBM, and the Department of Health. It would be responsible for providing legal counsel regarding the enforcement of the new mandate and representing the state in any associated litigation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires county boards of education to identify and report on safe alternative routes, such as sidewalks and bike paths, for public school students who are ineligible for transportation due to their proximity to school. County governing bodies are required to review these reports and construct the necessary sidewalks and crosswalks to create safe travel routes for students.
qa_results.responsible_party: County boards of education and county governing bodies
qa_results.stakeholders: Public school students living in areas without school bus service, county boards of education, and county governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill creates a mandate for county governments to construct infrastructure including sidewalks and crosswalks, which will result in significant local expenditures. County boards of education will also incur administrative costs to prepare annual reports identifying safe alternative routes.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires each county board of education to prepare and post annual reports identifying areas where students are ineligible for transportation and pathways they can use to travel safely. As the primary agency overseeing the state's K-12 system, MSDE is responsible for the policy and standards governing these boards.

The bill specifically requires counties to develop plans with the governmental entity that has control over non-county roads (typically the SHA for state-numbered roads) to construct sidewalks and crosswalks necessary for safe student routes.

As the parent agency of the State Highway Administration, MDOT oversees state-wide multi-modal transportation network planning and safety, including the pedestrian and bike infrastructure (sidewalks and crosswalks) mandated by this bill.

The agency is dedicated to fostering safe environments for K-12 students. This bill's focus on creating 'safe alternative routes' for students traveling to and from school falls directly within their mission of improving student safety and infrastructure.

The IAC oversees and funds the construction and maintenance of public school facilities and sites. The requirement to construct new sidewalks and crosswalks near schools could impact school site plans and potential capital improvement funding overseen by the Commission.

DBM oversees the state budget and estimates the fiscal impact of legislation. This bill imposes a significant construction and reporting mandate on local governments, which could have downstream effects on state education and transportation funding allocations.

The agency coordinates land use and sustainable growth. The development of safe pedestrian and bike pathways near schools aligns with the 'smart growth' and urban design strategies promoted by the Department of Planning.

The GOC leads a whole-of-government approach to child well-being. Improving safe access to schools is a core component of child welfare and family support, matching the agency's mission to address community-specific needs for children.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation and overseeing the operations of the executive departments (MSDE, MDOT, etc.) that will coordinate the implementation of these safe route reports and plans.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the state agencies involved, including the Department of Education and the Department of Transportation, and would handle any legal issues arising from the implementation of the new construction requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement that a person must obtain a concentrated animal feeding operation (CAFO) general discharge permit from the Maryland Department of the Environment before beginning construction on any part of a new CAFO.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and operators of concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) and the Maryland Department of the Environment

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Environment Article regarding water pollution control and discharge permits. The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) is the primary agency responsible for issuing CAFO discharge permits and enforcing water quality standards.

CAFOs are large-scale agricultural operations. The MDA regulates agricultural resource conservation and nutrient management, which are closely tied to the environmental impact of CAFOs and their permitting processes.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As a coordinating body for Bay restoration, the Council integrates the efforts of MDE and MDA. Permitting requirements for CAFOs are critical to achieving water quality goals and managing nutrient runoff into the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
CAFOs are major economic drivers in rural Maryland, particularly on the Eastern Shore. The bill affects the regulatory and construction timeline for agricultural businesses in these communities.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of the Environment. Any changes to permitting requirements or enforcement under the Environment Article require legal oversight and counsel from this office.
The Governor's Office oversees the Department of the Environment and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. As an emergency bill, it requires immediate executive action upon passage.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO provides financing and loans to farmers. Changes in the permitting timeline for construction of CAFOs may impact the timing and approval of agricultural infrastructure loans for new operations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires operators of residential child care programs to provide specific educational supports to children in their care, including homework assistance, study time, and computer access for dually enrolled students. It also mandates that child and youth care practitioners complete a comprehensive training program covering topics such as child development, special needs, suicide risk assessment, and medication management.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health, Department of Human Services, and Department of Juvenile Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Children in residential child care programs, program operators, and child and youth care practitioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill imposes new mandates on residential child care programs and practitioners, which likely increases administrative and oversight responsibilities for the Departments of Health, Human Services, and Juvenile Services, as well as operational costs for private providers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DHS is a primary licensing and oversight agency for residential child care programs. The bill amends the Human Services Article to require that DHS contracts with providers ensure compliance with educational standards and practitioner certification requirements.

MDH is one of the primary agencies that licenses residential child care programs. Additionally, the bill amends the Health Occupations Article to establish mandatory training topics for the Board of Residential Child Care Program Professionals, which is located within MDH.

DJS is a primary licensing agency for residential child care programs, particularly those serving youth in the juvenile justice system. The bill's requirements for educational support and staff training directly impact DJS operations and facility oversight.

The bill directly amends Section 7–309 of the Education Article, establishing new requirements for student enrollment, academic record transfers, teacher-program coordination, and educational supports (homework help, study time) for children in residential care.

The Governor's Office for Children leads the state's efforts to improve child well-being and coordinates a whole-of-government approach to issues like childhood poverty and access to healthcare, aligning with the bill's focus on educational and developmental outcomes for vulnerable youth.

The bill specifically addresses educational goals and supports for children with Individualized Education Programs (IEPs) and 504 plans within residential child care settings, requiring these programs to reinforce goals consistent with the children's special needs.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to DHS, MDH, and DJS. It would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the implementation of new training standards and the enforcement of the bill's requirements through state contracts and regulations.

DBM oversees state agency budgets and manages fiscal accountability. The bill refers to state-funded programs and introduces new training mandates that may have fiscal impacts on the budgets of the licensing and placement agencies.

OLA conducts fiscal and performance audits of executive agencies. It would be responsible for auditing DHS, MDH, and DJS to verify that these agencies are correctly enforcing the bill's educational and practitioner training requirements for providers.

OAH adjudicates contested cases from state agencies. It would likely preside over appeals from individuals denied practitioner certification or from programs facing licensing actions for failure to comply with the new educational and training standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes individuals convicted of failure to obey a court order to report to a place of confinement (specifically a violation of § 9–405(a)(2) of the Criminal Law Article) to petition for the expungement of associated police and court records. It further establishes that a petition for expungement for this specific offense may not be filed until at least 15 years after the completion of the sentence.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Maryland Judiciary and State law enforcement agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals convicted of failing to obey a court order to report to confinement and the Maryland court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's fiscal impact is not detailed in the provided text, though it would likely involve administrative costs for the Judiciary to process new expungement petitions and potential minor revenue from filing fees.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts judicial operations by authorizing new types of petitions for expungement of court records. The AOC manages the court record systems and the Case Search portal, which must be updated to comply with expungement orders for this new category of offense.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), the central repository for criminal records in Maryland. This bill adds a new category of conviction eligible for expungement, requiring DPSCS to process and implement expungement orders to remove relevant entries from CJIS records.

As a primary law enforcement agency that maintains police records and conducts background checks, the Maryland State Police are directly affected by changes to expungement eligibility, as they must comply with court orders to expunge records related to this specific offense.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Public Defender provides legal representation to indigent residents. This bill creates a new legal avenue for their clients to seek expungement for a specific misdemeanor conviction, likely increasing the agency's workload for expungement petitions and related legal services.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies and handles criminal appeals. They may be involved in representing the state in cases where an expungement petition is contested or in providing legal guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the new expungement requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the state’s central hub for criminal justice policy. Since this bill modifies criminal procedure and records management policies, it falls within their scope of advising the Governor on public safety and justice strategies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits state and local government agencies from using persistent aerial surveillance—defined as using aircraft to record video or images that track a person's actions over time—to gather evidence for criminal investigations. Exceptions are allowed for search warrants, arrest warrants, fresh pursuit of suspects, search and rescue, locating escaped prisoners, preventing imminent harm, or countering terrorist threats.
qa_results.responsible_party: State and local government units and agencies (including law enforcement)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland law enforcement agencies, state and local government units, and individuals subject to surveillance or criminal investigations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The fiscal note is not included in the provided text; however, the bill imposes legal restrictions on the use of aerial surveillance technology by state and local agencies for criminal investigations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary law enforcement agency with a dedicated Aviation Command, the MSP is the principal entity affected by restrictions on persistent aerial surveillance during criminal investigations and is responsible for many of the exempt activities like search and rescue.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor to state law enforcement and would be responsible for interpreting the new restrictions, advising agencies on compliance, and managing litigation related to the use of surveillance evidence.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is responsible for managing correctional facilities and would utilize aerial surveillance under the bill's specific exception for locating escaped prisoners, as well as in other parole and probation investigations.
MDOT oversees several business units involved in aviation and infrastructure security, and the bill explicitly relies on definitions within the Transportation Article managed by this department.
The Natural Resources Police use aerial assets for law enforcement, environmental protection, and search and rescue operations, all of which are impacted by the bill's restrictions and exceptions.

The MDTA Police use aerial surveillance to protect and monitor major infrastructure like bridges and tunnels, making the bill's restrictions on surveillance highly relevant to their security operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD represents indigent defendants and would likely use the bill's provisions to challenge the admissibility of evidence obtained through persistent aerial surveillance in criminal cases.

As the agency that fosters and regulates aviation activity in the state and manages Martin State Airport (where police aviation units are often based), the MAA is directly relevant to the definition and regulation of aircraft used for surveillance.

The bill includes a specific exception for surveillance necessitated by credible intelligence of a terrorist attack, which falls directly under this office's mission to coordinate counter-terrorism strategies.
MDEM coordinates search and rescue operations, which are specifically exempted from the bill's prohibition on persistent aerial surveillance.
The Maryland National Guard provides aerial support and situational awareness during state domestic emergencies and search and rescue missions, both of which are exceptions mentioned in the bill.
The bill requires a valid search warrant issued by a judge for persistent aerial surveillance in criminal investigations, which impacts judicial procedures and court administrative oversight.

The Governor's Office oversees all executive agencies involved in law enforcement and public safety, and would be responsible for signing or vetoing the legislation and ensuring its enforcement across departments.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises on criminal justice policy and grants; it may be involved in funding or developing strategies regarding the use of aerial surveillance technology by law enforcement.
The OSP investigates and prosecutes crimes affecting government integrity and multi-jurisdictional offenses where aerial surveillance could potentially be used as an investigative tool.
The bill addresses persistent surveillance which has significant implications for individual privacy and civil liberties, areas of interest for the commission's advocacy and oversight work.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS coordinates medevac and emergency communications that often utilize the same state aircraft (specifically those operated by MSP) affected by aviation-related regulations.
The MTA Police provide security for transit systems and may utilize aerial surveillance for large-scale security monitoring or criminal investigations.

SHA uses traffic monitoring and situational awareness tools on state highways, and while the bill focuses on criminal investigations, it impacts the overall regulatory environment for aerial assets on Maryland roads.
The MPA manages maritime facilities that require high levels of security and surveillance, which may be impacted by state-wide rules governing aerial surveillance assets.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the deadline for the State Retirement Agency to submit a report on the findings and recommendations of a workgroup studying the transfer of member service between State and local retirement and pension systems. It changes the report deadline from December 1, 2025, to October 1, 2026, and extends the workgroup's termination date to June 30, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Retirement Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of State and local retirement and pension systems who transfer service between systems
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact. Extending the reporting and termination dates for the workgroup does not affect governmental operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency (SRA) is the primary agency responsible for the bill's implementation. The bill specifically mandates that SRA convene the workgroup, manage its research into member service transfers, and provides the agency with a revised deadline for submitting its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's primary subject is the extension of a specialized workgroup convened by the State Retirement Agency. This workgroup falls under the classification of state study groups and task forces authorized by the General Assembly to address specific policy issues—in this case, the process of transferring retirement service credits between systems.

The Governor's Office is the executive entity responsible for overseeing all state agencies and is a designated recipient of the workgroup's final report on pension service transfers, as specified in the bill's reporting requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill converts the existing Biotechnology Investment Incentive Tax Credit into the Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program. Managed by the Department of Commerce, the program provides direct grants to qualified investors who invest in early-stage Maryland biotechnology companies, rather than requiring them to claim credits on their tax returns. The bill establishes the Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program Fund to facilitate these payments and provides a subtraction modification so that the grants are not subject to Maryland income tax.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Qualified investors and early-stage biotechnology companies in Maryland with fewer than 50 employees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates an annual General Fund appropriation of $10,000,000 to the Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program Fund. This replaces the previous tax credit system, shifting the fiscal impact from a reduction in revenue to a direct expenditure. Additionally, the bill creates a subtraction modification for grants received, which will result in a decrease in State and local income tax revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Department of Commerce as the primary agency responsible for administering the newly converted Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program, including approving applications, issuing certificates, and disbursing grants.

The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the new Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program Fund and administering the new income tax subtraction modifications for grants received under the program.

The bill mandates that the Governor include a $10,000,000 annual appropriation for the Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program Fund in the State budget, directly impacting the fiscal planning and budget formulation duties of DBM.
The State Treasurer is explicitly tasked with holding the new Biotechnology Investment Incentive Grant Program Fund and investing its money in the same manner as other State funds.
The bill requires the Governor to include a specific $10,000,000 appropriation in the annual budget bill and involves changes to executive branch economic development policy.

As the legal advisor to state agencies, the OAG would be involved in overseeing the regulatory transition from a tax credit to a grant program and drafting the required regulations for the Department of Commerce.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Prince George’s County to implement speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 5. It requires the county to install signage and real-time speed displays at these locations. Fine revenue collected, after deducting implementation and administrative costs, must be remitted to the Comptroller for distribution to the State Highway Administration to fund highway and pedestrian safety improvements on or near Maryland Route 5.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George's County and the Maryland State Highway Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Motorists traveling on Maryland Route 5 in Prince George's County, pedestrians, and local residents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Prince George's County will experience an increase in fine revenue from speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 5. After recovering the costs of implementing and administering the systems, the county must remit the remaining balance to the State. These funds are then distributed to the State Highway Administration to be used specifically for safety improvements on and in the vicinity of Maryland Route 5 in Prince George’s County, resulting in an increase in both revenue and expenditures related to local and state transportation safety projects.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly designates the State Highway Administration (SHA) as the recipient of net fine revenue from speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 5. The agency is responsible for using these funds for highway and pedestrian safety improvements on or near that route and must ensure compliance with signage and traffic control standards.

As the parent agency of the State Highway Administration, the Department of Transportation (MDOT) is responsible for the state's comprehensive transportation network and safety policies, which are directly impacted by the authorization of new automated enforcement on a state highway.

The bill requires Prince George's County to remit fine revenue to the Comptroller, who is then tasked with distributing those funds to the State Highway Administration and depositing any excess funds into the state's General Fund.

The bill amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article regarding the allocation of fines and involves the District Court's role in prescribing uniform citations and adjudicating speed monitoring violations.

The bill impacts state revenue by requiring the deposit of certain excess fine collections into the General Fund and creates a dedicated funding stream for specific highway projects, requiring oversight from the state's central fiscal authority.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) serves as the legal advisor to the agencies implementing the bill, including the SHA, MDOT, and the Comptroller, regarding the implementation of the new automated enforcement rules and revenue distribution.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises on public safety policy and coordinates criminal justice strategies. The bill's establishment of a dedicated safety fund from automated enforcement fines aligns with their mission to oversee public safety resource allocation.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved in the bill's implementation and manages the state's annual budget, which will be affected by the new fine revenue distributions and safety infrastructure expenditures.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Common Ownership Community Ombudsman Unit within the Office of the Attorney General to resolve disputes and provide information to residents of condominiums, cooperatives, and homeowners associations. It mandates that these communities file their governing documents with the Department of Housing and Community Development for the creation of a public database and authorizes filing fees and fines for noncompliance. Furthermore, it establishes requirements for local county-level commissions to handle registrations, provide technical assistance, and conduct dispute resolution via mediation and hearing panels.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Office of the Attorney General, Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and local county governments
qa_results.stakeholders: Homeowners, condominium unit owners, and cooperative housing members; governing bodies and managers of common ownership communities; and local government agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures will increase for the Attorney General to staff the Ombudsman Unit and for the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) to maintain a document database. State revenues will increase from COC filing fees (up to $100 for initial filings and $25 for amendments) and a $500 fine for noncompliance. Local governments will see increased administrative costs to operate common ownership commissions, which may be offset by authorized local registration and service fees.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Common Ownership Community Ombudsman Unit specifically within the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General and directs the Attorney General to appoint the Ombudsman.

The bill requires common ownership communities to file governing documents with this Department and mandates that the Department develop, maintain, and host a public database of these documents on its website.

The bill requires local commissions on common ownership communities to include a licensed common ownership community manager; the Department of Labor is the state agency responsible for the licensing and regulation of these professionals.

The bill establishes procedures for appealing administrative decisions to the courts, sets judicial standards of review for those cases, and provides for the postponement of civil actions in the court system when a dispute is filed with a local commission.
The bill creates a new state unit and requires staff as provided in the state budget, which is formulated and managed by the Department of Budget and Management.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Housing and Community Development and is responsible for the overall implementation of laws relating to the state's administrative infrastructure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires custodians of public records to deny public inspection of most records related to divorce proceedings, including applications for divorce, financial records, settlement records, and custody orders. However, the bill does not apply to the final decree in a divorce proceeding. Access to restricted records is limited to persons in interest, their legal representatives, or individuals authorized by a court order.
qa_results.responsible_party: Custodians of public records, specifically within the Maryland Judiciary and Clerks of the Circuit Court
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals involved in divorce proceedings, legal representatives, and members of the public seeking access to court records
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the Fiscal and Policy Note; however, the bill itself does not contain any specific appropriations or funding mandates.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Administrative Office of the Courts (AOC) manages the judicial branch's records and its public-facing information systems, such as 'Case Search.' Since this bill requires custodians to deny public inspection of divorce records (applications, financial filings, and custody orders) except for the final decree, the AOC is the primary agency responsible for implementing these restrictions within the state's court system.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) acts as the chief legal advisor for the State and its agencies on the interpretation and application of the Public Information Act (PIA). The OAG would be responsible for providing legal counsel to state agencies regarding these new nondisclosure requirements and defending custodians in litigation related to denied record requests.

The Maryland State Archives is the central depository for permanent government records, including historical and legal judicial documents. This bill would require the Archives to update its public access policies for historical divorce proceeding files to ensure restricted records are only released to authorized persons in interest, rather than the general public.

The Department of Human Services (DHS), through its Child Support Administration and child welfare services, often acts as a custodian of divorce-related records such as custody orders and financial statements. Under this bill, DHS would be required to deny public inspection of these specific records in its case files unless the applicant meets one of the statutory exceptions.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. The office also oversees the various executive departments that act as custodians of public records and must ensure compliance with updated Public Information Act mandates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the terminology used for Maryland State parks that preserve and interpret the history of underrepresented communities—specifically African American, Asian, Indigenous or Native American, and Hispanic or Latino populations. It removes the word 'historical' from the general statutory classification of these units and from the official names of specific sites, including Freedman’s State Park and Port Deposit State Park.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Underrepresented populations (African American, Asian, Indigenous or Native American, and Hispanic or Latino communities), the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, and local government entities in Montgomery County, Cecil County, and Baltimore City that partner in park management.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill primarily alters terminology and park names; it does not allocate or mandate specific funding. The fiscal impact is likely minimal and administrative, involving updates to signs, maps, and official documents. While the bill references reporting requirements for funding needs for certain sites like Freedman’s State Park and Gwynns Falls State Park, it does not provide those funds itself.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the state park system, the Department of Natural Resources is the lead implementer of the terminology changes and the development of the new state parks and management plans described in the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates consultation with several existing executive commissions for input and establishes multiple new stakeholder advisory committees to oversee the management and scope of specific state parks.

The Secretary of Planning and the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust (a unit of this department) are specifically named as members of stakeholder advisory committees for the development of partnership parks.

This agency oversees the ethnic and cultural commissions—such as those for African American, Asian Pacific, and Indian Affairs—that are explicitly required to provide input on decisions related to the establishment of these state parks.
The bill requires the Department of Transportation to collaborate with the Department of Natural Resources to improve bicycle, sidewalk, and trail access to state parks.
The Chief Archaeologist of the State Highway Administration is a specifically designated member of the stakeholder advisory committee for the Port Deposit State Park.
This multi-agency initiative coordinates land-use and conservation efforts between DNR, MDP, and MDE, which aligns with the bill's focus on sustainable park development and historical preservation.
The bill requires the Department of Natural Resources to coordinate decisions with the Office of Immigrant Affairs, which is a coordinating office within the Governor's Office.
The Secretary of Commerce is a designated member of the stakeholder advisory committee for the Port Deposit State Park, reflecting the economic and developmental importance of these sites.
The Secretary of the Environment is a member of the Port Deposit stakeholder advisory committee, and the bill references the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities.
Terminology changes and a renewed focus on historical interpretation at state parks directly impact the agency's mission to market Maryland's cultural and historical assets to visitors.

The bill's focus on establishing parks that preserve and interpret the history of Black Americans aligns with the Corporation's mission to document and preserve the contributions of African American Marylanders.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the governing documents of condominiums and homeowners associations (HOAs) from unreasonably restricting the governing body of the association from installing or authorizing the installation of electric vehicle (EV) recharging equipment in common use or limited common use parking spaces. It requires governing bodies to follow standard budget processes, consider the availability of sufficient parking for the community before installation, and allows them to grant renewable three-year licenses for equipment installation and electricity supply. The bill applies retroactively to all existing covenants, declarations, and bylaws.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governing bodies of condominiums and homeowners associations
qa_results.stakeholders: Condominium and homeowners association residents, association governing boards, and electric vehicle owners or prospective owners in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The provided text does not include the associated Fiscal and Policy Note; however, the bill regulates the internal governance and budgeting of private associations and does not specify any direct state or local government expenditures or revenue changes.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Energy Administration (MEA) manages programs and grants for electric vehicle charging stations. This bill facilitates the installation of such equipment within residential associations, aligning directly with MEA's mission to increase clean energy infrastructure.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel on state property laws and its Consumer Protection Division often handles disputes regarding the governing documents of condominiums and homeowners associations.
The Maryland Clean Energy Center (MCEC) provides financing solutions and technical support to accelerate the adoption of clean energy technologies, including electric vehicle recharging equipment.

The Department of the Environment leads the state's climate change initiatives. Expanding access to residential electric vehicle charging is a key component of the state's strategy to reduce transportation-related greenhouse gas emissions.

The Maryland Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth policies. This bill affects the management and use of common areas in residential developments, which falls under smart growth and community planning considerations.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs or vetoes legislation. This bill supports the executive branch's broader initiatives regarding public safety, economic opportunity, and environmental sustainability.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the types of alcoholic beverage licenses exempt from the prohibition against holding multiple licenses in Prince George's County to include Class B (on-sale) beer and wine licenses and Class B (on-sale) beer, wine, and liquor licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license applicants and holders in Prince George's County, specifically those operating Class B (on-sale) establishments like restaurants.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor must sign or veto all legislation. This bill directly modifies regulatory statutes within the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article for Prince George's County, requiring policy review and coordination with the local delegation and the Governor's legal team.

The OAG reviews all passed legislation for constitutionality and legal sufficiency before it is signed into law. This bill amends specific licensing requirements and interest prohibitions, which requires legal vetting regarding statutory consistency.

The Comptroller serves as the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog. Changes to alcoholic beverage licensing can impact the number of active business entities in the county, influencing the collection of state excise and sales taxes and the agency's revenue forecasting.

The Department of Commerce is tasked with supporting business expansion and private investment. By removing prohibitions on holding multiple Class B licenses, this bill facilitates the expansion of restaurant and hospitality businesses in Prince George's County.

The Maryland Department of Health promotes public health and safety, including behavioral health services for substance use disorders. Legislation that expands alcoholic beverage licensing interest is relevant to the agency's broader oversight of alcohol's impact on public health metrics.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County from approving the transfer or sale of a Class A beer, wine, and liquor license to another person or location. It requires license holders to return their license to the Board if it expires or if they no longer wish to hold it, and it prohibits the Board from reissuing any such licenses that have been returned.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County
qa_results.stakeholders: Holders of Class A beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Prince George’s County, the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County, and potential alcoholic beverages license applicants.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill will result in a gradual decline in local revenues for Prince George's County as Class A beer, wine, and liquor licenses are retired and not reissued, leading to the loss of the $910 annual license fee for each license removed from circulation. There is no described impact on state revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) serves as the primary legal advisor and representative for nearly all state agencies, including local Boards of License Commissioners. This bill introduces a significant restriction on the transfer or sale of Class A alcoholic beverages licenses, which may lead to legal challenges requiring counsel and defense from the OAG.

The Comptroller is responsible for issuing various business licenses and acting as a fiscal watchdog. This legislation directly impacts the regulatory framework for Class A alcoholic beverages licenses, which are a specific category of business licensure and economic activity overseen by the Comptroller’s office.

The Department of Commerce is tasked with supporting the expansion of existing companies and promoting economic development. By prohibiting the transfer or sale of liquor licenses, this bill affects the economic value and marketability of retail businesses in Prince George’s County.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advocates for small business owners and helps them navigate economic opportunities. Many Class A license holders are small or minority-owned businesses; this bill impacts their ability to transfer or sell a key business asset, which affects their long-term equity and exit strategies.

The Governor’s Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly. This bill, being local in nature for Prince George’s County, will require executive review and action to become law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Prince George's County to enact a local law allowing the county to retain a portion of the fee (up to 10 cents per bag) that retail establishments charge customers for single-use or reusable carryout bags. Any fees collected by the county under this authority must be deposited into the county's General Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George's County Government
qa_results.stakeholders: Retail establishments and customers in Prince George's County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill authorizes Prince George's County to generate revenue for its General Fund by retaining up to 10 cents for every bag fee charged at the point of sale by local retailers. The specific revenue increase is contingent upon the county enacting a local law and the volume of bag sales. There is no impact on Maryland State revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill concerns fees for single-use and reusable bags, which is a waste reduction strategy directly related to the department's mission of protecting Maryland's land and water resources from pollution.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller oversees the financial reporting requirements of retail establishments and monitors how local fees might interact with the state's sales and use tax framework.
The Governor's Office is responsible for the final review and signing of legislation, including local government authority bills that impact county-level revenue and environmental policy.
The OAG reviews legislation for legal sufficiency and provides counsel regarding the extent of local legislative authority granted by the state to a specific county.
The Department of Commerce works to support the retail sector and small businesses, which are the primary entities responsible for collecting and processing the fees established under this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Youth Charging Reform Act expands the exclusive original jurisdiction of the Maryland juvenile court by repealing several provisions that previously required certain children to be tried in adult criminal court. Specifically, it removes the automatic transfer to adult court for children at least 14 years old charged with crimes punishable by life imprisonment, and it significantly reduces the list of offenses for which children at least 16 years old are automatically charged as adults, including abduction, kidnapping, robbery, and first-degree assault.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Juvenile Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Juveniles charged with certain serious offenses, the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, State's Attorney's Offices, the Office of the Public Defender, and law enforcement agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: A Fiscal and Policy Note was not included in the provided text. However, bills of this nature typically result in increased expenditures for the Department of Juvenile Services due to a higher volume of cases requiring juvenile detention and rehabilitative services, potentially offset by decreased expenditures for the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services due to fewer youth being held in adult facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency responsible for the management, supervision, and rehabilitation of youth in the justice system, it is the primary entity affected by a policy keeping more youth within the juvenile court system.

The bill fundamentally alters the jurisdiction of the juvenile and criminal courts, requiring this agency to manage the resulting administrative, budgetary, and technological shifts within the Judiciary.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency provides legal representation for the majority of youth in these proceedings and will need to reallocate resources and specialized staff to handle the influx of serious cases in juvenile court.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency manages the Central Repository (CJIS) and fingerprinting requirements modified by the bill, and its adult correctional facilities will see a reduction in the youth population transferred to adult jurisdiction.
The bill amends the Education Article to modify the definition of 'reportable offenses,' directly impacting how schools are notified about and respond to off-campus youth crimes.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's hub for public safety policy and funding, this office will oversee the strategic implementation of these juvenile charging reforms.
This agency is responsible for statewide law enforcement operations, including the arrest and fingerprinting of youth and reporting delinquency data to the Central Repository.
This agency coordinates the reporting of 'reportable offenses' to schools and provides technical assistance to school systems on safe learning environments impacted by these policies.
The Governor's Office provides executive leadership over the implementing departments and is responsible for the final signing or vetoing of the legislation.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the state agencies involved in the juvenile justice system and manages criminal appeals arising from these jurisdictional changes.
The shift in youth caseloads between adult and juvenile systems has a notable fiscal impact on state personnel and facility funding managed by DBM.
The Lieutenant Governor chairs task forces and leads initiatives focused on public safety and mental health, which are integral to the goals of juvenile justice reform.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes standardized requirements for food and milk product labeling in Maryland by defining and requiring the use of specific terms for 'quality dates' and 'safety dates.' Starting July 1, 2027, food and milk manufacturers and retailers must use phrases such as 'Best if used by' or 'Use by' and are prohibited from using the phrase 'Sell by' on consumer-facing labels. The Maryland Department of Health is tasked with creating educational materials to inform the public about these labeling changes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Food manufacturers, food processors, food retailers, Grade A milk plants, milk processors, Maryland consumers, and local health departments
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $125,000 in fiscal 2027 and $125,000 in fiscal 2028 to cover contractual services for food science expertise and marketing for educational programs. Local health department expenditures may increase to manage retail enforcement and compliance checks. There is no projected impact on State or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the Department of Health is responsible for creating the food labeling educational program, developing website materials, and adopting regulations for food and Grade A milk product labeling.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Department of Health and would be responsible for drafting and reviewing the new regulations required by the bill, as well as managing any related civil appeals.
The bill has a notable fiscal impact of $125,000 annually for two fiscal years, which requires DBM oversight for the allocation of general funds for contractual services in the state budget.
The MDA regulates Maryland's agricultural industry and safeguards the food supply; the new standards for food and milk labeling intersect with their consumer protection and marketing missions.
The MFCA manages the state's wholesale food distribution infrastructure; the new labeling requirements will impact the food processors and retailers that distribute products through their facilities.

The OAH provides the forum for residents or businesses to challenge administrative decisions made by the Department of Health, which would include enforcement actions or penalties related to the new labeling standards.
The bill requires the Department of Health to post educational materials and program information on its website, which involves the digital services and infrastructure overseen by DoIT.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the Maryland income tax standard deduction from $3,350 to $4,100 for individual taxpayers and from $6,700 to $8,200 for joint filers, heads of household, and surviving spouses. Additionally, the bill provides for an annual cost-of-living adjustment to these deduction amounts starting in taxable year 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland individual income taxpayers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill will lead to a decrease in State general fund revenues and local income tax revenues as it increases the standard deduction, which reduces the Maryland taxable income of individuals who do not itemize deductions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the state's primary tax collector and is responsible for administering the income tax system. This bill directly alters the tax code the agency enforces and specifically tasks the Comptroller with calculating annual cost-of-living adjustments for the standard deduction.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for estimating state revenues and formulating the annual operating budget. A significant increase in the standard deduction will reduce general fund revenues, directly impacting the agency's fiscal forecasting and budget planning duties.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of all state departments and is responsible for drafting the annual budget. The fiscal impact of this tax deduction change affects the Governor's ability to fund statewide initiatives and requires executive action to sign the legislation into law.

The State Treasurer's Office manages the state's financial assets and cash flow. Notable reductions in income tax revenue impact the overall fiscal health and cash management strategies managed by the Treasurer, who also advises on the state's credit rating and bond management.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill restricts the authority of the Child Support Administration (CSA) to request the suspension of a driver's license for child support arrearages. It mandates that CSA verify an obligor has the financial means to pay but is consciously withholding payment and that other enforcement mechanisms have failed before initiating a suspension. Additionally, the bill expands the grounds for contesting a suspension—including cases where the child resides primarily with the obligor—and requires that all suspension notices be sent both in writing and electronically.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services (Child Support Administration), the Maryland Department of Transportation (Motor Vehicle Administration), and the Office of Administrative Hearings
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals who are 120 days or more out of compliance with child support payments (obligors), recipients of child support payments (obligees), and children entitled to support.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to increase administrative expenditures for the Department of Human Services (DHS) to implement new verification, investigation, and dual-notification procedures. Special fund revenues for the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) may decrease if fewer driver's licenses are suspended, leading to a reduction in the collection of license reinstatement fees.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Child Support Administration, which is a unit within DHS, is the primary entity responsible for verifying arrearages, conducting investigations into non-compliance, and notifying the MVA of necessary license suspensions under the bill.

The bill explicitly mandates the MVA to suspend licenses upon notification from the Child Support Administration, provides for the issuance of work-restricted licenses, and requires the MVA to provide notice to obligors.

The OAH is designated as the venue for appeals regarding child support compliance investigations and is specifically required to cooperate with the Secretaries of Transportation and Human Services to adopt implementation regulations.

As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration, MDOT is responsible for the overarching transportation network and the Secretary of Transportation must cooperate in drafting the required implementation regulations.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor and representative for DHS and MDOT, and would handle the legal and criminal appeals related to child support enforcement and license suspension.

The court system issues the underlying child support orders that establish the obligations and arrearages mentioned in the bill, and the AOC manages the infrastructure supporting these judicial determinations.
DBM oversees the fiscal and personnel implications of implementing the bill’s new requirements for verification, investigation, and electronic notification by executive agencies.

As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of DHS and MDOT and is responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating statewide initiatives related to child well-being and economic opportunity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the composition of the Maryland–Ireland Trade Commission by reducing the number of legislative members and adding two representatives from the private sector. It also extends the commission's termination date from September 30, 2026, to September 30, 2028, and mandates that the commission submit annual reports regarding bilateral trade, investment, and academic exchanges between Maryland and Ireland.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: The Irish-American community, private sector businesses, Maryland public higher education institutions, the Maryland Chamber of Commerce, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The extension of the commission's operations through September 2028 will result in continued minimal state expenditures for the Department of Commerce to provide staff support and for member travel reimbursements. The bill is not expected to affect state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland–Ireland Trade Commission is established within the Department of Commerce, and the Secretary of Commerce (or their designee) is a mandated member of the commission.
The Secretary of State is a mandated member of the Commission, which focuses on international trade relations.

As a division within the Office of the Secretary of State, this agency leads global engagement and manages international strategy, directly aligning with the Commission's goal to promote trade and academic exchanges with Ireland.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland–Ireland Trade Commission is a specialized advisory body created by the General Assembly to study and recommend policy on a specific area of public concern (international trade).
The Governor appoints several members of the Commission and receives its annual reports on trade findings and recommendations.
This office is responsible for vetting the various public and private sector candidates appointed by the Governor to serve on this commission.

The Commission's membership includes a representative of a public institution of higher education, and the Commission is tasked with promoting academic exchanges, which falls under MHEC's coordination of statewide higher education policy.

As the primary provider of public higher education in the state, the University System is a key stakeholder for the seat on the Commission reserved for a representative of a public institution of higher education.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the criteria for disqualifying individuals from jury service based on criminal convictions. It replaces the disqualification of anyone who received a sentence of more than one year with a disqualification only for those currently serving a sentence (including parole or probation) for a crime punishable by more than one year. It also adds specific disqualifications for individuals convicted of perjury, witness or jury intimidation, or fraud-related crimes, and repeals a provision regarding pardons.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Judiciary (Administrative Office of the Courts)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with past criminal convictions, the Maryland court system, and prospective jurors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $28,100 in FY 2027 only for the Judiciary to update juror qualification forms and systems. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Judiciary, specifically the Administrative Office of the Courts, is the primary implementing agency for the bill, as it is responsible for the administration of jury service, the updating of online and printed juror qualification forms, and managing the associated fiscal costs for system programming.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency oversees the Division of Parole and Probation and maintains the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which are essential resources for verifying whether prospective jurors are currently serving sentences or have disqualifying convictions.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation into law and oversees the clemency and pardon processes, which are directly referenced in the bill's repeal of redundant pardon-related jury qualification provisions.
As the state's central fiscal authority, this agency oversees the general fund and the budgetary process related to the fiscal impact of programming updates needed by the Judiciary.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the Judiciary and other executive agencies, providing counsel on the interpretation and application of revised qualification standards for jury service.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County to issue Class A beer or Class A beer and wine licenses to certain retail grocery stores located within the Capital Beltway. To qualify, an establishment must offer a full line of food products, dedicate at least 50% of its public square footage to food and beverages, and derive at least 50% of its average monthly gross receipts from food sales. The bill also waives the general prohibition against one person or entity holding multiple alcoholic beverages licenses for these specific licenses and requires the Board to submit an annual report on the licenses to the Governor and General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County
qa_results.stakeholders: Retail grocery store owners inside the Capital Beltway in Prince George's County, the Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners, and county residents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Prince George's County revenues will increase from the collection of new Class A license fees. County expenditures will increase for the Board of License Commissioners to process applications, verify that stores meet the required 50% food sales and square footage thresholds, and fulfill the annual reporting requirement. There is no significant impact on state revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill includes a specific statutory requirement (Section 26-1509.1(D)) that the Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners must report annually to the Governor by September 1 regarding the number of licenses issued and applications pending under this new law.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for collecting excise and sales taxes on alcoholic beverages. Expanding the number of retail licenses for beer and wine in a large jurisdiction like Prince George's County has a direct fiscal impact on revenue collection and auditing.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Governor and the General Assembly regarding the implementation of state laws. This bill amends the 'Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis' article to create a specific local exception to general prohibitions, which may require legal interpretation or advisory opinions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the statutory limit on the number of Class B beer, wine, and liquor licenses that the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County can issue, which was previously capped at 215 licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license applicants and holders in Prince George's County, the Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners, and the county government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill will likely increase local revenues for Prince George's County due to additional license application and renewal fees. Local expenditures for the Board of License Commissioners may increase to process and monitor the additional licenses issued under the repealed cap.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is relevant as the primary executive authority responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. Furthermore, the Governor appoints the members of the Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners, the body whose licensing limits are being modified by this bill.

This office vets candidates for state-level boards and commissions, including the Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners. A change in the licensing capacity of the board directly impacts the operational scope and recruitment needs for these gubernatorial appointees.

The Comptroller is the state's tax collector. Repealing the limit on Class B licenses likely increases the number of restaurants and bars in the county, resulting in a notable fiscal impact through increased collection of state sales and use taxes on alcoholic beverages.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state boards and agencies. It would provide legal counsel to the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County regarding the interpretation and implementation of the revised licensing limits.

Removing limits on liquor licenses stimulates private investment and business expansion in the hospitality sector, aligning with the Department of Commerce's mission to foster job creation and attract new businesses to Maryland.

DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and overseeing the executive budget. The potential increase in state tax revenue resulting from a higher volume of liquor licenses and associated alcohol sales is relevant to their fiscal forecasting.

Decisions regarding the issuance or denial of alcoholic beverages licenses can be appealed to the Maryland judicial system. An increase in the number of potential licenses may lead to a higher volume of administrative appeals handled by the courts.

The MDH oversees local health departments, which are responsible for the regulatory inspection and licensing of the food service operations that typically accompany Class B beer, wine, and liquor licenses.
